headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead.
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being record
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section in the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. 
In the fourth quarter of 2015, we realigned to the reporting structure of our direct-to-consumer reseller business and that it now reports into our Personal Solutions business. Previously, direct-to-consumer resellers were reported within the USIS and International segments based on the country of the customer. We have provided the quarterly history for Personal Solutions, USIS and International, and the new format for each quarter in 2014 and 2015 in the Q&A section of our earnings release. All discussion of the 2015 business unit performance and their outlook for 2016 will be consistent with the new structure. 
Earlier this week, the Veda shareholders voted to accept Equifax's acquisition offer, and we also received subsequent approval from the courts. Therefore, the 2016 guidance that are provided today as well as the updated long-term business model for Equifax, which is included in the Q&A section of our earnings release, both include the impact of the Veda acquisition. However, our guidance for the first quarter of 2016 will not include any impact from Veda, including the incremental cost of the debt given the short amount of time that it will be part of Equifax in the quarter. 
During this call, as in previous earnings releases, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted operating margins, which will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. In 2016, we will be emphasizing adjusted EBITDA margin in discussing our operational performance. Adjusted EBITDA is defined as operating income adding back depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain onetime items, including the acquisition and integration expenses from Veda, which are also reflected in our definition of adjusted EPS. These non-GAAP measures are detailed in reconciliation tables posted on our website. 
During this call, Bill be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax in this business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in the filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and the subsequent filings. Please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. Execution across all of our 4 business units continues to be very strong and enabled us to deliver yet another strong quarter in the fourth quarter as well as the
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning. 
Execution across all of our 4 business units continues to be very strong and enabled us to deliver yet another strong quarter in the fourth quarter as well as the full year. For the quarter, fourth quarter 2015, total revenue was $666 million, up 7% on a reported basis and up 10% on a local currency basis from 2014. For the quarter, FX created $18 million of year-over-year headwind for us. The adjusted operating margin was 27.1%, up from 26.5% in the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.14, up 12% from $1.02 in 2014. And just to refresh your memory, that exceeded the upper end of the guidance range we provided on the last call, which is $1.10 to $1.12. 
Finally, given our strong performance in 2015, our Board of Directors approved a 14% increase in our quarterly dividend up to now $0.33 a quarter, and this is, as you probably all know, the sixth consecutive double-digit increase in our dividend rate, reflecting the strong performance of the company. I think you'll agree on many dimensions. 2015 was outstanding year for our 117-year-old business. We exceeded our expectations. We have broad-based contributions from each business unit, industrial verticals and across the vast majority of our geographies, our team delivered. We're well positioned for a strong 2016. We'll talk about the economic environment in the Q&A, and I'm proud of the team for their continued commitment to innovation, execution, outstanding customer service. 
For the full year, total revenue is $2.7 billion, up 9% on a reported basis and up 12% on a local currency basis for 2014. And for the year, FX created a $76 million year-over-year headwind. Adjusted operating margin was 27.4%, up 90 basis points from 26.5% in 2014 and well above the targeted 25 basis points or so increase we guided to in the past. Adjusted EPS was $4.15, up 16% from $3.89 a year ago. And just as a reminder, that performance in 2015 was all organically driven as we had no acquisitions in the year. As always, our transition to the business units for some brief commentary before John gives you details. I'll go through some highlights for the business as well and then we'll get to more specifics. 
Let me talk, first of all, Jeff mentioned in his opening comments, we repositioned PSOL in 2015. You know that this team has been working diligently on their new growth model, which I fully support, and it's yielding benefits, and John will go through some of those numbers. at The same time, I made the decision that it was important we had one team, one leader, one business that we manage all strategy, all product positioning in the geographies for our consumer business regardless of that business going direct to the consumer or if it was going through a reseller. So we made the decision to realign that under Daniel Adams now who leads our direct-to-consumer businesses globally. I think that gives us more continuity going forward. 
Now on to the businesses themselves. USIS delivered an impressive 8% revenue growth for the year while expanding its operating margins 290 basis points. Our insights-driven strategy, which we've talked about, has resonated extremely well of our largest clients in key our client program. Our KCP customers are purchasing multiple Decision 360 products and services in aggregate access almost 5 Equifax data products, which is remarkable. Across our Top 100 clients, Decision 360 products and services are increasing as well, and there, they're accessing about 3 products on average. So D360 is really making a difference in the marketplace for us. 
In USIS, our product management solutions business again delivered healthy 22% growth for the year, largely driven by their ID authentication and management solution products. Our enterprise vertical strategy has made significant contributions to our total company revenue growth. We experienced industry executives in these verticals. We are better able to leverage our diverse data assets, analytical expertise in IT platforms to deliver premier Decision Solutions. USIS leads many of our enterprise vertical initiatives. To give you an example, a few of those in 2015, our vertical grew 25% in USIS and 29% for the total company. This again compares favorably to the average Mortgage Bankers Application index, which was up 17% for the year. So that trend of outperforming the mortgage market has continued now for many, many years. Next example is in the auto vertical, which USIS revenue grew 6% and total company grew 9%. This also compares very favorably to the overall market where verticals -- sales approximately 5%. And more recently, our retail banking vertical grew USIS revenue 17% and total company revenue by 18%. So you get a sense there that there's enterprise focus taking all over data assets and seasoned leaders in each vertical and delivering those unique assets to our customers is enabling us to grow significantly, in many cases, faster than market itself. 
For years now, we've been working with Fannie Mae on ways to better leverage our information to further improve the underwriting process for mortgage loans. Late in 2015, Fannie Mae made the decision to incorporate credit data into the underwriting process for mortgage lending. We talked about this with you in the past. This initiative will be important contributor to revenue in both 2016 and 2017. It also represents a significant structural change in the loan underwriting and it sets the stage for applications outside the mortgage lending to increasingly use trended data and our world-class analytical talent and leverage our Cambrian platform, which we talked about before. We're well positioned to take advantage of those opportunities as they arrive -- arise. Live testing is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2016 and go live midyear. More importantly, trended data will be available through our core credit online delivery system, making them information available for all solutions that access our credit database. 
Opportunities for USIS in 2016 and beyond are significant. Trended data, ID and fraud for the penetration on targeted vertical markets are all expected to make important contributions to sustained revenue growth. Our multi-year model for USIS remains, as we've communicated to you before, with top line growth in the 5% to 7% range. And adjusted EBITDA margin, which we'll now talk about going forward, is expected to be in the high 40s expanding to the low 50s over time. International delivered 12% local currency revenue growth with strong performance coming from our operations in Europe, in Latin America. Revenue in International's 3 largest verticals, FIs, telcos and small, medium-sized enterprises grew 13% in 2015. Our decision platforms, analytic solutions and debt management revenue grew 12% in 2015. Europe had an outstanding year, driven by largely by broad-based growth in our U.K. operations. By industry, FI, telco, SMEs all grew high to low double digits for the year. By offering Decision Solutions, analytical services and debt management all grew at double-digit rates in 2015. 
TDX has been working, as you know, with U.K. government to manage their past-due consumer debt in fourth quarter 2015 and started receiving accounts at that time, and we started placing those accounts with a collection analyzing the data in the fourth quarter of last year. And while still early, the performance of the data is slightly ahead of our expectations. This opportunity, along with our ongoing sales efforts, is expected to be a significant strategic initiative driving growth for International for years to come. International historically delivered some of our strongest performance in New Product Innovation, which has been a significant contributor to the incremental revenue growth, further market penetration obviously customer loyalty to build products and solutions that we couldn't build in the past. This broad-based effort towards innovation continues to fuel growth for International. For the year, our 6 geographies in International, represents almost 2/3 of the revenue delivered an NPI Vitality Index of 10% or greater, which is fabulous. International has some exciting opportunities ahead of it, in addition to try [indiscernible] will come back and talk later, which will become a part of the International operation. In 2016, we broadly expanded Cambrian, deploying it across the International geographies, substantially enhancing our ability to deliver analytical insights and drive growth. The continued excellent performance with new products and cost benefits and the regionalization efforts begun last year as well as the addition to Veda will expand EBITDA margins in 2016 and beyond. 
We have moderately raised our expectations for multi-year growth in International now to range of 7 -- or 8% to 10%, with adjusted EBITDA margins in the low 30s growing to mid 30s over time. Both of those measures in top line and EBITDA margin reflect the anticipated close of Veda. 
On to Workforce Solutions. They grew 18% last year. It was an outstanding performance as was their 510 basis point margin expansion for the year. Core product growth, along with a number of new product initiatives, all contributed to this outstanding performance. Verification Services is strong and broad-based growth of 25% in the year continues to be driven by adding records in the Work Number database. As their coverage of individual employment records increases the valuable service enables us to further penetrate our key targets verticals, including mortgage, auto, consumer finance, government and preemployment. All those verticals, every one of them, was up a strong double digit for the year. Just amazingly strong, balanced growth. 
At year-end, the Work Number database reached almost 280 million records as we stated before. We're well on our way to achieving 300 million records in total. The recent emergence of what they call the instant mortgage facilitated through online application process has generated new growth opportunities for automated income and employment verification. We recently signed one of the largest players in this space because of our unique ability to deliver both the credit information as well as the employment and income verification simultaneously and speeding up the process and enhancing the consumer experience. 
Within EWS, the Employer Services business also had another very strong year in 2015, growing 8%. Much of this growth was driven by our Workforce Analytics offering, which we talk to you about before. This allows employers to ensure that they are compliant with the Affordable Care Act as well as providing ACA-required tax information to employees. Workforce Analytics doubled their business in 2015 and is expected to more than double again in 2016. Our Workforce Analytics client base now is approaching over 800 clients with the pipeline remains very strong. To date, our solutions has largely been focused on our larger enterprise customers in 2016. We're starting to go down market, enabling us to capture relationships with smaller employees, which we can offer cross-sell opportunities with our other employee services offerings. Health care-related revenue generated by both our income verification and the Affordable Care Act to find solutions more than doubled in 2015 versus 2014. And workforce solutions has delivered a stellar performance not just in 2015 but over the last 9 years. As a business, they were quick to adopt our approach to innovate and to embrace LEAN. As a result, they've outperformed on revenue growth and substantially improved their margin. Looking forward, expanding and further penetrating their key markets and verticals, increasing their number of records in the Work Number database and globalizing their footprint, we'll continue to drive revenue growth and margin expansion. Our multi-year expectation for Workforce Solutions has been increased. Now expecting revenue growth of 9% to 11%, with adjusted EBITDA margin in the high-40% range expanding to low 50s over time. 
Personal Solutions finalized its strategic transformation and it's executing well against its four-pronged strategy. For the year, the newly constructed global Personal Solutions delivered 19% local currency growth -- revenue growth and is well positioned to for 2016 and beyond. Revenue growth from our direct and indirect consumer activities continues to meet our expectations. Revenue growth in our Personal Solutions business in Canada and U.K. was up a nice 7% in 2015. In the U.S., we continue to perform consistent with our expectations with increasing ARPU and lowering subscriber churn. Our direct-to-consumer resellers were the most significant contributor to Personal Solutions in 2015. We talked about that one as a part of the USIS. Our reseller revenues in both Canada and the U.K. grew solid as well. It's solid double digit, in fact, in 2015. And the reseller revenue -- reseller revenue in U.S. was very strong, primarily driven by the 2-year contract where leading companies in this space, credit and we talked to you about that. We're also well positioned for continued growth in 2016 and makes an addition of a new reseller [indiscernible] we signed a multiyear contract a few months back. 
With our broad-based portfolio of data assets, we believe there'll be additional opportunities in 2016 and beyond to provide a broader array of credit, income and fraud services the consumers to our direct and reseller channel. Under the new organizational structure, our multi-year expectation for revenue growth in PSol is now 5% to 8%, up from the previous target of 4% to 6%. Adjusted EBITDA margin is expected to be in the low 30s expanding to the mid-30s over time. The outsized growth in 2015 was primarily driven by the start-up of our relationship with Credit Karma, the largest of our DTC, direct-to-consumer the resellers. In 2016, we'll anniversary this revenue, so long-term growth rates from PSol will revert back to more normal levels again at 5% to 8% with strong growth going forward. 
Now on to some corporate highlights before I turn the mic over to John to give you more details on the financials. Today, we have a truly global company with a global set of processes deployed around the world, a global structure, a global culture and a group that's all focused on the core set of global strategic imperatives. Over the years, we've globalized our most critical and fundamental management to facilitate greater linkage between our strategy and our execution. And through this effort, we have streamlined our product innovation and placement. We've enabled greater leverage of our IT platforms. We've optimized the investment of our talent. We've more effectively moved our talent and products where greatest opportunities exist. This globalization also enable us to better and more quickly leverage the skills and expertise that often one market, i.e. in USIS, into another market in International. Again, that's both processes, products and people. Everybody in the company is measured in they contribute to our imperatives regardless of what part of the organization they reside. 
Having reinvigorated our NPI and New Product Innovation, what we talked to you about last year about 2.0 and the next phase of innovation, we launched 64 new products last year. Along with the pipeline of 2016 launches, we expect the revenue contributions to deliver strong NPI growth in 2016 and beyond. Our largest and most diverse growth opportunities are executed under our Enterprise Growth Initiatives we call EGI. In 2015, year-over-year revenue, growth from these large initiatives, was over 20%, and so 20% growth over 2014. In 2015, we exceeded our expectations for NPI revenues by 6%. Furthermore, I've discussed with you in the past, the class of products we launched in 2015 under our revitalized effort of 2.0 are expected to deliver a record level of revenue, year 3 revenue when compared to prior year launches. It is the healthiest class of products that we've launched since NPI has been in existence here. One of the more exciting new product opportunities revolves around trended data. The effort and investment we're making to fulfill our commitments to Fannie Mae will be leveraged across all of our unique data assets. We firmly believe that the next horizon for information-based solution is trended data, which will underpin more powerful decision and solutions for our customers and significantly improve our competitive position. So to be clear, our focus is trending as many of our unique data assets, which truly unique only to Equifax or our customers to provide these values, so things like the Work Number and C+ and others. 
Finally, as of many of our corporate management documents, our global NPI process will be implemented in Veda once we complete the acquisition. Now I'll review that in a moment. In 2015, we launched our Big Data platform called Cambrian. Cambrian will enable faster development and delivery analytical insights, including improving the speed in which we develop new products. It'll also greatly enhance our Decision 360 capabilities and provide significant competitive advantage using advanced Veda analytic techniques. Other corporate impairment for us has been about LEAN. LEAN continues to make incremental contributions to our expense leverage and exceeded our goal by contributing over 30% greater benefit in 2015 than we had budgeted. And we leveraged our expertise in LEAN principles to deepen our relationships with some of our largest customers with projects that help them streamline many of their operational activities, and that obviously provides a competitive differentiator boost in the marketplace. 
Let me close before I give it to John and talk a little bit about Veda. I'm sure many of you are aware that the regulatory approval of Veda received in December enabled them to schedule a shareholder meeting, which Jeff alluded to a little bit ago. They had a shareholder meeting on February 8 and gained approval there, and they've also received a the final Court approval this week. And at this point, it's our expectation to close the acquisition at the end of February of this year. We're very excited about this opportunity they represent for us. They have great strategy, strong financial performance, outstanding management team, great market position. And they also give us a significant opportunity in the Asia Pacific geography of further broadening and enhancing our geographic footprint, which is important to us as we diversify revenue stream. As we move into our first quarter earnings call and beyond, obviously we'll keep you apprised of the strategic and the financial progress of that the team is making with his new asset. 
In closing, our performance in 2015 exemplifies the culture and the strength of our management team and our dedication and the entire organization to innovate and execute for our customers. It's a culture and a process that has taken years to develop, and it underpins the confidence we have in our ability to continue delivering on our commitments and to make our customers and shareholders satisfied with that performance. Our strategic imperatives as we enter 2016 are a few areas. They are very important to us. We cascade this around the world. One, obviously, is to deliver strong and consistent profitable growth and shareholder returns; two, to develop unparalleled analytically insights, leveraging the unique data assets in Equifax has; three is to innovate for market leadership in key domains and verticals in which we operate; four, is to serve the trusted steward and advocate for customers and consumers around the world; and obviously, closing the last, to invest in talent to drive that strategy and foster a culture of innovation. 
So with that, john, as you always do, please go through the financials.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the fourth quarter. As Jeff mentio
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. 
Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the fourth quarter. As Jeff mentioned at the opening, all this information is based on the new segments with direct-to-consumer resellers moved into PSol from USIS and International. Going forward, given the substantial amortization expense related to the Veda acquisition, we will increase our discussion of EBITDA for Equifax and the operating segments. 
U.S. Information Solutions revenue in 4Q '15 was $296 million, up 7% when compared to the fourth quarter of '14. For the full year, revenue of $1.2 billion was up 8%. This compares favorably to our long-term expectation for USIS of 5% to 7% growth as both mortgage and automotive were very strong in 2015. 
Online Information Solutions revenue was $204 million in 4Q '15, up 6% year-to-year and $842 million for the full year, up 8% when compared to the prior year. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $28 million in 4Q '15, up 10% year-to-year and $124 million for calendar year '15, up 17%. Total mortgage-related revenue was up 16% and 17% in the quarter for USIS and Equifax, respectively. For calendar year '15, mortgage-related revenue was up 25% and 29% for USIS and Equifax, respectively. This compares favorably to the average Mortgage Bankers Application index, which was up 14% in the fourth quarter and 17% for the calendar year. 
Financial Marketing Services revenue was $64 million in 4Q '15, up 7% year-to-year and $205 million for calendar year '15, up 5% year-to-year. The operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 41.6% in 4Q '15 and 41.9% for calendar year '15, up 50 basis points and 290, respectively. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 48.5% in 4Q '15 and 49.7% in calendar year '15. We expect to see continued expansion in the USIS EBITDA margins in 2016. 
International's revenue was $143 million in 4Q '15, down 1% on a reported basis but up 11% on a local currency basis. Revenue was $569 million for calendar year '15, down 1% on a reported basis but up 12% on a local currency basis. By region, Europe's revenue was $64 million in 4Q '15, up 3% in U.S. dollars and up 10% in local currency. For calendar year '15, Europe revenue was $247 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and up 12% on local currency. Latin America's revenue was $49 million in 4Q '15, up 2% in U.S. dollars and 18% in local currency. Revenue was $200 million for calendar year '15, up 4% in U.S. dollars and 17% in local currency. Latin America showed outstanding local currency growth throughout '15, led by strong growth across Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. 
Canada revenue was $29 million, down 11% in U.S. dollars but up 5% in local currency. Revenue for calendar year '15 was $122 million in U.S. dollars, down 11% U.S. dollars but up 3% in local currency. Canada's performance strengthened very nicely in the second half and has momentum going into 2016. 
International's operating margin was 20.7% in 4Q '15 and 20% in calendar year '15. EBITDA margins were 27.2% in 4Q '15 and 27% in calendar year '15. Both operating and EBITDA margins were down year-to-year in International, however, both showed sequential improvement in the fourth quarter relative to the third. In 2016, we expect to see continued margin improvement, driven by continued strong local currency growth and the benefits of regionalization as well as from the addition of Veda. We'll see some margin pressure related to weakened foreign currencies, particularly with the Canadian dollar and the devaluation of the Argentinean peso. 
Workforce Solutions revenue was $144 million in the quarter, up 12% year-to-year and $578 million in calendar year '15, up 18% year-on-year. This reflects continued very strong growth in Verification Services, up 14% in fourth quarter and 25% year-to-year. Employer services also delivered a very strong performance, up 8% in the fourth quarter and 8% in the calendar year. This was driven by success in their Compliance Center offerings and their solution for employers' compliance that are the requirements of the ACA. The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 36.8% in 4Q '15 and 37.9% in calendar year '15, up 430 and 510 basis points, respectively. Workforce Solutions EBITDA margins were 44.3% in the fourth quarter and 45.1% in the calendar year. We expect continued strong expansion of Workforce Solutions EBITDA margins in 2016. 
Global Personal Solutions revenue of $84 million in 4Q '15, up 12% on a reported basis and up 14% on local currency basis. Revenue in calendar year '15 was $346 million, up 18% on a reported basis and up 19% on a local currency basis. PSol's business has 2 main areas: credit and identity monitoring services sold through direct and indirect channels that protect and monitor consumers' ID and enable consumers to gain better access to credit, and credit another data sales sold through our DTC reseller partners. Credit and identity monitoring services sold through the indirect channel represent those circumstances where Equifax provides white label online credit and identity services through partners. In 2015, ongoing revenue from credit and identity monitoring services grew at the high end of 4% to 6% guidance range we have previously provided for the PSOL segment prior to the addition of DTC sellers. DTC reseller's revenue represent sales of credit and other data to resellers. In these cases, Equifax provides data and analytics but not the web properties with which the customer directly interacts. Examples of these business are relationships with Credit Karma and LifeLock. DTC reseller revenue showed substantial growth in 2015, driven primarily by our relationship with Credit Karma, which began in 4Q '14. Our DTC reseller revenue should continue to grow faster than our direct-to-consumer sales, but as Rick mentioned, not at the very high rate you saw in 2015. 
Looking forward, as previously mentioned, we expect this overall segment to grow 5% to 8%. Operating margin was 27% in 4Q '15 and 27.5% for calendar year '15, consistent with our expectations. EBITDA margins were 29.7% in 4Q '15 and 30.2% in calendar year '15. PSOL revenue and operating margin in the 4Q '14 [ph] were very strong, reflecting a large reach deal won in 4Q '14. 4Q '15 operating margin of 27% was consistent with our expectations and our guidance and reflects the impact of our decision to invest more in marketing in 2015 as well as the addition of DTC reseller business to PSOL. 
In the fourth quarter, general corporate expense was $51 million, excluding $3.7 million for onetime expenses associated with the Veda acquisition, general corporate expense was up slightly from 3Q, consistent with our guidance. For the first quarter of 2016, we expect general corporate expense, excluding Veda-related acquisition and integration expenses, to be in the range of $55 million to $60 million and run at a slightly lower rate throughout the remaining quarters of the year. The adjusted operating margin at 27.1% in 4Q '15 and 27.4% in calendar year '15 were up 60 and 90 basis points year-to-year, respectively. Adjusted EBITDA margins were 34.4% in 4Q '15 and 34.8% in calendar year '15. We expect to see improvements in our adjusted EBITDA margin in 2016 expanding by about 75 basis points. Our GAAP effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 32.6%, equal to our expectation and in our guidance. For the full year, our non-GAAP effective tax rate, after adjusting for non-GAAP items, the Missouri state tax law change in the second quarter and TDX escrow adjustment in third quarter, was 33.7% consistent with our comments during our third quarter release. Looking forward into 2016, our expectation is for a GAAP effective tax rate of about 33%. 
Operating cash flow was $205 million in 4Q '15 and $742 million in calendar year '15. Both were very strong, reflecting strong earnings and working capital performance. Free cash flow, equal to operating cash flow less capital expenditures, was very strong in 2015 at $596 million, up 12% from 2014. 
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $53 million and for calendar year '15 were $146 million. Consistent with our comments throughout the year, the increase in capital spending versus 2014 reflects the acceleration of our investment in New Product Innovation, deployment of global platforms, including Cambrian and other analytics, InterConnect, fraud, and our PSol infrastructure. As we look forward to 2016, we expect capital spending, including Veda, to be in the range of 5% to 6% of revenue. This is consistent with 2015 and reflects a continuation of our current investments as well as some additional spending in the near term as we integrate Veda. This is slightly higher than our expected long-term rate of capital spending of about 5% of revenue due to the Veda integration.
As Rick indicated, we have received Veda shareholder approval and approval from the Australian courts to complete the purchase of Veda. We expect the acquisition to close on about February 25. Total purchase price, including assumed debt and fees, is approximately USD 1.9 billion. At the close of the Veda transaction, we will have debt outstanding of just under $3.1 billion and debt to EBITDA on a trailing basis of just under 3x. As indicated previously, we expect to maintain our current credit ratings. In 2016, we will focus on using our very strong cash flow for debt reduction and returning our leverage to a level consistent with our current credit rating. Therefore, we do not intend to repurchase shares in 2016. We will, however, continue with acquisitions beyond Veda in 2016 with a goal of delivering on our long-term model of an additional 1 to 2 points of revenue growth. Assuming acquisitions consistent with our targets in 2016 and 2017, we would expect to repurchase shares in 2017. 
As we discussed last quarter, we will exclude Veda transactions and other acquisition expenses and integration expenses incurred in the first year after the Veda acquisition through 1Q '17 and calculating adjusted EPS and adjusted operating margin and EBITDA margin. We will provide information regarding transaction and acquisition expenses incurred with the acquisition as well as integration expenses we expect to incur related to the Veda acquisition after the transaction closes at our 1Q '16 Earnings Release Conference Call. Also, Jeff mentioned at the beginning of the call, given the relatively short time we will own Veda in the quarter, our 1Q '16 guidance does not include the impact of Veda nor the incremental debt cost, including interest expense related to the acquisition. We will provide you details on the impact of Veda on 1Q '16 during our 1Q '16 earnings call in April. 
The 2016 full year guidance Rick will provide includes Veda. For 2016, we have assumed Veda will be part of Equifax for 10 months. Veda revenue for 10 months is assumed to be USD 220 million to USD 230 million. This include an estimate of the impact to revenue of U.S. GAAP, which will be updated as we close 1Q '16. The benefit to adjusted EPS from Veda, net of acquisition financing cost, is about $0.10 to $0.15 per share. As a reminder, adjusted EPS excludes acquisition amortization expense. For modeling purposes, you can assume an average cost of our Veda acquisition debt during 2016 of about 2.5%. Veda's seasonality of revenues is similar to Equifax, with 2Q revenue typically the highest from a seasonality perspective, 1Q generally the lowest revenue, and 3Q and 4Q somewhat similar in terms of revenue. The spread between 2Q and 1Q revenue has recently been in the range of 7% to 10%. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Some summary comments before we go to the Q&A. As I've mentioned before to all of you and many of you noted in our conversations and in the write ups, the level of execution and the momentum this team has generated in 2015 is the best in my
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Some summary comments before we go to the Q&A. As I've mentioned before to all of you and many of you noted in our conversations and in the write ups, the level of execution and the momentum this team has generated in 2015 is the best in my 10 years here. I think it's truly remarkable what they've done. We are well positioned for growth opportunities that lie ahead and our ability to take care -- to take on any of the challenges that may confront us. In the coming years, the incremental revenue that would be contributing from class of new products that we just launched, we expect it to exceed our historical average. That's the wind in our back. Our enterprise growth initiatives, including the expanded insights, driven by Cambrian, healthcare, trended data and auto, will not only enhance our competitive position but also deliver growth opportunities for years to come. All of these efforts are expected, in our opinion, to offset the anticipated slowdown of U.S. mortgage market, which, as you know, started to decelerate over the course of 2015. While it's impossible to predict where the mortgage market is going to go, especially when I look this morning at 10-year Treasury under 1.6, forecast range from down 20% to up mid-single digits. Our forecast that we're giving you for 2016 is anticipating that the mortgage market will be down single digits in 2016. And obviously, our expectation of the team in both Workforce Solutions and USIS, as they have done for many, many years, outperforms that quite significantly. Obviously, if rates continue to stay low as they are, there may be some market upside to what occurs in the mortgage market, and we'll all know obviously when we head deeper into the year. 
2016 is yet again expected to be another strong year performance for the company. For the year, we expect revenue, including the impact of Veda, to be between $3 billion and $3.1 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of the '15% to 19%. That's going to be partially offset by 2 to 3 points of FX headwind. This is consistent with our comments in October that the organic constant currency growth would be at the high end of our long-term range of 6% to 8%. I got to say it again, that's at the high end of our range coming off at constant currency growth last year of 12%. So it's, I think, quite remarkable. As John mentioned, we also expect to add another 1 to 2 points of tuck-in acquisitions throughout the year. These additional acquisitions are obviously beyond Veda, which as you said is not including our 2000 -- I'm sorry, in the first [ph] quarter of 2016 outlook. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $4.95 and $5.05, which is up 10% to 12% per year, excluding approximately $0.13 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 13% to 15%. For the first quarter, we expect organic revenue to be between $685 million and $695 billion, reflecting constant currency organic revenue growth of 8% to 10%. That will be partially offset by about 3 points of FX headwinds in the quarter. First quarter adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.14 and $1.16, which is up 7% to 8%, excluding $0.04 per share of negative impact on FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 10% to 12% to the first quarter. Again, we expect to close the Veda in the first quarter, but we'll not include that in the estimate. Maybe in the Q&A, we'll talk about why it's not in the first quarter, for that 1 month. In 2016, we'll also going to shift our focus to adjusted EBITDA margin, and we talked about that throughout the call, since it's better represents the true operating profound the company. In 2016, we expect our adjusted EBITDA margin to expand by a solid 75 basis points over last year's 34.8% EBITDA margin. In our modified multiyear business model, we expect adjusted EBITDA margins to be in the upper 30% to 40% range and with annual acceleration of at least at 25 basis points. 
So with that, operator, if you open up for questions for audience, that would be great.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Togut with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Togut with Evercore ISI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, could you give us your outlook for the health of the consumer by major geographies served given some of the trends we're seeing globally? Do you think the consumer will hold up?
componenttext: Rick, could you give us your outlook for the health of the consumer by major geographies served given some of the trends we're seeing globally? Do you think the consumer will hold up?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. Obviously, with the volatility we've seen in the first 5 or 6 weeks of 2016, John and I spent a lot of time with our teams talking about that. I can't for the life of me at this juncture draw a connection between equity market vol
componenttext: That's a great question. Obviously, with the volatility we've seen in the first 5 or 6 weeks of 2016, John and I spent a lot of time with our teams talking about that. I can't for the life of me at this juncture draw a connection between equity market volatility and the health of the consumer in our major markets around the world. As you know, we operate in about 19 different countries and have a great pulse on what's going on with customer, in many cases, on a daily basis across different verticals, different industry sectors. And combine that with some very smart people internally and externally we leverage on the routine basis, economists that help us think through the consumer small business lending trends. And We are not seeing a slowdown in our markets, maybe an exception here are there, but nothing material, David, that gives me concern that the forecast we gave you for guidance is not very attainable. We're just not seeing that strong correlation. So at this juncture, in our major markets around the world, the consumers continue to be healthy. We described it, I think it was a few quarters ago, it's in this sweet spot. We still believe that, and we feel it, we see it in our numbers.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then could you talk about operating leverage for 2016? Most of your margin comments were more mid to long term, which were very helpful, but we saw Workforce Solutions margin up in the fourth quarter, for example, 430 basis points. So how shoul
componenttext: Great. And then could you talk about operating leverage for 2016? Most of your margin comments were more mid to long term, which were very helpful, but we saw Workforce Solutions margin up in the fourth quarter, for example, 430 basis points. So how should we think about sort of margin profile by business segment for this year?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me get the aggregate, and I'll turn to John for details. But I did guide at the very end, that 75 basis point -- we're talking EBITDA now, David, 75 basis points of margin expansion at the corporate level 2016 over 2015. What you're going to see there
componenttext: Let me get the aggregate, and I'll turn to John for details. But I did guide at the very end, that 75 basis point -- we're talking EBITDA now, David, 75 basis points of margin expansion at the corporate level 2016 over 2015. What you're going to see there is continued margin expansion in businesses that have been expanding now for quite some time. That EWS, as you alluded to, and USIS, that trend will continue. number Two, we intentionally made investments in PSOL in 2015, position them for better growth in 2016 and beyond. That's kind of behind us now. We'll to start to see margin expansion in PSOL, levels you saw in 2015. We also invested in 2 main areas in International that are behind us now, one was, as you're very well aware, standing up of the U.K. government contract. it was a year-long, heavy investment. And now, the revenue starts to come because it was virtually no revenue in 2015. Secondly, we talked about kind of regionalization of platforms and people and processes that give us a long term, more cost-efficient International model. Those investments were largely made in 2015. Those have now been anniversary-ed. So you'll start to see International and PSOL margins expanding this year. And obviously, international, I think I alluded to it, will be -- also, their margins will be enhanced with the addition of a very high-margin, successful business in Veda. Behind that, do you have any other trend?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I add is compliance and security expenses continue to -- tremendous growth in 2014, 2015. Still more substantial investments '16, but we do expect over time those are going to moderate in terms of the increases, although still be substantia
componenttext: The only thing I add is compliance and security expenses continue to -- tremendous growth in 2014, 2015. Still more substantial investments '16, but we do expect over time those are going to moderate in terms of the increases, although still be substantial, so we should see some accretion over time related to the moderation of those growth.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make a statement here, and John, correct me if I'm wrong, give you more texture or maybe what you're looking for is, if you look at each individual BU and you look sequentially '16 versus '15, that will BU's EBITDA margin will go up from 2015 and 201
componenttext: I'll make a statement here, and John, correct me if I'm wrong, give you more texture or maybe what you're looking for is, if you look at each individual BU and you look sequentially '16 versus '15, that will BU's EBITDA margin will go up from 2015 and 2016's expectation.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You'll see much -- much larger expansion in USIS and EWS as you've seen over the past several years. You should see some across PSOL and International. And then overall, we will expand because you're just not going to see the degradation from the last 2.
componenttext: You'll see much -- much larger expansion in USIS and EWS as you've seen over the past several years. You should see some across PSOL and International. And then overall, we will expand because you're just not going to see the degradation from the last 2.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Just a final quick question. Rick, you called 280 million Work Number records, which is up pretty substantially. Can you give us a sense of how you're thinking of the growth of this business. Particularly as the Work Number records in
componenttext: That's very helpful. Just a final quick question. Rick, you called 280 million Work Number records, which is up pretty substantially. Can you give us a sense of how you're thinking of the growth of this business. Particularly as the Work Number records increase, are you seeing a much greater hit rate on searches by clients?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I think this business -- all 4 businesses are executing high with great growth opportunities. These guys are in the early stages of a growth opportunity. It's not only going to 280 million to 300 million, that increased hit rate as you mention
componenttext: Yes, David, I think this business -- all 4 businesses are executing high with great growth opportunities. These guys are in the early stages of a growth opportunity. It's not only going to 280 million to 300 million, that increased hit rate as you mentioned. It's also -- we're so early, and I give you some sense of growth rates by verticals, it's amazing. These are all very, very high levels of growth for the verification side. But we are such -- we're so lightly penetrated in many of the high-growth markets. Those years of growth to go on the verification side in the U.S. alone and you add to that, which is the heart of your question, growth from the analytics platform that we built on employers side, and I gave a little comment which I didn't expand upon but will now in my prepared comments, David. The appetite for customers and geographies around the world for us to take the platform of the Work Number to their geographies is stronger now than it's ever been. And when we've got a team working full speed when a couple of many geographies around the world. I'm not going to give a detail on where -- but we saw the same problems that we're solving here, there. So long way of saying, the growth opportunity is significant. It's multiyear, and it's not just U.S.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Rick, just a couple of questions on the trended data. I was just wondering, first, if you want to, probably too sensitive, but if you want to talk about maybe the price freemium or the ASP for trended data versus credit snapshot. Also, I wanted to kn
componenttext: Hey, Rick, just a couple of questions on the trended data. I was just wondering, first, if you want to, probably too sensitive, but if you want to talk about maybe the price freemium or the ASP for trended data versus credit snapshot. Also, I wanted to know what percentage of mortgages currently use or kind of pull the Work Number and where you think that's going to be, sort of what it is currently, what could be the year-end and maybe what you think could be out 2 to 3 years from now?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul, yes. A few comments. I'm not going to go into the level of price increase we get from trended data. But the way to look at this is, the value derived on ROI basis from the mortgage underwriters from looking at data over multiple years versus
componenttext: Thanks, Paul, yes. A few comments. I'm not going to go into the level of price increase we get from trended data. But the way to look at this is, the value derived on ROI basis from the mortgage underwriters from looking at data over multiple years versus at this shot in time, is significant. As a result, they're willing to pay more for trended data. The other point I alluded to in my prepared comments, Paul, was we're going to trend more than just the credit file and take out really unique data assets when no else has and start trending those. Think about the value of trending income data versus taking a snapshot in time so -- and then you take the utility data. So the trending -- I really mean this is the sort of the trending of data especially the unique data assets we have I think creates innovative products and solutions for the years to come. As far as the mortgage market, Workforce Solutions, again, we don't disclose that level of detail. I'll leave it up this -- There's still significant room, and David to be kind of alluded to this. As the database grows, the hit rate goes up. It benefits all verticals, including mortgage. But we still have penetration opportunities not just on hit rate but by account in the mortgage arena in EWS, much like we do in auto, insurance, credit card, government and others for the Work Number.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask a follow-up. I think you left guidance for USIS relatively stable under the new system versus the old. I'm just wondering where the opportunity that trended presents to you, why would you kind of not setup a little bit?
componenttext: If I could just ask a follow-up. I think you left guidance for USIS relatively stable under the new system versus the old. I'm just wondering where the opportunity that trended presents to you, why would you kind of not setup a little bit?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a couple of things. One, short term, as we look at the '16, they're multiyear; two, for '16, there one primary thing going on there. You've got significant headwinds specifically in the first half of the year in USIS and mortgage. And mortgag
componenttext: Yes, there's a couple of things. One, short term, as we look at the '16, they're multiyear; two, for '16, there one primary thing going on there. You've got significant headwinds specifically in the first half of the year in USIS and mortgage. And mortgage is, I think this quarter is first or second quarter what we said before, started to decelerate in the second half. So that's why that model consistent with '16, Paul. In fact, I think you'll be at the lower end of that range in '16 to be very clear with you. And then as far as the multiyear model, I wouldn't ratchet up. I'd rather do that once I have success under our belt and we see just how big this is going to be. So I think it's a little premature. But at the right time, once we see the success and the traction, as you know, it goes live in midyear, they'll be a lot smaller coming out of the year. Model may change at that time, we will.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, nice to hear, as always, a lot of progress. But it sounds like at least with all your initiatives, you guys have taken that up one notch, like a level there. And I think you still have your NPI target of 10%. I know I've asked you this many times be
componenttext: Rick, nice to hear, as always, a lot of progress. But it sounds like at least with all your initiatives, you guys have taken that up one notch, like a level there. And I think you still have your NPI target of 10%. I know I've asked you this many times before. It doesn't sound like you need to motivate people by taking it up, but at what point do you do sort of push yourselves even further to take the target up?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Think of it this way, I did mention the revitalization of NPI that we launched in late '14 and benefited the '15 class, strong class as ever, that will bode well for the next 3 years. So it's moving in the right direction. Two, you always have, as yo
componenttext: Yes. Think of it this way, I did mention the revitalization of NPI that we launched in late '14 and benefited the '15 class, strong class as ever, that will bode well for the next 3 years. So it's moving in the right direction. Two, you always have, as you think about the totally index, big chunks of products roll off every once in a while. So making up big chunks products is harder than it sounds, just to stay at 10%. But really, maybe the most important, you've heard us now talk about 2 years around EGI sort of innovation that is taking large, complicated growth initiatives across multiple geographies and making sure we sustain the kind of growth we need there. And that was I think 20% growth I alluded to in my earnings discussion. If you look at it totally and the contribution from NPI and EGI, its is significant. So I don't feel compelled at this juncture to ratchet up 10% beyond 10%.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the margins, the 25 basis points still, I mean, I guess this clearly sounds like an element that can build into that. Like what are the puts and takes that go through your planning when you still stick with 25 as opposed to mayb
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the margins, the 25 basis points still, I mean, I guess this clearly sounds like an element that can build into that. Like what are the puts and takes that go through your planning when you still stick with 25 as opposed to maybe 50?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think you know what's wrong with right now we're kind of thoughtful and conservative with our guidance. We guided 25 basis points for 2015. What was the operating margin was what?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: 90 basis points. I'm guiding to '16 beyond EBITDA margin, up 75 basis points. So I don't want to starve the business. And you heard John talk about the invested CapEx we had historically, the standardized platforms, bring Cambrian global to facilitate fas
componenttext: 90 basis points. I'm guiding to '16 beyond EBITDA margin, up 75 basis points. So I don't want to starve the business. And you heard John talk about the invested CapEx we had historically, the standardized platforms, bring Cambrian global to facilitate faster, more profitable growth. So I think it's obscure, and I think that combination of really strong organic growth that we talked to you about combined with margin expansion of 25 basis points, if we can get this business to do that year in, year out and get to aspirational goals, we're really to 40% EBITDA margin, I think that's pretty damn good. I hope you agree.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair. And just one last one for me. I know you said it in your guidance obviously implies it as well that you don't expect consumer recession. But just in trying to understand like if equity market operating at a drag and we do get there like
componenttext: Yes, that's fair. And just one last one for me. I know you said it in your guidance obviously implies it as well that you don't expect consumer recession. But just in trying to understand like if equity market operating at a drag and we do get there like  obviously, Equifax today is much different than what it was in 2008, 2009. So any high-level comments and which areas should hold up and which areas would be hit?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think -- thank you, We're not anticipating global recession at this juncture. If it does occur, look, today versus how we're positioned as a company 2007 has been dramatically different. LEAN is an example, and our ability to operate global p
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think -- thank you, We're not anticipating global recession at this juncture. If it does occur, look, today versus how we're positioned as a company 2007 has been dramatically different. LEAN is an example, and our ability to operate global platforms and take global processes and prudent take cost out and act and react to a recessionary environment is far greater today than it was. We're in infancy stage in understanding globalizing the platform, globalizing the process and deploying around the world, so we could act much faster if we had to in the environment. Two, just the overall pipeline of products we have, we're much stronger now. We're in early days of NPI back then. The EGI did not exist then. So just the ability to grind out organic growth that exist then. And lastly, we have built some counter -- I mean, 2 other points, countercyclical products that are bigger now, that did well. I think about unemployment claims as an example in EWS that will do well in a recessionary environment. And we're more global today, especially with the addition of Veda and their platform. If the entire globe is in recession, that doesn't really help you. But if it's isolated a few of the developed markets, in fact, a little bit of growth enterprise may help us as well.

componenttext: Okay. The ranges are there for reason we think they're pretty solid ranges, and you see nuances and noise quarter-to-quarter as you guys know and maybe year-to-year. But over multiple years, those ranges were pretty good. The one, again, the one business that's really clicking on all cylinders and probably has more runway to exceed would be EWS. I mean, their sandbox is just, it's a bigger sandbox in their less mature business and they've got early days of growth. So if there's one that you've got to say maybe has more opportunity to outperform, it's that one.

componenttext: Absolutely. And the other thing I'd say maybe, too, is so, yes, so that's including the mortgage environment I just alluded to down single digits and performance. So obviously, mortgage is stronger and we expect that benefit for EWS as well as USIS. The other business may be short term in 2016. I have to think about maybe more runway than the long-term model would be PSOL because they get some pretty good things going on if you were define their model as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a question on, within International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you faced a really tough comes. So how are you thinking about that? And then s
componenttext: And then a question on, within International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you faced a really tough comes. So how are you thinking about that? And then specifically, can you comment on how much inflation in Argentina is driving the growth of that segment versus volume or unit sales of your offerings?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. and the first part is, I think I alluded to it my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates are growing despite difficult economic environments in Latin America and other part
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. and the first part is, I think I alluded to it my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates are growing despite difficult economic environments in Latin America and other parts of the world, too, is innovation. I mentioned that a majority or 2/3 of the revenue in these large geographies are generating vitality index from New Product Innovation above 10%. So if weren't for that, and they're also been a factor of EGI obviously as well, but if we weren't for those innovative approaches to products in EGI, they will not be performing like they performed.

componenttext: Yes, we've got a small team down in South Australia and New Zealand that represented the debt management analytics platforms. componenttextpreview: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side of the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be I don't see it as probable. B
componenttext: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side of the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be I don't see it as probable. But lifelong is going to be very good add to us, expanding what PSOL does. And also, think about, we've got there's 2 other things that are important. You got now taking that same concept of Credit Karma to other geographies, which we operate, take it Australia, take it to Canada, take it to U.K. And also, you've got Daniel Adams. And one of the beauties leaders around the different businesses is they have a different perspective in the predecessor. And Dan is looking at this business now and saying kind of look at the bridge market differently. These guys are saying, how do I combine some of the assets that we have from EWS where he was for 5.5 years into the global PSOL channel. So it's not just the large indirect resellers that give me hope for long-term growth in PSOL. It's the full levers we talked about plus taking other data assets into PSOL.

componenttext: It's the latter, and it's by far, the latter. I can see the day this business so dramatically than it is today not just in the U.S. but global. componenttext: Good question. It's the latter. Structure does not always facilitate faster growth, in fact, growth will be slower. It's a four-pronged strategy we laid last year that gives us confidence that the growth of PSOL not your model is slightly higher than the past.

componenttextpreview: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, our dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local
componenttext: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, our dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local basis in Australia to think about that. And have walked away with the couple of thoughts, Shlomo. One is for 2016, unless there is an implosion that no one has ever contemplated in China, the diversified their markets, their economy as such that, in fact, the consensus even today is a stronger GDP in Australia than 2015. the second thought I have is, if they're going to have a recession eventually, you can't defy odds. I think there's a second-longest running economy in the history of modern time in the world. The time they had last recession, they're going to have one The third, we are making investment like this we don't make an investment for a quarter, for a year, for 2-year period of time. This is a part of the world that the want to be in. We have great partner down there with Veda. They give us a lens into so many more geographies down there. Austria, New Zealand, so it's a generational but not just a quarter or year bit.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

Good day, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being record
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. 
In the fourth quarter of 2015, we realigned the reporting structure of our direct-to-consumer reseller business, so that it now reports into our Personal Solutions business. Previously, direct-to-consumer resellers were reported within the USIS and International segments based on the country of the customer. We have provided the quarterly history for Personal Solutions, USIS and International, and the new format for each quarter in 2014 and 2015 in the Q&A section of our earnings release. All discussion of the 2015 business unit performance and their outlook for 2016 will be consistent with the new structure. 
Earlier this week, the Veda shareholders voted to accept Equifax's acquisition offer, and we also received subsequent approval from the court. Therefore, the 2016 guidance provided today as well as the updated long-term business model for Equifax, which is included in the Q&A section of our earnings release, both include the impact of the Veda acquisition. However, our guidance for the first quarter of 2016 will not include any impact from Veda, including the incremental cost of the debt. Given the short amount of time, Veda will be part of Equifax in the quarter. 
During this call, as in previous earnings releases, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted operating margin, which will be adjusted for certain items, which affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. In 2016, we will be emphasizing adjusted EBITDA margin in discussing our operational performance. Adjusted EBITDA is defined as operating income adding back depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain one-time items, including the acquisition and integration expenses from Veda, which are also reflected in our calculation of adjusted EPS. These non-GAAP measures are detailed in reconciliation tables posted on our website. 
During this call, we'll be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax in this business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in the filings with the SEC, including our 2014 Form 10-K and the subsequent filings. Please refer to our various investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning.  Execution across all 4 of our business units continues to be very strong, and enabled us to deliver yet another strong quarter in the fourth quarter as well as the
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us this morning.  Execution across all 4 of our business units continues to be very strong, and enabled us to deliver yet another strong quarter in the fourth quarter as well as the full year. For the quarter, fourth quarter 2015 total revenue was $666 million, up 7% on a reported basis and up 10% on a local currency basis from 2014. For the quarter, FX created $18 million of year-over-year headwind for us. The adjusted operating margin was 27.1%, up from 26.5% in the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted EPS was $1.14, up 12% from $1.02 in 2014. And just to refresh your memory, that exceeded the upper end of our guidance range we provided on the last call, which is $1.10 to $1.12. Finally, given our strong performance in 2015, our Board of Directors approved a 14% increase in our quarterly dividend up to now $0.33 a quarter, and this is, as you probably all know, the sixth consecutive double-digit increase in our dividend rate, reflecting the strong performance of the company. I think you'll agree on many dimensions. 2015 was an outstanding year for our 117-year-old business. We exceeded our expectations. We had broad-based contributions from each business unit, industrial verticals, and across the vast majority of our geographies, our team delivered. We're well positioned for a strong 2016. We'll talk about the economic environment in the Q&A, and I'm proud of the team for their continued commitment to innovation, execution, outstanding customer service. 
For the full year, total revenue is $2.7 billion, up 9% on a reported basis, and up 12% on a local currency basis for 2014, and for the year, FX created a $76 million year-over-year headwind. Adjusted operating margin was 27.4%, up 90 basis points from 26.5% in 2014, and well above the targeted 25 basis points or so increase we have guided to in the past. Adjusted EPS was $4.15, up 16% from $3.89 a year ago, and just as a reminder, that performance in 2015 was all organically driven, as we had no acquisitions in he year. As I always do, I'll transition to the business units for some brief commentary before John gives you the details. I'll go through some highlights for the business as well, and then we'll get in to more specifics. 
I want to talk, first of all, Jeff mentioned in his opening comments, we repositioned PSOL in 2015. You know that this team has been working diligently on their new growth model, which I fully support. It's yielding benefits, and John will go through some of those numbers. At the same time, I made the decision that it was important that we have one team, one leader, one business that would manage all strategy, all product positioning in the geographies for our consumer business, regardless of that business going direct to the consumer or if it was going through a reseller. So we've made the decision to realign that under Dan Adams now, who leads our direct-to-consumer businesses globally. I think that just gives us more continuity going forward. 
Now onto the businesses themselves. USIS delivered an impressive 8% revenue growth for the year, while expanding its operating margins 290 basis points. Our insights-driven strategy, which we've talked about, has resonated extremely well with our largest clients in key our client program. Our KCP customers are purchasing multiple Decision 360 products and services, in aggregate, access almost 5 Equifax data products, which is remarkable. Across our top 100 clients, Decision 360 products and services are increasing as well, and there, they're accessing about 3 products on average. So D360 is really making a difference in the marketplace for us. 
In USIS, our product vending management solutions business again delivered a healthy 22% growth for the year, largely driven by their ID authentication and management solution products. Our enterprise vertical strategy has made significant contributions to our total company revenue growth. With experienced industry executives in these verticals, we are better able to leverage our diverse data assets, analytic expertise in IT platforms to deliver premier Decision Solutions. USIS leads many of our enterprise vertical initiatives. To give you an example, a few of those in 2015, our mortgage vertical grew 25% in USIS and 29% for the total company. This again compares favorably to the average Mortgage Bankers Application index, which was up 17% for the year. So that trend of outperforming the mortgage market has continued now for many, many years. Next example is in the auto vertical, which USIS revenue grew 6% and total company grew 9%. This also compares very favorably with the overall market where verticals -- vehicles sales dropped approximately 5%. And more recently, our retail banking vertical grew USIS revenue 17%, and total company revenue by 18%. So you get a sense there that there's enterprise focus taking all over data assets and seasoned leaders in each vertical, delivering those unique assets to our customers, is enabling us to grow significantly, and in many cases, faster than the market itself. 
For years now, we've been working with Fannie Mae on ways to better leverage our information to further improve the underwriting process for mortgage loans. Late in 2015, Fannie Mae made the decision to incorporate credit data into the underwriting process for mortgage lending. We talked about this with you in the past. This initiative will be an important contributor to revenue in both 2016 and 2017. It also represents a significant structural change in the loan underwriting, and it sets the stage for applications outside the mortgage lending to increasingly use trended data and our world-class analytical talent and leverage our Cambrian platform, which we talked about before. We're well positioned to take advantage of the opportunities as they arise. Live testing is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2016, and go live midyear. More importantly, trended data will be available through our core credit online delivery system, making the information available for all solutions that access our credit database. 
Opportunities for USIS in 2016 and beyond are significant. Trended data, ID and fraud, further penetration in our targeted vertical markets are all expected to make important contributions to sustained revenue growth. Our multi-year model for USIS remains, as we've communicated to you before, with top line growth in the 5% to 7% range. And adjusted EBITDA margin, which we'll now talk about going forward, is expected to be in the high 40s, expanding to the low-50s over time. International delivered 12% local currency revenue growth, with strong performance coming from our operations in Europe, in Latin America. Revenue in international's 3 largest verticals: FIs, telcos and small, medium-sized enterprises, grew 13% in 2015. Our decision platforms, analytic solutions and debt management revenue grew 12% in 2015. Europe had an outstanding year, driven by largely by broad-based growth in our U.K. operations. By industry, FI, telco, SMEs all grew high to low double digits for the year. Our offering: Decision Solutions, analytical services and debt management all grew at double-digit rates in 2015. 
TDX has been working, as you know, with U.K. government to manage their past-due consumer debt in fourth quarter 2015, and started receiving accounts at that time, and we started placing those accounts with the collection agencies, analyzing the data in the fourth quarter of last year, and while still early, the performance of the data is slightly ahead of our expectations. This opportunity, along with our ongoing sales efforts, is expected to be a significant strategic initiative, driving growth for international for years to come. Internationals historically delivered some of our strongest performance in New Product Innovation, which has been a significant contributor to incremental revenue growth, further market penetration, and obviously, customer loyalty because we're new build products and solutions that we couldn't build in the past. This broad-based effort towards innovation continues to fuel growth for international. For the year, our 6 geographies in international, represented almost 2/3 of the revenue, delivered an NPI Vitality Index of 10% or greater, which is fabulous. International has some exciting opportunities ahead of it, in addition to Veda, which I'll come back and talk later, which will become a part of the International operation. In 2016, we broadly expanded Cambrian, deploying it across the International geographies, substantially enhancing our ability to deliver analytical insights and drive growth. The continued excellent performance with new products and cost benefits and the regionalization efforts begun last year, as well as the addition to Veda, will expand EBITDA margins in 2016 and beyond. We have moderately raised our expectations for multi-year growth in international now to a range of 7% -- or 8% to 10%, with adjusted EBITDA margins in the low-30s, growing to mid-30s over time.
