Both those measures in top line and EBITDA margin reflect the anticipated close of Veda. 
On to Workforce Solutions. They grew 18% last year. It was an outstanding performance, as was their 510 basis point margin expansion for the year. Core product growth, along with a number of new product initiatives, all contributed to this outstanding performance. Verification Service is strong and broad-based growth of 25% in the year continues to be driven by adding records in the Work Number database. As their coverage of individual employment records increases the value of our service enables us to further penetrate our key target verticals, including mortgage, auto, consumer finance, government and preemployment. In all those verticals, every one of them, was up a very strong double digit for the year, just amazingly strong, balanced growth. At year-end, the Work Number database reached almost 280 million records, as we stated before. We're well on our way to achieving 300 million records in total. The recent emergence of what they call the instant mortgage facilitated through online application process has generated new growth opportunities for automated income and employment verification. We recently signed one of the largest players in the space because of our unique ability to deliver both the credit information, as well as the employment and income verification simultaneously by speeding up the process and enhancing the consumer experience. 
Within EWS, the Employer Services business also had another very strong year in 2015, growing 8%. Much of this growth was driven by our Workforce Analytics offering, which we've talked to you about before. This allows employers to ensure that they are compliant with the Affordable Care Act, as well as providing ACA-required tax information to employees. Workforce Analytics doubled their business in 2015, and is expected to more than double again in 2016. Our Workforce Analytics client base now is approaching over 800 clients. Our pipeline remains very strong. To date, our solutions' largely been focused on our larger enterprise customers in 2016. We're starting to go down market, enabling us to capture relationships with smaller employees, which we can offer cross-sell opportunities with our other employee services offerings. Health care-related revenue, generated by both our income verification and the Affordable Care Act compliance solutions, more than doubled in 2015 versus 2014. And workforce solutions has delivered a stellar performance, not just in 2015, but over the last 9 years. As a business, they were quick to adopt our approach to innovate and to embrace Lean. As a result, they've outperformed on revenue growth and substantially improved their margin. Looking forward, expanding and further penetrating their key markets and verticals, increasing their number of records in the Work Number database and globalizing their footprint will continue to drive revenue growth and margin expansion. Our multi-year expectation for Workforce Solutions has been increased. Now expecting revenue growth of 9% to 11%, with adjusted EBITDA margin in the high-40% range, expanding to low-50s over time. 
Personal Solutions finalized its strategic transformation, and is executing well against its four-pronged strategy. For the year, the newly constructed global Personal Solutions delivered 19% local currency growth -- revenue growth, and is well-positioned for 2016 and beyond. Revenue growth from our direct and indirect consumer activities continues to meet our expectations. Revenue growth in our Personal Solutions business in Canada and U.K. was up a nice 7% in 2015. In the U.S., we continue to perform consistent with our expectations, with increasing ARPU and lowering subscriber churn. Our direct-to-consumer resellers were the most significant contributor to Personal Solutions in 2015. We've talked about that one. That was a part of USIS. Our reseller revenues in both Canada and the U.K. grew solid as well, a solid double digit, in fact, in 2015. And the reseller revenue -- the reseller revenue in U.S. was very strong, primarily driven by the 2-year contract. We're a leading company in the space. Credit Karma will talk to you about that. We're also well-positioned for continued growth in 2016. You may have seen the addition of a new reseller, LifeLock. We signed a multiyear contract a few months back. 
With our broad-based portfolio of data assets, we believe there'll be additional opportunities in 2016 and beyond to provide a broader array of credit, income and fraud services to consumers through our direct and reseller channel. Under the new organizational structure, our multi-year expectations for revenue growth in PSOL is now 5% to 8%, up from the previous target of 4% to 6%. Adjusted EBITDA margin is expected to be in the low-30s, expanding to the mid-30s over time. The outsized growth in 2015 was primarily driven by the start-up of our relationship with Credit Karma, the largest of our DTC, direct-to-consumer resellers. In 2016, we'll anniversary this revenue, so long-term growth rates for PSOL will revert back to more normal levels again of 5% to 8%, with strong growth going forward. 
Now on to some corporate highlights before I turn the mic over to John to give you more details on the financials. Today, we are truly global company with a global set of processes deployed around the world, a global structure, a global culture and a group that's all focused on the core set of global strategic imperatives. Over the years, we've globalized our most critical and fundamental management disciplines to facilitate greater linkage between our strategy and our execution. And through this effort, we have streamlined our product innovation and placement. We've enabled greater leverage of our IT platforms. We've optimized the investment in our talent. We've more effectively moved our talent and products where the greatest opportunities exist. This globalization also enables us to better and more quickly leverage the skills and expertise develop in one market, i.e. in USIS, into another market, International. Again, that's both processes, products and people. Everybody in the company is measured and evaluated in what they contribute to our imperatives, regardless of what part of the organization they reside. 
Having reinvigorated our NPI, New Product Innovation, what we talked to you about last year of our 2.0 and the next phase of innovation, we launched 64 new products last year. Along with the pipeline of 2016 launches, we expect the revenue contributions to deliver strong NPI growth in 2016 and beyond. Our largest and most diverse growth opportunities are executed under our enterprise growth initiatives we call EGI. In 2015, year-over-year revenue growth from these large initiatives was over 20%, and so a 20% growth over 2014. In 2015, we exceeded our expectations for NPI revenues by 6%. Furthermore, I've discussed with you in the past, the class of products we launched in 2015 under our revitalized effort of 2.0 are expected to deliver a record level of revenue, year 3 revenue when compared to prior year launches. It is the healthiest class of products that we've launched since NPI has been in existence here. One of the more exciting new product opportunities revolves around trended data. The effort and investment we're making to fulfill our commitment to Fannie Mae will be leveraged across all of our unique data assets. We firmly believe that the next horizon for information-based solution is trended data, which will underpin more powerful decision and solutions for our customers and significantly improve our competitive position. So to be clear, our focus is trending as many of our unique data assets, which are truly unique only to Equifax or our customers to provide these values, so things like the Work Number and C+ [ph] and others. 
Finally, as with many of our corporate management documents, our global NPI process will be implemented in Veda once we complete the acquisition, and I'll get to Veda in a moment. In 2015, we launched our Big Data platform called Cambrian. Cambrian will enable faster development and delivery analytic insights, including improving the speed at which we develop new products. It will also greatly enhance our Decision 360 capabilities, and provide significant competitive advantage using advanced analytic techniques. Now the corporate impairment for us has been about LEAN. LEAN continues to make incremental contributions to our expense leverage, and exceeded our goal by contributing over 30% greater benefit in 2015 than we had budgeted. And we've leveraged our expertise in LEAN principles to deepen our relationships with some of our largest customers, with projects that help them streamline many of their operational activities, and that obviously provides a competitive differentiator boost in the marketplace. 
Let me close before I give it to John and talk a little bit about Veda. I'm sure many of you are aware that the regulatory approval of Veda received in December enabled them to schedule a shareholder meeting, which Jeff alluded to a little bit ago. They had a shareholder meeting on February 8 and gained approval there, and they've also received a the final court approval this week, and at this point, it's our expectation to close the acquisition at the -- towards the end of February of this year. We're very excited about this opportunity, represent for us the great strategy, strong financial performance, outstanding management team, great market position, and they also give us a significant opportunity in the Asia Pacific geography of further broadening and enhancing our geographic footprint, which is important to us, as we diversify revenue stream. As we move into our first quarter earnings call and beyond, obviously, we'll keep you apprized of the strategic and the financial progress that the team is making with his new asset. 
In closing, our performance in 2015 exemplifies the culture and the strength of our management team and our dedication in the entire organization to innovate and execute for our customers. It's a culture and a process that has taken years to develop, and it underpins the confidence we have in our ability to continue delivering on our commitments and to make our customers and shareholders satisfied with that performance. Our strategic imperatives, as we enter 2016, are in a few areas that are very important to us. We cascade this around the world. One, obviously, is deliver strong and consistent profitable growth and shareholder returns; two, to develop unparalleled analytically insights, leveraging the unique data assets that Equifax has; three is to innovate for market leadership in the key domains and verticals in which we operate; four, is to serve as a trusted steward and advocate for customers and consumers around the world; and obviously, in closing, the last, to invest in talent to drive that strategy and foster a culture of innovation. 
So with that, John, as you always do, please go through the financials.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the fourth quarter. As Jeff mentione
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. Now let me turn to the business units' financial performance for the fourth quarter. As Jeff mentioned at the opening, all BU information is based on the new segments with direct-to-consumer resellers moved to PSOL from USIS and International. Going forward, given the substantial amortization expense related to the Veda acquisition, we will increase our discussion of EBITDA for Equifax and the operating segments. 
U.S. Information Solutions revenue in 4Q '15 was $296 million, up 7% when compared to the fourth quarter of '14. For the full year, revenue of $1.2 billion was up 8%. This compares favorably to our long-term expectation for USIS of 5% to 7% growth as both the mortgage and automotive were very strong in 2015. 
Online Information Solutions revenue was $204 million in 4Q '15, up 6% year-to-year and $842 million for the full year, up 8% when compared with the prior year. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $28 million in 4Q '15, up 10% year-to-year, and $124 million for calendar year '15, up 17%. Total mortgage-related revenue was up 16% and 17% in the quarter for USIS and Equifax, respectively. For calendar year '15, mortgage-related revenue was up 25% and 29% for USIS and Equifax, respectively. This compares favorably to the average Mortgage Bankers Application index, which was up 14% in the fourth quarter and 17% for the calendar year. 
Financial Marketing Services revenue was $64 million in 4Q '15, up 7% year-to-year and up $205 million for calendar year '15, up 5% year-to-year. The operating margin for U.S. Information Solutions was 41.6% in 4Q '15 and 41.9% for calendar year '15, up 50 basis points and 290 basis points, respectively. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 48.5% in 4Q '15 and 49.7% in calendar year '15. We expect to see continued expansion in the USIS EBITDA margins in 2016. 
International's revenue was $143 million in 4Q '15, down 1% on a reported basis, but up 11% on a local currency basis. Revenue was $569 million for calendar year '15, down 1% on a reported basis, but off 12% on a local currency basis. By region, Europe's revenue was $64 million in 4Q '15, up 3% in U.S. dollars and up 10% in local currency. For calendar year '15, Europe revenue was $247 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and up 12% on local currency. Latin America's revenue was $49 million in 4Q '15, up 2% in U.S. dollars and 18% in local currency. Revenue was $200 million for calendar year '15, up 4% in U.S. dollars and 17% in local currency. Latin America showed outstanding local currency growth throughout '15, led by strong growth across Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Canada revenue was $29 million, down 11% in U.S. dollars, but up 5% in local currency. Revenue for calendar year '15 was $122 million in U.S. dollars, down 11% in U.S. dollars but up 3% in local currency. Canada's performance strengthened very nicely in the second half, and has momentum going into 2016. 
International's operating margin was 20.7% in 4Q '15 and 20% in calendar year '15. EBITDA margins were 27.2% in 4Q '15, and 27% in calendar year '15. Both operating and EBITDA margins were down year-to-year in International. However, both showed sequential improvement in the fourth quarter relative to the third. In 2016, we expect to see continued margin improvement, driven by continued strong local currency growth and the benefits of regionalization as well as from the addition of Veda. We will see some margin pressure related to weakened foreign currencies, particularly with the Canadian dollar and the devaluation of the Argentinean peso. 
Workforce Solutions revenue was $144 million in the quarter, up 12% year-to-year, and $578 million in calendar year '15, up 18% year-to-year. This reflects continued very strong growth in Verification Services, up 14% in fourth quarter and 25% year-to-year. Employer services also delivered a very strong performance, up 8% in the fourth quarter and 8% in the calendar year. This was driven by success in their Compliance Center offerings and their solution for employers' compliance that are the requirements of the ACA. The Workforce Solutions operating margin was 36.8% in 4Q '15 and 37.9% in calendar year '15, up 430 and 510 basis points, respectively. Workforce Solutions EBITDA margins were 44.3% in the fourth quarter, and 45.1% in the calendar year. We expect continued strong expansion of Workforce Solutions EBITDA margins in 2016. 
Global Personal Solutions revenue was $84 million in 4Q '15, up 12% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis. Revenue in calendar year '15 was $346 million, up 18% on a reported basis and up 19% on a local currency basis. PSOL's business has 2 main areas: credit and identity monitoring services sold through direct and indirect channels that protect and monitor consumers' ID and enable consumers to gain better access to credit, and credit another data sales sold through our DTC reseller partners. Credit and identity monitoring services sold through the indirect channel represent those circumstances where Equifax provides white label online credit and identity services through partners. In 2015, ongoing revenue from credit and identity monitoring services grew at the high end of the 4% to 6% guidance range we have previously provided for the PSOL segment prior to the addition of DTC sellers. DTC reseller's revenue represent sales of credit and other data to resellers. In these cases, Equifax provides data and analytics, but not the web properties with which the customer directly interacts. Examples of this business are relationships with Credit Karma and LifeLock. DTC reseller revenue showed substantial growth in 2015, driven primarily by our relationship with Credit Karma, which began in 4Q '14. Our DTC reseller revenue should continue to grow faster than our direct-to-consumer sales, but as Rick mentioned, not at the very high rate you saw in 2015. 
Looking forward, as previously mentioned, we expect this overall segment to grow 5% to 8%. Operating margin was 27% in 4Q '15 and 27.5% for calendar year '15, consistent with our expectations. EBITDA margins were 29.7% in 4Q '15 and 30.2% in calendar year '15. PSOL revenue and operating margin in 4Q '14 were very strong, reflecting a large reach deal won in 4Q '14. 4Q '15 operating margin of 27% was consistent with our expectations and our guidance, and reflects the impact of our decision to invest more in marketing in 2015, as well as the addition of DTC reseller business to PSOL. 
In the fourth quarter, general corporate expense was $51 million, excluding $3.7 million for onetime expenses associated with the Veda acquisition. General corporate expense was up slightly from 3Q, consistent with our guidance. For the first quarter of 2016, we expect general corporate expense, excluding Veda-related acquisition and integration expenses, to be in the range of $55 million to $60 million and run at a slightly lower rate throughout the remaining quarters of the year. The adjusted operating margin at 27.1% in 4Q '15 and 27.4% in calendar year '15 were up 60 and 90 basis points year-to-year, respectively. Adjusted EBITDA margins were 34.4% in 4Q '15 and 34.8% in calendar year '15. We expect to see improvements in our adjusted EBITDA margin in 2016, expanding by about 75 basis points. Our GAAP effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 32.6%, equal to our expectation and in our guidance. For the full year, our non-GAAP effective tax rate, after adjusting for non-GAAP items, the Missouri state tax law change in the second quarter and TDX escrow adjustment in third quarter, was 33.7% consistent with our comments during our third quarter release. Looking forward into 2016, our expectation is for a GAAP effective tax rate of about 33%. 
Operating cash flow was $205 million in 4Q '15 and $742 million in calendar year '15. Both were very strong, reflecting strong earnings and working capital performance. Free cash flow, equal to operating cash flow less capital expenditures, was very strong in 2015 at $596 million, up 12% from 2014. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $53 million and for calendar year '15 were $146 million. Consistent with our comments throughout the year, the increase in capital spending versus 2014 reflects the acceleration of our investment in New Product Innovation, deployment of global platforms, including Cambrian and other analytics, InterConnect, fraud, and our new PSOL infrastructure. As we look forward to 2016, we expect capital spending, including Veda, to be in the range of 5% to 6% of revenue. This is consistent with 2015 and reflects a continuation of our current investments as well as some additional spending in the near term as we integrate Veda. This is slightly higher than our expected long-term rate of capital spending of about 5% of revenue due to the Veda integration.
As Rick indicated, we have received Veda shareholder approval and approval from the Australian courts to complete the purchase of Veda. We expect the acquisition to close on about February 25. Total purchase price, including assumed debt and fees, is approximately USD 1.9 billion. At the close of the Veda transaction, we will have debt outstanding of just under $3.1 billion, and debt to EBITDA on a trailing basis of just under 3x. As indicated previously, we expect to maintain our current credit ratings. In 2016, we will focus on using our very strong cash flow for debt reduction and returning our leverage to a level consistent with our current credit rating. Therefore, we do not intend to repurchase shares in 2016. We will, however, continue with acquisitions beyond Veda in 2016 with a goal of delivering on our long-term model of an additional 1 to 2 points of revenue growth. Assuming acquisitions consistent with our targets in 2016 and 2017, we would expect to repurchase shares in 2017. 
As we discussed last quarter, we will exclude Veda transactions and other acquisition expenses and integration expenses incurred in the first year after the Veda acquisition through 1Q '17, and calculating adjusted EPS and adjusted operating margin and EBITDA margin. We will provide information regarding transaction and acquisition expenses incurred with the acquisition, as well as integration expenses we expect to incur related to the Veda acquisition after the transaction closes at our 1Q '16 earnings release conference call. Also, Jeff mentioned at the beginning of the call, given the relatively short time we will own Veda in the quarter, our 1Q '16 guidance does not include the impact of Veda nor the incremental debt cost, including interest expense related to the acquisition. We will provide you details on the impact of Veda on 1Q '16 during our 1Q '16 earnings call in April. 
The 2016 full year guidance Rick will provide includes Veda. For 2016, we have assumed Veda will be a part of Equifax for 10 months. Veda revenue for 10 months is assumed to be USD 220 million to USD 230 million. This include an estimate of the impact to revenue of U.S. GAAP, which will be updated as we close 1Q '16. The benefit to adjusted EPS from Veda net of acquisition financing cost is about $0.10 to $0.15 per share. As a reminder, adjusted EPS excludes acquisition amortization expense. For modeling purposes, you can assume an average cost of our Veda acquisition debt during 2016 of about 2.5%. Veda's seasonality of revenues is similar to Equifax, with 2Q revenue typically the highest from a seasonality perspective, 1Q generally the lowest revenue, and 3Q and 4Q somewhat similar in terms of revenue. The spread between 2Q and 1Q revenue has recently been in the range of 7% to 10%. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Some summary comments before we go to the Q&A. As I've mentioned before to all of you and many of you noted in our conversations and in the write ups, the level of execution and the momentum this team has generated in 2015 is the best in my
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Some summary comments before we go to the Q&A. As I've mentioned before to all of you and many of you noted in our conversations and in the write ups, the level of execution and the momentum this team has generated in 2015 is the best in my 10 years here. I think it's truly remarkable what they've done. We are well positioned for growth opportunities that lie ahead and our ability to take care -- to take on any of the challenges that may confront us. In the coming years, the incremental revenue that would be contributing from class of new products that we just launched, we expect it to exceed our historical average. That's the wind in our back. Our enterprise growth initiatives, including the expanded insights, driven by Cambrian, healthcare, trended data and auto, will not only enhance our competitive position but also deliver growth opportunities for years to come. All of these efforts are expected, in our opinion, to offset the anticipated slowdown of U.S. mortgage market, which, as you know, started to decelerate over the course of 2015. While it's impossible to predict where the mortgage market is going to go, especially when I look this morning at 10-year Treasury under 1.6, forecast range from down 20% to up mid-single digits. Our forecast that we're giving you for 2016 is anticipating that the mortgage market will be down single digits in 2016. And obviously, our expectation of the team in both Workforce Solutions and USIS, as they have done for many, many years, outperforms that quite significantly. Obviously, if rates continue to stay low as they are, there may be some market upside to what occurs in the mortgage market, and we'll all know obviously when we head deeper into the year. 
2016 is yet again expected to be another strong year performance for the company. For the year, we expect revenue, including the impact of Veda, to be between $3 billion and $3.1 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of the '15% to 19%. That's going to be partially offset by 2 to 3 points of FX headwind. This is consistent with our comments in October that the organic constant currency growth would be at the high end of our long-term range of 6% to 8%. I got to say it again, that's at the high end of our range coming off at constant currency growth last year of 12%. So it's, I think, quite remarkable. As John mentioned, we also expect to add another 1 to 2 points of tuck-in acquisitions throughout the year. These additional acquisitions are obviously beyond Veda, which as you said, is not included in our 2000 -- I'm sorry, in the first quarter of 2016 outlook. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $4.95 and $5.05, which is up 10% to 12% per year, excluding approximately $0.13 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 13% to 15%. For the first quarter, we expect organic revenue to be between $685 million and $695 million, reflecting constant currency organic revenue growth of 8% to 10%. That will be partially offset by about 3 points of FX headwind in the quarter. First quarter adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.14 and $1.16, which is up 7% to 8%, excluding $0.04 per share of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 10% to 12% for the first quarter. Again, we expect to close Veda in the first quarter, but we'll not include that in the estimate. Maybe during the Q&A, we'll talk about why it's not in the first quarter for that 1 month. In 2016, we'll also going to shift our focus to adjusted EBITDA margin. We'll just talk about that throughout the call since it better represents the true operating performance of the company. 2016, we expect our adjusted EBITDA margin to expand by a solid 75 basis points over last year's 34.8% EBITDA margin. In our modified multiyear business model, we expect adjusted EBITDA margins to be in the upper 30% to 40% range, with annual acceleration of at least 25 basis points. 
So with that, operator, if you'd open up for questions for audience, that would be great.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Togut with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from David Togut with Evercore ISI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, could you give us your outlook for the health of the consumer by major geographies served? Given some of the trends we're seeing globally, do you think that consumer will hold up?
componenttext: Rick, could you give us your outlook for the health of the consumer by major geographies served? Given some of the trends we're seeing globally, do you think that consumer will hold up?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave, that's a great question. Obviously, with the volatility we've seen in the first 5 or 6 weeks of 2016, John and I spent a lot of time with our teams talking about that. I can't, for the life of me, at this juncture, draw a connection between equ
componenttext: Yes, Dave, that's a great question. Obviously, with the volatility we've seen in the first 5 or 6 weeks of 2016, John and I spent a lot of time with our teams talking about that. I can't, for the life of me, at this juncture, draw a connection between equity market volatility and the health of the consumer in our major markets around the world. As you know, we operate in about 19 different countries and have a great pulse on what's going on with the customer; in many cases, on a daily basis across different verticals, different industry sectors and combine that with some very smart people internally and externally we leverage on a routine basis, economists, that help us think through consumer small business lending trends. And we are not seeing a slowdown in our markets. Maybe an exception here or there, but nothing material, David, that gives me concern that the forecast we just gave you for guidance is not very attainable. We're just not seeing that strong correlation. So at this juncture, in our major markets around the world, the consumers continue to be healthy. We described it, I think it was a few quarters ago, was in this sweet spot. We still believe that. And we feel it, and we see it in our numbers.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then could you talk about operating leverage for 2016? Most of your margin comments were more mid- to long term, which were very helpful, but we saw Workforce Solutions margin up in the fourth quarter, for example, 430 basis points. So how shou
componenttext: Great. And then could you talk about operating leverage for 2016? Most of your margin comments were more mid- to long term, which were very helpful, but we saw Workforce Solutions margin up in the fourth quarter, for example, 430 basis points. So how should we think about sort of margin profile by business segment for this year?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll make it the aggregate, and I think sort of maybe John can do the details. But I did guide at the very end about 75 basis -- we're talking EBITDA now, David, 75 basis points of margin expansion at the corporate level 2016 over 2015. What you're g
componenttext: Yes, I'll make it the aggregate, and I think sort of maybe John can do the details. But I did guide at the very end about 75 basis -- we're talking EBITDA now, David, 75 basis points of margin expansion at the corporate level 2016 over 2015. What you're going to see there is continued margin expansion in businesses that have been expanding now for quite some time. That's EWS, as you alluded to, and USIS. That trend will continue. Number two, we intentionally made investments in PSOL in 2015 to position them for better growth in 2016 and beyond. That's kind of behind us now. So you'll start to see margin expansion in PSOL, from the levels you saw in 2015. We also invested in 2 main areas in International that are behind us now. One was, as you're very well aware, standing up of the U.K. government contract, which was a year-long, heavy investment. And now, the revenue starts to come because it was virtually no revenue in 2015. Secondly, we talked about kind of regionalization of platforms and people and processes that give us a long term, more cost-efficient International model. Those investments were largely made in 2015. Those have now been anniversaried. So you'll start to see International and PSOL margins expanding this year. And obviously, International, I think I alluded to it, will be -- also, their margins will be enhanced with the addition of a very high-margin, successful business in Veda. Beyond that, do you have any other trends [indiscernible]?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I'd add is compliance and security expenses continue to -- tremendous growth in 2014, 2015. Still more substantial investments '16, but we do expect over time those are going to moderate in terms of the increases, although still be sub
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I'd add is compliance and security expenses continue to -- tremendous growth in 2014, 2015. Still more substantial investments '16, but we do expect over time those are going to moderate in terms of the increases, although still be substantial. So we should see some accretion over time related to the moderation of those growths.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make a statement here, John, correct me if I'm wrong, David, to give you little more texture maybe what you're looking for is, if you look at each individual BU and you look sequentially '16 versus '15, every BU's EBITDA margin will go up from 2015 a
componenttext: I'll make a statement here, John, correct me if I'm wrong, David, to give you little more texture maybe what you're looking for is, if you look at each individual BU and you look sequentially '16 versus '15, every BU's EBITDA margin will go up from 2015 and 2016's expectation.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You'll see much better -- you see much larger expansion in the USIS and EWS as you've seen over the past several years. You should see some across PSOL and International. And then overall, we will expand because you're just not going to see the degradatio
componenttext: You'll see much better -- you see much larger expansion in the USIS and EWS as you've seen over the past several years. You should see some across PSOL and International. And then overall, we will expand because you're just not going to see the degradation from the last 2.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. Just a final quick question. Rick, you called out 280 million Work Number records, which is up pretty substantially. Can you give us a sense of how you're thinking of the growth of this business? Particularly as the Work Number record
componenttext: That's very helpful. Just a final quick question. Rick, you called out 280 million Work Number records, which is up pretty substantially. Can you give us a sense of how you're thinking of the growth of this business? Particularly as the Work Number records increase, are you seeing a much greater hit rate on searches by clients?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I think this business -- all 4 businesses are executing high, great growth opportunities. These guys are in early stages of their growth opportunity. It's not only going from 280 million to 300 million that does increase the hit rate as you me
componenttext: Yes, David, I think this business -- all 4 businesses are executing high, great growth opportunities. These guys are in early stages of their growth opportunity. It's not only going from 280 million to 300 million that does increase the hit rate as you mentioned. It's also -- we're so early, and I gave you some sense for the growth rates by verticals, and it's amazing. These are very, very high double-digit growth rates in these verification side. But we are such -- we're so lightly penetrated in many of the high-growth markets. There's years of growth to go on the verification side in the U.S. alone. And you add to that, which is not the heart of your question, growth from the analytics platform that we've built on the employer side. And I gave a little comment, which I didn't expand upon, but I will now, in my prepared comments, David. The appetite for customers and geographies around the world for us to take this platform of the Work Number to their geographies is stronger now than it's ever been. And we have got a team working full speed on a couple of many geographies around the world. And so I'm not going to get in a lot of detail on where. But they saw the same problems that we're solving here there. So long way of saying, the growth opportunity is significant, it's multiyear, and it's not just the U.S.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we will take our next question from Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we will take our next question from Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Rick. Just a couple of questions on the trended data. I was just wondering, first, if you want to -- probably too sensitive, but if you want to talk about maybe the price premium or the ASP for trended data versus credit snapshot. Also wanted to know
componenttext: Hey, Rick. Just a couple of questions on the trended data. I was just wondering, first, if you want to -- probably too sensitive, but if you want to talk about maybe the price premium or the ASP for trended data versus credit snapshot. Also wanted to know what percentage of mortgages currently use or kind of pull the Work Number? And where you think that's going to be sort of -- what it is currently? What could be at year-end? And maybe what you think could be out 2 to 3 years from now?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Yes, your comments were accurate. I'm not going to go into the level of price increase we get from trended data. But the way to look at it is, the value derived on ROI basis from the mortgage underwriters from looking at data over multiple y
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. Yes, your comments were accurate. I'm not going to go into the level of price increase we get from trended data. But the way to look at it is, the value derived on ROI basis from the mortgage underwriters from looking at data over multiple years versus a shot in time is significant. As a result, they're willing to pay more for trended data. The other point I alluded to in the -- in my prepared comments, Paul, was we're going to trend more than just the credit file and take our really unique data assets that no else has and sort of trending those. Think about the value of trending income data versus taking a snapshot in time so -- and then you take the utility data. So the trending -- I really mean essentially the trending of data, especially the unique data assets we have, I think, creates innovative products and solutions for years to come. As far as the mortgage market -- on Workforce Solutions, again, we don't disclose that level of detail. I'd leave it at this though. There's still significant room. And David Togut kind of alluded to this. As the database grows, the hit rate goes up. It benefits all verticals, including mortgage. But we still have penetration opportunities, not just on hit rate but by account in the mortgage arena in EWS, much like we do in auto, insurance, credit card, government and others for the Work Number.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask a follow-up, I think you left guidance for USIS relatively stable under the new system versus the old. I'm just wondering with the opportunity that trended presents to you, why wouldn't you have kind of notched that up a little bit?
componenttext: If I could just ask a follow-up, I think you left guidance for USIS relatively stable under the new system versus the old. I'm just wondering with the opportunity that trended presents to you, why wouldn't you have kind of notched that up a little bit?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a couple of things. One, short term, as we look at '16, and I will do the multiyear too, for '16, there -- one primary thing going on there. You've got significant headwinds, specifically in the first half of the year in USIS and mortgage. Mo
componenttext: Yes, there's a couple of things. One, short term, as we look at '16, and I will do the multiyear too, for '16, there -- one primary thing going on there. You've got significant headwinds, specifically in the first half of the year in USIS and mortgage. Mortgage is, I think, these quarters were the first or second quarter, and as we said before, started to decelerate in the second half. So that's why that model is consistent for '16, Paul. In fact, I think it'll be at the lower end of that range in '16, to be very clear with you. And then as far as the multiyear model, I wouldn't have ratchet that up. I'd rather do that once I have success under our belt, and we see just how big this is going to be. So I think it's a little premature. But it's the right time once we see the success and the traction. As you know, it goes live in midyear and will be a lot smarter coming the end of the year. And as the model just wise [ph] being changed at that time, we will.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And congratulations on the Social Security Administration contract. If I could just really quickly ask for the my online Social Security accounts, how many times a year do you think you'll verify each of those 22 million accounts on average?
componenttext: Great. And congratulations on the Social Security Administration contract. If I could just really quickly ask for the my online Social Security accounts, how many times a year do you think you'll verify each of those 22 million accounts on average?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, great question. I have no idea. Good question though, Paul.
componenttext: Paul, great question. I have no idea. Good question though, Paul.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Manav Patnaik with Barclays.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Manav Patnaik with Barclays.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, nice to hear, as always, lot of progress. But it sounds like at least with all your initiatives, you guys have taken that up one notch, like a level there. And I think you still have your NPI target of 10%. I know I've asked you this many times befo
componenttext: Rick, nice to hear, as always, lot of progress. But it sounds like at least with all your initiatives, you guys have taken that up one notch, like a level there. And I think you still have your NPI target of 10%. I know I've asked you this many times before. It doesn't sound like you need to motivate people by taking it up. But at what point do you do sort of push yourselves even further to take that target up?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, think of it this way. I did mention the revitalization of NPI that we launched in late '14 benefited the '15 class, one of our strongest classes ever, and that will bode well for the next 3 years. So it's moving in the right direction. Two, you alway
componenttext: Yes, think of it this way. I did mention the revitalization of NPI that we launched in late '14 benefited the '15 class, one of our strongest classes ever, and that will bode well for the next 3 years. So it's moving in the right direction. Two, you always have, as you think about the Vitality Index, Manav, you've got big chunks of products that roll off every once in a while. So making up big chunks of products is harder than it sounds just to stay at 10%. But three, maybe most important, you've heard us now talk for about 2 years around EGI. That's another innovation that is taking large, complicated growth initiatives across multiple geographies and making sure we sustain the kind of growth we need there. And that was, I think, 20% growth I alluded to in my [indiscernible]. Look at it totally, and the contribution from NPI and EGI, it is significant. So I don't feel compelled at this juncture to ratchet up 10%, beyond 10%.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the margins, the 25 basis points still, I mean, I guess, this clearly sounds like an element of conservatism to that. Like what are the puts and takes that go through your planning when you still stick with 25 as opposed to mayb
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the margins, the 25 basis points still, I mean, I guess, this clearly sounds like an element of conservatism to that. Like what are the puts and takes that go through your planning when you still stick with 25 as opposed to maybe 50?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you know what's wrong up by now. We tend to be thoughtful and maybe little conservative on our guidance. We guided 25 basis points for 2015. When was it -- the operating margin was up, what?
componenttext: Well, I think you know what's wrong up by now. We tend to be thoughtful and maybe little conservative on our guidance. We guided 25 basis points for 2015. When was it -- the operating margin was up, what?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Over 90.
componenttext: Over 90.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: 90 basis points. I'm guiding '16 to be, on EBITDA margin, up 75 basis points. So I don't want to starve the business. And you heard John talk about continued investment at the CapEx level. It's higher that we have historically, the standardized platforms,
componenttext: 90 basis points. I'm guiding '16 to be, on EBITDA margin, up 75 basis points. So I don't want to starve the business. And you heard John talk about continued investment at the CapEx level. It's higher that we have historically, the standardized platforms, to bring Cambrian global to facilitate faster, more profitable growth. So, Manav, I think it's a Rubik's Cube, and I think that combination of really strong organic growth that we talked to you about combined with margin expansion of 25 basis points. If we can get this business to do that year in, year out and get to our aspirational goals that we alluded to of 40% EBITDA margin, I think that's pretty damn good. I hope you agree.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair. And then just one last one from me. I mean, I know you said it, and your guidance, obviously, implies it as well. Well, you don't expect a consumer recession. But just in trying to understand, like if equity markets are predicting it rig
componenttext: Yes, that's fair. And then just one last one from me. I mean, I know you said it, and your guidance, obviously, implies it as well. Well, you don't expect a consumer recession. But just in trying to understand, like if equity markets are predicting it right, and we do get there like -- obviously, Equifax today is much different than what it was in 2008, 2009. So any high-level comments and which areas should hold up and which areas would be hit?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think -- thank you, Manav. We're not anticipating a global recession at this juncture. If it does occur, I look today versus the way how we're positioned as a company 2007 has been dramatically different, Lean as an example. And our ability t
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think -- thank you, Manav. We're not anticipating a global recession at this juncture. If it does occur, I look today versus the way how we're positioned as a company 2007 has been dramatically different, Lean as an example. And our ability to operate global platforms and take global processes and pull them to take cost out and act and react to recessionary environment is far greater today than it was. And we are in our infancy stage of understanding globalizing the platform, globalizing the process and deploying Lean around the world. So we could react much faster, if we had to, in that environment. Two, just the overall pipeline of products we have is much stronger now. We're in the early days of NPI back then. EGI did not exist then. So just the ability to grind out organic growth that exist. And lastly, we have built some counter -- I mean 2 other points, countercyclical products that are bigger now, would do well. Think about unemployment claims as an example in EWS. That would do well in a recessionary environment. And we're more global today, especially with the addition of Veda and their platform. If the entire globe hits with recession, that doesn't really help you. But if it's isolated to a few of the developed markets, in fact a little better global enterprise may help us as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, I'd like to ask you about the Veda revenue and EPS assumptions that you highlighted for the 10 months included in Equifax. On kind of a like-for-like basis, what type of revenue growth does that assume? And when you talk about the EPS accretion, are
componenttext: Rick, I'd like to ask you about the Veda revenue and EPS assumptions that you highlighted for the 10 months included in Equifax. On kind of a like-for-like basis, what type of revenue growth does that assume? And when you talk about the EPS accretion, are you counting on cost synergies?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take a crack at it, John. You jump in. Think about Veda as a business that kind of fits right into our organic growth model, which is 6% to 8% and maybe at the upper end of the -- upper part of that range versus the lower part of that range. So
componenttext: Yes, I'll take a crack at it, John. You jump in. Think about Veda as a business that kind of fits right into our organic growth model, which is 6% to 8% and maybe at the upper end of the -- upper part of that range versus the lower part of that range. So nicely in our organic growth target, not just for '16 but year in, year out. And much like the rest of the world, Andrew, there's the opportunity for tuck-in acquisitions in their geographies that are exciting to us in these early days. On the -- what was the second question, was it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cost synergies.
componenttext: Cost synergies.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does not include synergies. So we didn't assume any meaningful synergies in 2016.
componenttext: It does not include synergies. So we didn't assume any meaningful synergies in 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, on the cost side. There really aren't many cost synergies. In fact, it'd be just the opposite. We're adding cost to Veda to bring things like Cambrian, InterConnect and other things to help them link data and grow faster.
componenttext: Yes, I guess, on the cost side. There really aren't many cost synergies. In fact, it'd be just the opposite. We're adding cost to Veda to bring things like Cambrian, InterConnect and other things to help them link data and grow faster.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, if you look at the last reported revenue of Veda and then take a look at what we've just indicated, growth rate for 18 months would have to be high single to near 10%.
componenttext: Andrew, if you look at the last reported revenue of Veda and then take a look at what we've just indicated, growth rate for 18 months would have to be high single to near 10%.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one more on that. Rick, are you accounting a lot on comprehensive data being a meaningful impact to the Australian market over the next couple of years when thinking about the Veda acquisition?
componenttext: Okay. And just one more on that. Rick, are you accounting a lot on comprehensive data being a meaningful impact to the Australian market over the next couple of years when thinking about the Veda acquisition?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The model did not contemplate that, Andrew. But I'd tell you what, I walked away on my last visit with a team down there. More impressed with the rate at which contributors have been contributing data positively, I should say. So it's not right now in our
componenttext: The model did not contemplate that, Andrew. But I'd tell you what, I walked away on my last visit with a team down there. More impressed with the rate at which contributors have been contributing data positively, I should say. So it's not right now in our guidance. It's not in the model we use that suggest by buying the company. But I'm more hopeful and impressed now than I was in early days that it will be a meaningful change down the road.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question with Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We will take our next question with Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You already commented on USIS maybe being towards the lower end of the long-term targets. But how about the other businesses? Are any of them in the seed position to be above the high end this year? Or would we think those targets by segment are good plac
componenttext: You already commented on USIS maybe being towards the lower end of the long-term targets. But how about the other businesses? Are any of them in the seed position to be above the high end this year? Or would we think those targets by segment are good places to be for 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, the ranges are there for a reason. We think they're pretty solid ranges. And you're going to see nuances and noise quarter-to-quarter, as you guys know, and maybe even year-to-year. But over multiple years, those ranges feel pretty good. The one --
componenttext: Look, the ranges are there for a reason. We think they're pretty solid ranges. And you're going to see nuances and noise quarter-to-quarter, as you guys know, and maybe even year-to-year. But over multiple years, those ranges feel pretty good. The one -- again, the one business that's really clicking on all cylinders and probably has more runway to exceed would be EWS. I mean, their sandbox is just -- it's a bigger sandbox, and they're less mature business, and they've got early days of growth. So if there's one that you've got to say it maybe has more opportunity to outperform, it's that one.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that include your commentary about mortgage being much tougher comps still able to do very well there?
componenttext: And would that include your commentary about mortgage being much tougher comps still able to do very well there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And the other thing I'd say, maybe two, is -- so, yes. So that's including the mortgage environment I just alluded to down single digits and walked out performance. So obviously, if mortgage is stronger, then we expect that benefits EWS as wel
componenttext: Absolutely. And the other thing I'd say, maybe two, is -- so, yes. So that's including the mortgage environment I just alluded to down single digits and walked out performance. So obviously, if mortgage is stronger, then we expect that benefits EWS as well as USIS. The other business may be short term in 2016 I think about having maybe more runway than the long-term model would be PSOL because they get some pretty good things going as we define their model as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a question on within the International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you face a really tough comp. So how are you thinking about that? And then
componenttext: And then a question on within the International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you face a really tough comp. So how are you thinking about that? And then specifically, can you comment on how much inflation in Argentina is driving the growth of that segment versus volume or unit sales of your offerings?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. But the first part is, and I think I alluded to it in my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates they're growing in spite of difficult economic environments in Latin America
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. But the first part is, and I think I alluded to it in my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates they're growing in spite of difficult economic environments in Latin America and other parts of the world, too, is innovation. I mentioned that a majority of their -- 2/3 of their revenue in these large geographies aren't generating Vitality Index from new product Innovation above 10%. So one for that. And they're also a benefactor of EGI, obviously, as well. But once those innovative approaches to products in EGI, they would not be performing like they're performing.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one last cleanup one. Do you have -- I know it's early, but do you have a sense for what we expect the amortization and depreciation from Veda to be?
componenttext: Great. And then just one last cleanup one. Do you have -- I know it's early, but do you have a sense for what we expect the amortization and depreciation from Veda to be?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey. It's early. And obviously, as the transaction closes, these numbers will be updated. But acquisition amortization, right now, we're assuming it somewhere in the neighborhood of $95 million.
componenttext: Hey. It's early. And obviously, as the transaction closes, these numbers will be updated. But acquisition amortization, right now, we're assuming it somewhere in the neighborhood of $95 million.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jeff Meuler with Baird.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jeff Meuler with Baird.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Nick Nikitas on for Jeff. Just switching back to Veda and maybe talking more about some revenue potential synergies, you mentioned TDX has seen some positive signs in Australia. Do you guys maybe see that as an opportunity to leverage Veda's prese
componenttext: This is Nick Nikitas on for Jeff. Just switching back to Veda and maybe talking more about some revenue potential synergies, you mentioned TDX has seen some positive signs in Australia. Do you guys maybe see that as an opportunity to leverage Veda's presence throughout the region? Or is there any other potential avenues that you see to drive additional growth into the future?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got a small team domiciled in Australia and New Zealand that represented the debt management analytics platforms. So yes, having access to a much larger sales organization with deeper, longer-standing relationships will help our debt management
componenttext: Yes, we've got a small team domiciled in Australia and New Zealand that represented the debt management analytics platforms. So yes, having access to a much larger sales organization with deeper, longer-standing relationships will help our debt management growth. But beyond that, one, we're getting a business that's got great organic growth opportunities. I alluded the fact there's inorganic opportunities. And then the others are bringing things like the Work Number to Australia, bringing Cambrian to Australia, bringing InterConnect to Australia, bringing our global fraud platform to Australia. It's hard -- you can't underestimate the relationship these guys have in Australia and New Zealand, and the market presence they have with all major verticals is significant. And they build out, much like Equifax has in Australia and New Zealand a very wide array of unique data assets. And if we can bring our know-how to bear there to build products, that is a great growth driver. And then as someone, I think it was Andrew, asked a second ago, eventually, one comprehensive as you referred to or positive data as many referred to it, when that becomes mainstream, guess what, we know how to manage positive data and build production on positive data really well. And that, in years to come, is another growth driver for us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just within the U.K., was TDX a sizable contribution for the 4Q? Or is that still thinking about '16 more of a strong contributor there for looking at growth rates similar kind of low double-digit European growth rate as possible?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just within the U.K., was TDX a sizable contribution for the 4Q? Or is that still thinking about '16 more of a strong contributor there for looking at growth rates similar kind of low double-digit European growth rate as possible?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business. TDX continued to provide growth, but we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business as well. Just to make sure I was -- everyone understands my answer, the $95 million for Veda acquisi
componenttext: Yes, we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business. TDX continued to provide growth, but we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business as well. Just to make sure I was -- everyone understands my answer, the $95 million for Veda acquisition amortization is an annualized number. It's not the '16 number. It's an annualized number.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, it's interesting the way the PSOL business has evolved generally in direct to consumer in particular. And obviously, Credit Karma was a big win. Can you frame up, perhaps, the additional opportunities in DTC? Is Credit Karma, probably, the biggest o
componenttext: Rick, it's interesting the way the PSOL business has evolved generally in direct to consumer in particular. And obviously, Credit Karma was a big win. Can you frame up, perhaps, the additional opportunities in DTC? Is Credit Karma, probably, the biggest opportunity -- biggest single opportunity you see out there recognizing that the markets changing pretty quickly and you have some new entrants? Or are there other large, potential targets, too, that could be call outs the way Credit Karma was?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side or the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be. I don't see it as probable.
componenttext: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side or the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be. I don't see it as probable. But lifelong, it's going to be very good add to us, expanding what PSOL does. And also, think about -- what you got is 2 other things that are important. You've got -- now taking that same concept of Credit Karma to other geographies, which we operate, taking it to Australia, taking it to Canada, taking it to U.K. And also you've got Dann Adams. And one of the beauties, Andrew, of moving leaders around the different businesses is they have a different perspective than the predecessor. And Dann is looking at this business now saying kind of look at the bridge market differently. He's looking and saying, how do I combine some of the assets that we have from EWS, where he was for 5.5 years, into the global PSOL channel. So it's not just the large indirect resellers that give me hope for the long-term growth in PSOL, it's the 4 levers we talked about plus taking other data assets into PSOL.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'll ask you, I guess, the same question around Workforce Solutions. It seems like every year there's another wrinkle, another innovation, another customer. I mean, has this been an exceptional period, given developments like ACA, where you'd sa
componenttext: Okay. And I'll ask you, I guess, the same question around Workforce Solutions. It seems like every year there's another wrinkle, another innovation, another customer. I mean, has this been an exceptional period, given developments like ACA, where you'd say, hey, that -- this was just a remarkable time? Or are we looking at the pace of change and an opportunity set that is just structurally bigger than you might have thought it was 2 or 3 years ago?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. And it's by far, the latter. I mean, I can see a day, where this business is so dramatically bigger than it is today, not just in the U.S. but global. And Andrew, we're going to wake up in x number of years, and it's going to be in a coup
componenttext: It's the latter. And it's by far, the latter. I mean, I can see a day, where this business is so dramatically bigger than it is today, not just in the U.S. but global. And Andrew, we're going to wake up in x number of years, and it's going to be in a couple of more geographies that are really important to us. I talked about trended data. We are just now in the early days of trended data. We're building the capabilities for trended data. So I would be remiss if I didn't say the leadership that was there was outstanding. They did a hell of a job, I'm sure. And Dann has done a hell of a job out there as you know. I mean, you've seen the financials. But really, we'll continue that progress and take this business to the next level. And it's not far-fetched to see at some juncture EWS being bigger than our core 117-year-old credit business and margins equal to if not higher than USIS. So that's kind of how we think about that.

componenttext: I think most of my questions have been answered. I guess on the back of the question that was just asked about EWS, it's clear that there's a lot of demand for these solutions globally. I guess, in the U.S., is there any place that you would call out as a major area of focus beyond, I think, most of us clearly get the case in autos, mortgage and government, but are there very obvious large areas that you should be going after that you're not today?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we've got our toes into everything, but it's all relative. It's are we going -- I'm going to hate this basic analogy, where we're again are moving in the bottom half the first inning or the top half of the ninth inning. In most cases, we're ve
componenttext: No, I think we've got our toes into everything, but it's all relative. It's are we going -- I'm going to hate this basic analogy, where we're again are moving in the bottom half the first inning or the top half of the ninth inning. In most cases, we're very early stages. So -- I mean, credit card is important to us. Insurance is important to us. Prescreening is important to us. So thinking about anywhere we're having a affirmation that someone is employed and the confirmation that how much someone makes across almost every vertical, there's a need for that. So we're into, I think, virtually all of them, Andrew, but it's some of our very, very early days. Well, penetration has got years to go.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on PSOL, I apologize if you've covered this before. I jumped on. But I know you took up the growth rate longer term. And was there anything particular about the reorg that should drive a material change in the strategy? Or is it really just getting ev
componenttext: And on PSOL, I apologize if you've covered this before. I jumped on. But I know you took up the growth rate longer term. And was there anything particular about the reorg that should drive a material change in the strategy? Or is it really just getting everyone on the same page, seeing the same numbers and having unified goal?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. It's the latter. Structure does not necessarily always facilitate faster growth. In fact, growth can be slower. This is -- it just intellectually makes sense to have one team manage every aspect of the strategy for a consumer regardless of
componenttext: Good question. It's the latter. Structure does not necessarily always facilitate faster growth. In fact, growth can be slower. This is -- it just intellectually makes sense to have one team manage every aspect of the strategy for a consumer regardless of how the consumer buys that product directly from us or through a partner of ours. So that's why we did that. I don't think that in itself changes the growth profile. It's executing, and it's the four-pronged strategy we laid last year that gives us confidence that the growth of PSOL multiyear model is slightly higher than the past.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions; one, just focusing on EWS. You talked about the geographic expansion opportunity. The way I understand that business works, you need sort of a database of numbers in order to really start having a product to sell. And you mentioned you had
componenttext: Two questions; one, just focusing on EWS. You talked about the geographic expansion opportunity. The way I understand that business works, you need sort of a database of numbers in order to really start having a product to sell. And you mentioned you had teams on the ground in several geographies. Are they just there constructing that database? And kind of how long does it take to get to a salable product in those geos? And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's going to take a while. This is -- when I think about the multiyear model we communicated earlier, Brett, it does not contemplate internationally, and I would never do that. So it's going to take a while to build a database, but we're good at it. We k
componenttext: It's going to take a while. This is -- when I think about the multiyear model we communicated earlier, Brett, it does not contemplate internationally, and I would never do that. So it's going to take a while to build a database, but we're good at it. We know how to do it. We get funds invested in doing it. We got people invested in doing it. We've got customers we know very well, one. We got the technology. We got the platforms. We know how to do it. But it's going to take a while to get it done. This is something you look out over a 5-year period of time and say, got it, now it's [indiscernible] versus fourth quarter 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a bigger picture question. I'm trying to tick off all, I think, of the major growth opportunities. Wondered if you just sort of rank them in terms of your excitement? And I guess, the categories are trended data, Cambri
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a bigger picture question. I'm trying to tick off all, I think, of the major growth opportunities. Wondered if you just sort of rank them in terms of your excitement? And I guess, the categories are trended data, Cambrian, the NPI/EGI and maybe the -- just talking about Work Number going international? Maybe there's another one or twoI'm missing. But as you think about the 3-year opportunity in those, which ones are -- kind of how do you rank them?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we're so good at and we've done for so long is NPI and EGI. So that's something that obviously as an investor or an analyst is thinking about us should have high level of confidence in continuing at the rate it's continued, if not higher. Two, you al
componenttext: What we're so good at and we've done for so long is NPI and EGI. So that's something that obviously as an investor or an analyst is thinking about us should have high level of confidence in continuing at the rate it's continued, if not higher. Two, you alluded to just the core of EWS, which we talked about quite a bit this morning. Continuing to grow International for EWS, obviously, is one. Cambrian. You can't underestimate Cambrian. Cambrian will not only allows us to link these different data assets together to build products we can never built before but we can build them fast. So time to revenuewill be faster with Cambrian. Obviously, I mean, small tuck-in acquisitions that we're so good at, and hopefully, we continue to be really good at. So we know how to do it. That will be a vehicle for profitable growth going forward. So the cool thing is, and I think you'll agree is, it's not just 1, 2 or 3 things we're counting on for growth. The foundation has been built by our teams that have got so many levers to pull that gives you pretty good confidence.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Rick, how concerned are you about the Australian economy and their ties to China and then impacts for Veda? Or are just really excited about all the opportunities to bring value over there, and that's going to overwhelm the concerns that y
componenttext: Okay. And then, Rick, how concerned are you about the Australian economy and their ties to China and then impacts for Veda? Or are just really excited about all the opportunities to bring value over there, and that's going to overwhelm the concerns that you might have from an economic perspective over there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local basi
componenttext: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local basis in Australia to think about that. And have walked away with a couple of thoughts, Shlomo. One is for 2016, unless there is an implosion that no one has ever contemplated in China, they've diversified their markets, their economy as such that, in fact, the consensus even today is a stronger GDP in Australia than 2015. The second thought I have is, if they're going to have recession eventually, you can't defy odds. I think they're the second-longest running economy in the history of modern time in the world. The time they had their last recession, they're going to have one eventually. The third, we're making investment like this. We don't make an investment for a quarter, for a year, for 2-year period of time. This is a part of the world that we want to be in. We have great partner down there now with Veda. They give us a lens into so many more geographies down there, beyond just Australia, New Zealand. So it's a generational bet, not just a quarter or a year bet.

componenttext: So on the direct-to-consumer business, you've talked in the past about your four-pronged strategy: Indirect, International, equifax.com, the freemium market. headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

Good day, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being record
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, our Chairman in Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today in the Investor Relations section of the About Equifax tab of our website at www.equifax.com. 
In the fourth quarter of 2015, we realigned the reporting structure of our direct-to-consumer reseller business, so that it now reports into our Personal Solutions business. Previously, direct-to-consumer resellers were reported within the USIS and International segments based on the country of the customer. We have provided the quarterly history for Personal Solutions, USIS and International, and the new format for each quarter in 2014 and 2015 in the Q&A section of our earnings release. All discussion of the 2015 business unit performance and their outlook for 2016 will be consistent with the new structure. 
Earlier this week, the Veda shareholders voted to accept Equifax's acquisition offer, and we also received subsequent approval from the court.
