So it's not right now in our guidance. It's not in the model we use to justify buying the company. But I'm more hopeful and impressed now than I was in early days that it will be a meaningful change down the road.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question with Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We will take our next question with Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You already commented on USIS maybe being towards the lower end of the long-term targets. But how about the other businesses? Are any of them in the exceed position to be above the high end this year? Or would we think those targets by segment are good pl
componenttext: You already commented on USIS maybe being towards the lower end of the long-term targets. But how about the other businesses? Are any of them in the exceed position to be above the high end this year? Or would we think those targets by segment are good places to be for 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, the ranges are there for a reason. We think they're pretty solid ranges. And you're going to see nuances and noise quarter-to-quarter, as you guys know, and maybe even year-to-year. But over multiple years, those ranges feel pretty good. The one --
componenttext: Look, the ranges are there for a reason. We think they're pretty solid ranges. And you're going to see nuances and noise quarter-to-quarter, as you guys know, and maybe even year-to-year. But over multiple years, those ranges feel pretty good. The one -- again, the one business that's really clicking on all cylinders and probably has more runway to exceed would be EWS. I mean, their sandbox is just -- it's a bigger sandbox, and they're less mature business, and they've got early days of growth. So if there's one that you've got to say it maybe has more opportunity to outperform, it's that one.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that include your commentary about mortgage being much tougher comps still able to do very well there?
componenttext: And would that include your commentary about mortgage being much tougher comps still able to do very well there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And the other thing I'd say, maybe too, is -- so, yes. So that's including the mortgage environment I just alluded to down single digits and walked out performance. So obviously, if mortgage is stronger than we expect, that benefits EWS as wel
componenttext: Absolutely. And the other thing I'd say, maybe too, is -- so, yes. So that's including the mortgage environment I just alluded to down single digits and walked out performance. So obviously, if mortgage is stronger than we expect, that benefits EWS as well as USIS. The other business may be short term in 2016 I think about having maybe more runway than the long-term model would be PSOL because they get some pretty good things going as they redefine their model as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a question on within the International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you face a really tough comp. So how are you thinking about that? And then
componenttext: And then a question on within the International on Latin America. Two-part question, I guess. It seems like there's a lot weaker economic activity in a bunch of those markets, and you face a really tough comp. So how are you thinking about that? And then specifically, can you comment on how much inflation in Argentina is driving the growth of that segment versus volume or unit sales of your offerings?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. But the first part is, and I think I alluded to it in my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates they're growing in spite of difficult economic environments in Latin America
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we break that second part up. But the first part is, and I think I alluded to it in my comments, what's allowing International to continue to grow at the rates they're growing in spite of difficult economic environments in Latin America and other parts of the world too, is innovation. I mentioned that a majority of their -- 2/3 of their revenue in these large geographies aren't generating Vitality Index from New Product Innovation above 10%. So if it weren't for that -- and they're also a benefactor of EGI, obviously, as well. But if it weren't for those innovative approaches through products in EGI, they would not be performing like they're performing.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one last cleanup one. Do you have -- I know it's early, but do you have a sense for what we expect the amortization and depreciation from Veda to be?
componenttext: Great. And then just one last cleanup one. Do you have -- I know it's early, but do you have a sense for what we expect the amortization and depreciation from Veda to be?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey. It's early. And obviously, as the transaction closes, these numbers will be updated. But acquisition amortization, right now, we're assuming it somewhere in the neighborhood of $95 million.
componenttext: Hey. It's early. And obviously, as the transaction closes, these numbers will be updated. But acquisition amortization, right now, we're assuming it somewhere in the neighborhood of $95 million.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jeff Meuler with Baird.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jeff Meuler with Baird.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Nick Nikitas on for Jeff. Just switching back to Veda and maybe talking more about some revenue and potential synergies, you mentioned TDX has seen some positive signs in Australia. Do you guys maybe see that as an opportunity to leverage Veda's p
componenttext: This is Nick Nikitas on for Jeff. Just switching back to Veda and maybe talking more about some revenue and potential synergies, you mentioned TDX has seen some positive signs in Australia. Do you guys maybe see that as an opportunity to leverage Veda's presence throughout the region? Or is there any other potential avenues that you see to drive additional growth into the future?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got a small team domiciled in Australia and New Zealand that represented the debt management analytics platforms. So yes, having access to a much larger sales organization with deeper, longer-standing relationships will help our debt management
componenttext: Yes, we've got a small team domiciled in Australia and New Zealand that represented the debt management analytics platforms. So yes, having access to a much larger sales organization with deeper, longer-standing relationships will help our debt management growth. But beyond that, one, we're getting a business that's got great organic growth opportunities. I alluded the fact there's inorganic opportunities. And then the others are bringing things like the Work Number to Australia, bringing Cambrian to Australia, bringing InterConnect to Australia, bringing our global fraud platform to Australia. It's hard -- you can't underestimate the relationship these guys have in Australia and New Zealand, and the market presence they have with all major verticals is significant. And they build out, much like Equifax has in Australia and New Zealand, a very wide array of unique data assets. And if we can bring our know-how to bear there to build products, that is a great growth driver. And then as someone, I think it was Andrew, asked a second ago, eventually when comprehensive, as you referred to or positive data as many referred to it, when that becomes mainstream, guess what, we know how to manage positive data and build production on positive data really well. And that, in years to come, is another growth driver for us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just within the U.K., was TDX a sizable contribution to the 4Q? Or is that still thinking about '16 more of a strong contributor there if we're looking at growth rates a similar kind of low double-digit European growth rate as possib
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just within the U.K., was TDX a sizable contribution to the 4Q? Or is that still thinking about '16 more of a strong contributor there if we're looking at growth rates a similar kind of low double-digit European growth rate as possible?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business. TDX continued to provide growth, but we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business as well. Just to make sure I was -- everyone understands my answer, the $95 million for Veda acquisi
componenttext: Yes, we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business. TDX continued to provide growth, but we saw very nice growth rates in the core U.K. business as well. Just to make sure I was -- everyone understands my answer, the $95 million for Veda acquisition amortization is an annualized number. It's not the '16 number. It's an annualized number.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, it's interesting the way the PSOL business has evolved generally in direct to consumer in particular. And obviously, Credit Karma was a big win. Can you frame up, perhaps, the additional opportunities in DTC? Is Credit Karma, probably, the biggest o
componenttext: Rick, it's interesting the way the PSOL business has evolved generally in direct to consumer in particular. And obviously, Credit Karma was a big win. Can you frame up, perhaps, the additional opportunities in DTC? Is Credit Karma, probably, the biggest opportunity -- biggest single opportunity you see out there recognizing that the markets changing pretty quickly and you have some new entrants? Or are there other large, potential targets, too, that could be call outs the way Credit Karma was?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side or the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be. I don't see it as probable.
componenttext: Okay, good question. No doubt that Credit Karma in the U.S. marketplace for the reseller side or the indirect channel, as we call it, is a uniquely large piece of business. Might there be a larger U.S. piece in that? Might be. I don't see it as probable. But LifeLock is going to be very good add to us, expanding what PSOL does. And also, think about -- what you got is 2 other things that are important. You've got -- now taking that same concept of Credit Karma to other geographies, which we operate, taking it to Australia, taking it to Canada, taking it to U.K. And also you've got Dann Adams. And one of the beauties, Andrew, of moving leaders around to different businesses is they have a different perspective than the predecessor. And Dann is looking at this business now saying, can look at the breach market differently? He's looking and saying, how do I combine some of the assets that we have from EWS -- where he was for 5.5 years -- into the global PSOL channel? So it's not just the large indirect resellers that give me hope for the long-term growth in PSOL, it's the 4 levers we talked about plus taking other data assets into PSOL.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'll ask you, I guess, the same question around Workforce Solutions. It seems like every year there's another wrinkle, another innovation, another customer. I mean, has this been an exceptional period, given developments like ACA, where you'd sa
componenttext: Okay. And I'll ask you, I guess, the same question around Workforce Solutions. It seems like every year there's another wrinkle, another innovation, another customer. I mean, has this been an exceptional period, given developments like ACA, where you'd say, hey, that -- this was just a remarkable time? Or are we looking at the pace of change and an opportunity set that is just structurally bigger than you might have thought it was 2 or 3 years ago?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the latter. And it's by far, the latter. I mean, I can see a day where this business is so dramatically bigger than it is today, not just in the U.S. but global. And Andrew, we're going to wake up in x number of years, and it's going to be in a coupl
componenttext: It's the latter. And it's by far, the latter. I mean, I can see a day where this business is so dramatically bigger than it is today, not just in the U.S. but global. And Andrew, we're going to wake up in x number of years, and it's going to be in a couple of more geographies that are really important to us. I talked about trended data. We are just now in the early days of trended data. We're building the capabilities for trended data. So I would be remiss if I didn't say the leadership that was there was outstanding. They did a hell of a job, I'm sure. And Dann has done a hell of a job out there as you know. I mean, you've seen the financials. But Rudy will continue that progress and take this business to the next level. And it's not far-fetched to see at some juncture EWS being bigger than our core 117-year-old credit business and margins equal to if not higher than USIS. So that's kind of how we think about that.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: If government regulation continues to extend the opportunities to expand the compliance business, so it's not just in verifier, it's in employer as well. It's both sides of the business.
componenttext: If government regulation continues to extend the opportunities to expand the compliance business, so it's not just in verifier, it's in employer as well. It's both sides of the business.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great point.
componenttext: Great point.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's pretty ambitious and pretty exciting. So good.
componenttext: Okay, that's pretty ambitious and pretty exciting. So good.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think most of my questions have been answered. I guess on the back of the question that was just asked about EWS, it's clear that there's a lot of demand for these solutions globally. I guess, in the U.S., is there any place that you would call out as a
componenttext: I think most of my questions have been answered. I guess on the back of the question that was just asked about EWS, it's clear that there's a lot of demand for these solutions globally. I guess, in the U.S., is there any place that you would call out as a major area of focus beyond, I think, most of us clearly get the case in autos, mortgage and government, but are there very obvious large areas that you should be going after that you're not today?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we've got our toes into everything, but it's all relative. It's are we going -- I'm going to hate to use a baseball analogy but I will again -- are we in the bottom half the first inning or the top half of the ninth inning? In most cases, we'r
componenttext: No, I think we've got our toes into everything, but it's all relative. It's are we going -- I'm going to hate to use a baseball analogy but I will again -- are we in the bottom half the first inning or the top half of the ninth inning? In most cases, we're very early stages. So -- I mean, credit card is important to us. Insurance is important to us. Prescreening is important to us. So thinking about anywhere we're having a affirmation that someone is employed and the confirmation how much someone makes across almost every vertical, there's a need for that. So we're into, I think, virtually all of them, Andrew (sic) [Andre], but it's some of our very, very early days where penetration has got years to go.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on PSOL, I apologize if you've covered this before I jumped on. But I know you took up the growth rate longer term. And was there anything particular about the reorg that should drive a material change in the strategy? Or is it really just getting eve
componenttext: And on PSOL, I apologize if you've covered this before I jumped on. But I know you took up the growth rate longer term. And was there anything particular about the reorg that should drive a material change in the strategy? Or is it really just getting everyone on the same page, seeing the same numbers and having unified goal?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. It's the latter. Structure does not necessarily always facilitate faster growth. In fact, growth can be slower. This is -- it just intellectually makes sense to have one team manage every aspect of the strategy for a consumer regardless of
componenttext: Good question. It's the latter. Structure does not necessarily always facilitate faster growth. In fact, growth can be slower. This is -- it just intellectually makes sense to have one team manage every aspect of the strategy for a consumer regardless of how the consumer buys that product directly from us or through a partner of ours. So that's why we did that. I don't think that in itself changes the growth profile. It's executing, against the 4-pronged strategy we laid last year that gives us confidence that the growth of PSOL multiyear model is slightly higher than the past.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Brett Huff with Stephens.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brett Huff with Stephens.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions; one, just focusing on EWS. You talked about the geographic expansion opportunity. The way I understand that business works, you need sort of a database of numbers in order to really start having a product to sell. And you mentioned you had
componenttext: Two questions; one, just focusing on EWS. You talked about the geographic expansion opportunity. The way I understand that business works, you need sort of a database of numbers in order to really start having a product to sell. And you mentioned you had teams on the ground in several geographies. Are they just there constructing that database? And kind of how long does it take to get to a salable product in those geos? And then I have one follow-up.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's going to take a while. This is -- when I think about the multiyear model we communicated earlier, Brett, it does not contemplate internationally, and I would never do that. So it's going to take a while to build a database, but we're good at it. We k
componenttext: It's going to take a while. This is -- when I think about the multiyear model we communicated earlier, Brett, it does not contemplate internationally, and I would never do that. So it's going to take a while to build a database, but we're good at it. We know how to do it. We get funds invested in doing it. We got people invested in doing it. We've got customers we know very well that want it. We got the technology. We got the platforms. We know how to do it. But it's going to take a while to get it done. This is something you look out over a 5-year period of time and say, got it, now it's delivering revenue versus fourth quarter 2016.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a bigger picture question. I'm trying to tick off all, I think, of the major growth opportunities. Wondered if you just sort of rank them in terms of your excitement? And I guess, the categories are trended data, Cambri
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a bigger picture question. I'm trying to tick off all, I think, of the major growth opportunities. Wondered if you just sort of rank them in terms of your excitement? And I guess, the categories are trended data, Cambrian, the NPI/EGI and maybe the -- just talking about Work Number going international? Maybe there's another 1 or 2 I'm missing. But as you think about the 3-year opportunity in those, which ones are -- kind of how do you rank them?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we're so good at and we've done for so long is NPI and EGI. So that's something that obviously as an investor or an analyst is thinking about us should have high level of confidence in continuing at the rate it's continued, if not higher. Two, you al
componenttext: What we're so good at and we've done for so long is NPI and EGI. So that's something that obviously as an investor or an analyst is thinking about us should have high level of confidence in continuing at the rate it's continued, if not higher. Two, you alluded to just the core of EWS, which we talked about quite a bit this morning. Continuing to grow International for EWS, obviously, is one. Cambrian. You can't underestimate Cambrian. Cambrian will not only allows us to link these different data assets together to build products we can never built before but we can build them faster. So time to revenue will be faster with Cambrian. Obviously, I mean, small tuck-in acquisitions that we're so good at, and hopefully, we continue to be really good at. So we know how to do it. That will be a vehicle for profitable growth going forward. So the cool thing is, and I think you'll agree is, it's not just 1, 2 or 3 things we're counting on for growth. The foundation has been built by our teams that have got so many levers to pull that gives you pretty good confidence.

Or are just really excited about all the opportunities to bring value over there, and that's going to overwhelm the concerns that you might have from an economic perspective over there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local basi
componenttext: Good question. Yes, we spend a lot of time trying to understand and deconstruct the economic drivers of the Australian economy, dependency on exports to China. We engage some of, I think, the best economic minds on a global basis as well as the local basis in Australia to think about that. And have walked away with a couple of thoughts, Shlomo. One is for 2016, unless there is an implosion that no one has ever contemplated in China, they've diversified their markets, their economy as such that, in fact, the consensus even today is a stronger GDP in Australia than 2015. The second thought I have is, if they're going to have recession eventually, you can't defy odds. I think they're the second-longest running economy in the history of modern time in the world. The time they had their last recession, they're going to have one eventually. But third, we're making investment like this, we don't make an investment for a quarter, for a year, for 2-year period of time. This is a part of the world that we want to be in. We have great partner down there now with Veda. They give us a lens into so many more geographies down there, beyond just Australia, New Zealand. So it's a generational bet, not just a quarter or a year bet.

componenttext: So on the direct-to-consumer business, you've talked in the past about your 4-pronged strategy: Indirect, International, equifax.com, the freemium market. And you've had some success there, especially on the direct-to-consumer resellers: Credit Karma and LifeLock. So I wanted to ask, how sensitive is or economically sensitive is this business? And then if it is economically sensitive, how strong are the trends towards credit literacy and other demands in terms of ID SaaS protection and other drivers on the secular side that could potentially offset it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: That's an interesting question. I had not done a statistical correlation analysis between the GDP and PSOL business. So if I give you an answer it would be wrong. But I think about drivers most likely help individual wanting to buy a PSOL product or products. It's: am I employed, am I experiencing some wage stability if not inflation, am I in the market for something -- those are tied together, right -- the health of the auto industry, if 'm unemployed, home versus and so on, so forth. So I'm not sure how to answer that other than that. I have not done a strong correlation analysis between what economic drivers and sensitivities drive PSOL up or down.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Equifax First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge with Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, our Chief Financial Officer.Today's call is being re
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge with Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, our Chief Financial Officer.
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com. During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual different to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including in 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings. During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect comparability of the underlying operational performance for the first quarter of 2016. Adjusted EPS excludes acquisition-related amortization expense as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda. Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain when onetime items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda. These non-GAAP measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with our earnings release and are also posted on our website.
Also refer to the investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details. Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks as always for joining us this morning on the call. Our first quarter performance certainly exceeded our expectations and further underscored the strength and the ability of this management team to consisten
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks as always for joining us this morning on the call. Our first quarter performance certainly exceeded our expectations and further underscored the strength and the ability of this management team to consistently deliver results that meet or exceed the commitments we made to you, our shareholders. And not only do have experienced leadership team but the entire organizational rhythm is geared to the management disciplines we created and built together over the last 10 or 11 years this attends our NPI, enterprise growth initiatives, Lean, growth account management, et cetera. Let me tell you one thing, this team is hungry and competitive and continue to winning streak that they've been on now for a number of years.
Our first quarter results are noteworthy as they are compared to a very strong performance in the first quarter 2015. 2016 first quarter was a record quarter, which is on top of a record year in 2015. For the quarter, total revenue was $728 million, that was up 12% on a reported basis and up 15% on a local currency basis from the first quarter of 2015. Organic constant currency revenue growth was very strong, up almost 11% over last year. Also in the quarter, foreign exchange created a $19 million year-over-year headwind. The adjusted EBITDA margin was 34.2% compared to 34.5% in the first quarter of 2015 and that was in line with our expectations when we guided for full year during our fourth quarter release, and John will talk about that in detail as will either if you have any questions. Adjusted EPS was $1.23, up 15% from $1.07 last year and significantly above the upper end of our guidance range.
As always, before John gives you the financial details, I'd like to briefly cover some more highlights for the first quarter as I always do. I'll talk about the business unit specifically first and the transition corporate level highlights. And then John will take the financials.
Starting, obviously, with USIS. They delivered solid 4% revenue growth in the quarter, double-digit growth in front, automotive, commercial and mortgage resellers helped offset slower goals in Mortgage Solutions, which, as you know, last year first quarter was a really, really strong quarter for us. New product innovation is expected a significant impact on USIS's future growth, while some of this is been driven by the initiatives that USIS like the company are very, very large base. Our current estimate, sticking with USIS, for 2016's class of new products are expected to have 3-year revenue that is double the estimate of our 2015 class. We'll talk about more about NPI at the company level later in my comments, but it's off to a very, very good start for USIS.
Also the pipeline a new product is much more robust than prior years. Our current pipeline is estimated to deliver significantly more revenue, incremental revenue growth reflecting both market demand and our increasing investments in products.
Cambria, which you've heard now about for a number of quarters, is having a very positive impact with our customers. Since launching Cambria, our mix of projects have shifted significantly towards multi-data sources and deeper insights for many our customers traditional decision activities. Data extraction and analysis time have been reduced by well over 50%. What that allows us to do is fail fast and as I've talked before, it shortens the cycle time of to bring new products to market.
Initial applications have address customer needs across the verticals including banking, auto, telecommunications. That's enabling us to enable our entire customer base with unified technology and skill sets.
Our work with Fannie Mae on trend today is on track and expected to go live as we committed to you over in the year and we'll go live at the end of June, 1st of July of this year. IT integration with Fannie Mae and ongoing platform for trending data is complete and our global operations team is in the final stages of establishing their support readiness program, again, anticipating at the end of June, early July launch.
USIS is expected to have another strong year in 2016 with growth at the lower end of the long-term range of 5% to 7% despite our continuing expectations for a flat to down mortgage market in 2016. EBITDA margins are expected to be at or above 50% for the year, which is slightly better than what we were expecting as we entered 2016.
On the international, they delivered 30% local currency revenue growth benefiting from broad-based organic growth, which is above the upper end of the long-term growth model, which is 8% to 10%. The growth was also, obviously, contributed from the support of the acquisition of Veda and John will go into a lot of detail on that.
Within international, NPI has been and will continue to be an important growth driver for them. Innovation in international is very broad-based. For instance, in the first quarter, over 60% of new product revenue was driven by our customers for decision activities, the remainder was driven by new solutions for high-value operations in ivy, identification, date the 360, front and debt management.
The relationship with U.K. government for our debt management services is strong and the initiative is off to a very good start. We have 5 central government agencies operationalized, including the HMRC, which is, as you recall, the equivalent to our IRS. And this represents most of the debt that has been placed for collections. We have placed over $800 million of debt the various agencies, were performing the analytics and the collections effort. Our data is fully integrated in the process of segmenting consumer and business accounts through terminal which agencies is best suited to collect that particular segment.
Revenue in international's 4 largest vertical, which are financial institutions, telcos, government and SMEs will be very strong 12% in the quarter, which is very broad-based across verticals and countries. The decision in platforms, Analytical Services and debt management revenue across solid 19% in the quarter, be deepening our relationship -- our customer relationships and strengthening our competitive position globally. Many of we delivered very healthy double-digit local currency growth in Latin America for a number of years and we expect to do so again this year, although the second evaluation of the Argentine peso will have a negative impact on our reported results in 2016, it appears that Argentina's new government is moving in the right direction to restore credibility and the financial markets.
In fact, I just returned from Argentina to spend sometime with our customers, government officials and economists and the outlook for Argentina in the next 2, 3, 4 years is as strong as I seen in my 10.5 years here. Across the region, in Latin America, we have a very good management team, a very strong market position and our strategy continues to resonate well with our customers.
Finally, the integration of via is going very well. Our primary focus at this point is 2 is a possible integration of the backroom processes, tools, the point products and capabilities from around the company that will add value to our local customers; and 3, ensuring all of our customer-facing teams in that region continues to service our customers well.
We continued to expect international to have a strong 2016. Organic revenue growth should be above the upper end of the long-term model, again, which is 8% to 10%, with EBITDA margins improving sequentially throughout the course of the year as planned.
On the work force solutions, they delivered an outstanding 21% revenue growth and over 200 basis points of EBITDA margin expansion in the first quarter. Work force solutions continued to grow were above the upper end from our multiyear model of 9% to 11% as really being driven strong execution of the core strategic growth initiatives which are adding records that the database, New Product Innovation, pursuing new growth opportunities and difficult such as automatic credit card, healthcare government in the growth continues to be very broad-based across many verticals, penetrating new customers and offer a new products.
Demand for solutions known as ACA, and solutions for employers continue to be strong. Our current outlook for the year is now ahead of the expectations we stated earlier in the year. And you may recall those expectations earlier in the year expected very significant grows over 2015, so that strength is getting even stronger as we move through 2016. We've also identified other interesting opportunities to help employers with their ACA compliance. That includes things like the IRS forms 10-94 and 10-95 and even beyond that. Work force solutions is emerging as a leader in what can be called compliance as a service to help employers solve increasingly complex compliance matters. A Swedish services has expanded and we continue to look for new opportunities our services with these emerging needs. An example of emerging need is new regulation coming out around overtime pay changes, and we are looking at leveraging our ACA analytical platform to solve those problems as well.
EWS' NPI Vitality Index is expected to be very strong again this year, reaching approximately 13%. The growth focus this year is on accelerating record growth in those working of the database and deepening market penetration and targeted markets against such as auto, car and government and maximizing opportunities to help employers with their compliance needs. Ford also continuing to solve employers complex HR compliance challenges. Work for solutions should have another outstanding year in 2016 with revenue growth well above the long-term range of 9% to 11%.
EBITDA margins should be in the high 40s, just shy of a long-term target we gave you earlier in the year of 50%.
On a global consumer solutions, they also had an exceptional quarter, with 16% local currency revenue growth and 100 basis points margin -- hundred basis points of EBITDA margin expansion. Indirect revenue was up over 50% as the team continues to sign large deals with established companies who seek to deepen and broaden the relationships with consumers.
Our customers and our pipeline is robust across multiple industries, including banking, retail, consumer products and services as well as our expanding relationship that we established last year with -- Mid-single-digit revenue growth for our direct-to-consumer activities was consistent with our expectations and largely driven by higher average in the U.S. and account acquisition outside the U.S.
Global consumer solutions first quarter performance was outstanding, and we now expect that they to will be comfortably exceed their long-term growth target -- constantly delivering doubled digit growth for the year of adjusted EBITDA margin for the year is expected to exceed 30%.
Before I go on to John, let me just give a couple of highlights at the corporate level and then John will give you the financials.
Our enterprise growth initiatives are off to a very good start this year. 3 or 4 transformational initiatives are developing the work global exchange; 2, disrupting innovation by cambria platform throughout our global footprint and; 3, unify our global consumer solutions business with a single operating platform around the world that we call let me jump at it each of those are a second.
With already completed the scope and the timeline for creating an income and employment verification exchange in a select group of our larger markets. We have the platform, we have strong customer demand and we will be moving forward with his efforts throughout 2016 and beyond.
We are -- the initial focus for globalizing Cambria will be in Canada, Argentina and Australia. Canada will be the first other geographies will complete their initial assessment and defined their requirements. We'll give you an update on other countries as we exit 2016. That bodes well for growth opportunities in '17, '18 and beyond. Our global IT platform supporting global consumer solutions Renaissance is expected to go live this year after deployment in our core markets of the U.S., Canada and the U.K., will evaluate for the market opportunities, obviously, including Australia and Latin America.
Cambrian has substantially enhanced our ability to provide unique, high value and size to our customers and it positions us well for the future. The platform can easily incorporate very contemporary analytic technologies, i.e. machine learning algorithms, analyze all types of unstructured data and provide customers with dashboards customized to their specific needs. In front, we've applied machine learning algorithms to increase prediction by over 20% by reducing false positives for Know Your Customer and anti-money laundering, we know unstructured data to reduce false positives by approximately 60%.
Customers were providing them with access to over 50 metrics on over $3 billion trade lines from their customers, with We 
Created a dashboard portal that will be updated on a periodic basis. These types of services uniquely enable us to further deepen our customer relationships and position as as a premier source of insights on their consumers. Although in the early year, our new product pipeline for 2016 looks very promising. We expect year 3 revenue from our 2016 launches to be up significantly from 2015 product launches in 3-year revenue expectation, which most of you may recall, 2015 class was up significantly over 2014.
two various solid product class will fuel growth through 2018. Our Lean -- our work with our customers leveraging our operational experience with Lean is creating great client Stickiness. It has been the activities we're helping our clients with our numerous and inclusions things as mortgage lending, collections, auto lending, marketing and employee on boarding so again, the activities are far beyond their interaction with us. Destroyed to make their processes more efficient. We've also extended their program to international on either completed or have projects in the pipeline in countries such as the U.K. and Canada. We have a number of clients where we have repeat engagements including 2 where we have had 5 separate engagements as 1 company since 2014.
Increasingly, client is making Equifax a trusted adviser in times of change. But these relationships were able to increase utilization of our products and services across the enterprise, identify new customer opportunities down year for product and services and support and strengthen long-term relationships.
Our broad-based performance continues to position us very nicely to exceed the targets we set for ourselves and have committed to our employees, our customers, shareholders and consumers.
We are now adding a second quarter with strong momentum and in many respects, have yet to fully realize the benefits of a number a strategic initiatives that were expected to meaningful contributions not only to this year but again, in 2017 and '18. With that, let me turn it over to John for the financials.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Just before, we'll generally be
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Just before, we'll generally be                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    we generated for into the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis.
As indicated previously, with the data acquisition, will ship adjusted EBITDA margin to more consistently present the operating performance of the segments and company as a whole. Adjusted EBITDA margin has been defined as adjusted net income plus depreciation, net interest expenses and taxes. At the segment level, adjusted EBITDA margin. As adjusted operating income plus depreciation, plus net equity and other income.
Given the change in our reporting structure, this metric will provide an improved understanding of segment performance as well as assessing their progress against our multiyear targets.
The GAAP, non-GAAP organization at -- the earnings release provide a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin.
As you will recall, we'll be excluding beta transaction expenses and integration expenses incurred through 1Q '17, the first year after the beta acquisition from our adjusted EPS and adjusted EBITDA margin. In 1Q '16, the total beta transaction pretax expense was about $22 million virtually all of which was transaction related. $16 million of these pretax expenses are reflected as operating expense. Of this $16 million, $12 million are investing millinery spreads legal and accounting adviser transaction fees and impact general corporate expense.
The remainder of the operating expense as a beta acquisition related, employee compensation of data, which is included in the international operating segment. Net FX loss is related to beta financing were approximately $6 million in the first quarter and are reflected as other income.
As a reminder, recognize $5 million in FX gains related to beta financing in 4Q '15. Looking forward, the remaining beta transaction expenses will be occurred in 2Q '16 and should be relatively smaller, principally final legal and finance fees related to require government filings and FX losses of approximately $3 million related to completion of the extinguishments of certain beta debts.
Beta integration expenses will increase in 2Q '16 as integration activities accelerate. Total beta transaction and integration pretax expenses in 2Q '16 are expected to be approximately $7 million, which includes the $3 million in FX losses.
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the first quarter.
U.S. information solutions revenue was $295 million, up 4% when compared to the first quarter of 2016 and consistent with our expectations. Online information solutions revenue was $280 million, up 5% when compared to the year-ago period, reflecting double-digit growth in commercial information in fraud. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $32 million, up 1% compared to Q1 2015. Total mortgage related revenue in USIS was up 7% in the quarter, which compares favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which is up 1% in the first quarter.
USIS total mortgage revenue growth continues to outpace overall mortgage market growth, consistent with our historical performance, although the mortgage market was slightly better than we anticipated for the quarter, our full-year outlook for mortgage origination remains the same as last quarter at flat to down slightly. On the Financial Marketing Services in the revenue was $45 million, up 1% when compared to the year-ago quarter. The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions was a strong 48.7%. As expected, this was down from the very strong 50.8% delivered in the first quarter of 2015, reflecting the very strong mortgage market in 1Q '15. In addition, the decline reflects increased legal expenses versus 1Q '15. Legal expenses incurred in any given period can be choppy. And excluding this increase legal expense, the adjusted EBITDA margin for 1Q '16 would have been down only slightly versus the record levels of 1Q '15.
Work force solutions revenue was $180 million for the quarter, up 21% when compared to the first quarter of 2015. Verification Services revenue of $99.2 million, up 16%, was driven by strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto and preemployment market segments. This reflects increased penetration verifiers as well as continued growth and records to the database.
Employer services revenue, $8.9 million, was up 29% from last year. Our traditional employer services businesses of unemployment claims -- validations and onboarding, performed well with, and revenue was consistent with our long-term electrification expectations in the mid-single digits. Workforce Analytics, had a very strong quarter as 1Q '16 and 2Q '16 represent the first in which employers are providing Form 1095C to employees as part of their annual tax filing and as required by the ACA.
As these forms are principally delivered in the first half of the year, we expect the strong growth in Workforce Analytics to continue into 2Q '16. The workforce solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 49.5%, up from 47.3% in 1Q '15. This reflects a very strong growth of our higher-margin verifier and Workforce Analytics businesses.
Revenue from our combined USIS and workforce solutions businesses, which represent our total U.S. B2B business activities was $475 million, representing organic growth of over 10%.
International's revenue was $158 million, up 17% on a reported basis and 30% on a local currency basis. Constant currency organic revenue growth, which excludes beta revenue, was slightly above our long-term range of 8% to 10%. By region, -- revenue was 100 -- was $61 million, up 10% in U.S. dollars and 15% in local currency.
Latin America's revenue was $43 million, down 11% in U.S. dollars but up 15% in local currency. As you probably know, Argentina's average FX rates in 1Q '16 depreciated almost 40% from 1Q '15. Argentina when combined with the impact on the currency and Uruguay, contributed almost 75% of the negative foreign exchange impact on revenue in Latin America.
Asia Pacific revenue was $28 million, which is comprised mostly of revenue from beta from net positive and are tedious management at the operations of Australia. Our current debt management revenue in Australia is very small. As a reminder, the Veda transaction closed on February 24, with that of being a part of Equifax for about 40% of the quarter. Canada revenue was $28 million, down 10% in U.S. dollars both flat and local currency. We saw continuing in improvement in Equifax Canada during the second half of 2015, both in terms of revenue growth and, importantly, the pipeline of new products we expect to begin to deliver revenue later in 2016 and 2017.
This flat performance in 1Q '16 reflects the relative weakness of the Canadian economy we referenced in our last earnings call. We expect improved performance as we -- as new products ramp later this year.
For the first quarter, international adjusted EBITDA margin was 25.3% and, as expected, down slightly from 1Q '15. The slight decline reflects the benefit of adding higher-margin as well as improved EBITDA margin performance it's in that management, which was offset by a decline in EBITDA margin and Latin America.
This decline in Latin America is due to substantial weakness of local currencies. A portion of our cost is in U.S. dollars, which does not benefit from the devaluation of the currency. Over the remainder of 2016 and international, we expect to show EBITDA margin growth, reflecting revenue growth on our higher-margin countries, coupled with the cost benefit of the regionalization program started last year.
Global consumer solutions revenue was $95 million, up 14% on a reported basis and up 16% on a local currency basis. Global Personal Solutions showed growth across all channels, B2C, indirect and direct and the strong growth in the quarter driven by principally by and to a lesser extent, our other channels. For the first quarter, in adjusted EBITDA margin was 30.8%, up 100 basis points from 1Q '15. This reflects strong revenue growth and leverage against support costs.
In the first quarter, general corporate expense of $71.6 million, was in line with our expectations and down 9% from last year. Onetime items impacted both 1Q '16 and 1Q '15. As I mentioned earlier, Veda integration expenses impact the corporate expense by just over $12 million in 1Q '16. As you will remember, in 1Q '15, we executed an organizational restructuring which impacted corporate expense by $23 million. Excluding these items, general corporate expense was approximately $59 million in 1Q '16, an increase of about $4 million or about 8%.
For the second quarter, we expect general corporate expense to be in the range of $55 million to $60 million including the integration expense. The adjusted EBITDA margin at 34.2% was down from 34.5% in 2016 and consistent with our expectations for the quarter. The reduction reflects the expected decline in USIS and international that we discussed customer earlier, partially offset by very strong EBITDA margin performance at both work for solutions and global consumer solutions.
We expect to see year-over-year growth in EBITDA margins in each of the second through fourth quarters and continue to expect 2016 EBITDA margins to be up approximately 75 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015.
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the first quarter was 33.5%, which is in line with our expectations. Our adjusted effective tax rate, excluding the tax impact of the data transaction integration expenses was 32.7%. This was consistent with the 32% guidance we have provided. For the remainder of 2016, we expect our expected tax rate to be slightly below this level, approaching 32%.
Capital expenditures for the quarter was $40 million. We continue to expect capital expenditures for the year to be at the high-end of our long-term range of 5% to 6% of revenue. This reflects expected spending related to the integration of Veda. Operating cash flow for the quarter was $90 million and consistent with our expectations. Operating cash flow was down from 1Q '15 U2 working capital movements. We continue to expect strong growth in cash flow year-over-year for 2016.
Total debt in the quarter was $3.08 billion, slightly below our expectations, yesterday we flighty Form 8-K, with the required Veda financial interest new statement which will give usx ability to take advantage of market windows to refinance a portion of the Veda acquisition. As an indicator last quarter, was banned our share repurchases during 2016 and focus our very strong cash flow and debt reduction and returning a leveraged to a level consistent with our target leverage. We will, however, continue with acquisitions beyond Veda in 2016 with the goal of delivering 1 to 2 points of additional ongoing revenue growth.
Finally, you'll recall that in our 2016 calendar year guidance, we indicated that we expect revenue from Veda of USD 220 million to USD 230 million. And that we expected a benefit of Veda to adjusted EPS of $0.10 to $0.15 per share. In addition, when you provided outlook from 1Q '16, we do not include any impact for Veda. As we indicated at that time, once we have completed the initial integration of Veda into our financial statements and had progressed in the transition of Veda U.S. Capital onto an, we have provide an update of these estimates.
Based on the completion of this were today, we are increasing our full year expectation for EPS accretion to approximately $0.20 per share. Our expectation for revenue in 2016 is now $230 million to $235 million, which reflects improved growth expectations, partially offset by a larger negative impact on revenue recognition from the movement U.S. GAAP accounting. Betas performance in 1Q '16 was consistent on a pro rata basis with these expectations. Acquisition amortization and 2016 from the beta acquisition expected to be approximately $55 million.
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As I give you guidance for second quarter and for the balance of the year, just to clarify, that does not assume any additional M&A at this juncture. So it's, obviously, the full year of Veda in the numbers plus organic growth. And as John a
componenttext:
Thanks, John. As I give you guidance for second quarter and for the balance of the year, just to clarify, that does not assume any additional M&A at this juncture. So it's, obviously, the full year of Veda in the numbers plus organic growth. And as John alluded to in his comments, we are expecting to do additional tuck-in M&A this year. That's just not in the guidance I'm about to give you. I want to make sure that was there.
For the second quarter, we're increasing our outlook for both revenues and adjusted EPS. We now expect revenue, including Veda to be between $795 million and $805 million, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of 20% to 22% that's partially offset by 3% of FX headwind. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.34 and $1.36. That's up 17% to 18% over 2015, excluding $0.03 per share of negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 19% to 21%.
With our strong first performance in second quarter and outlook of second quarter, we also increasing our full year outlook for the year. We expect revenue, including the impact of Veda to be between $3.05 million to $3.15 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of 17% to 21%. Again, partially offset by 2 to 3 points of FX headwinds.
This is up from the previous guidance of $3.0 billion and $3.1 billion and moves nicely above the high end of a multiyear financial model, 60% organic growth. And you also up expect potential additional growth requisition is the pipeline a strong, but not included in our outlook.
Adjusted EPS for the years compacted to be between $5.15 and $5.25, which is up 14% to 17% year-on-year, excluding approximately $0.12 per share of negative impact and FX. This reflects constant currency EPS growth of 17% and 19%. This, too, is up from $4.95 to $5.05 that we guided to during the fourth quarter earnings call a few months ago.
We also -- continue to expect, as John division, we expect our adjusted EBITDA margin to continue to expand our approximately 75 basis points for all of 2016.
So with that, operator, I'd you know to open up for any questions. Open the blinds

componenttext: Yes, so we didn't give the exact numbers, right? But effectively, the drivers were biggest driver was Latin in terms of reduction was Latin America comes to Latin America weakness pretty substantial devaluation of currencies, which is much larger than we've seen the last several years. We saw margin impact there. It was planned it was expected to occur and that is specifically related to the fact that we do have nonlocal currency expenses and all local currency revenue so that the margin system benefit on both the top and bottom line in the same way. Canada margins were slightly down as well because you saw and the revenue was flat in the local currency basis, expenses were up slightly, so yes, Canada market was down slightly. But the big driver was Latin America. And the positive side, in terms of international market to partially offset by declines were, obviously, the adding of Veda because they have very good EBITDA margins. And also as Rick mentioned during his prepared comments and after, debt management brewing performed better. We took out some cost of it as a better performance in overall margins in debt management. So that -- those were the drivers of why the why you saw basically flat EBITDA margins and international.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
