headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Equifax First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Equifax First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge with Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, our Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge with Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, our Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com. 
During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including the 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings. 
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance for the first quarter of 2016. Adjusted EPS excludes acquisition-related amortization expense as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda. Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax, adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain onetime items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda. These non-GAAP measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with earnings release and are also posted on our website. Also refer to the investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks as always for joining us this morning on the call. Our first quarter performance certainly exceeded our expectations and further underscored the strength and the ability of this management team to consisten
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks as always for joining us this morning on the call. Our first quarter performance certainly exceeded our expectations and further underscored the strength and the ability of this management team to consistently deliver results that meet or exceed the commitments we made to you, our shareholders. And not only do have an experienced leadership team, but the entire organizational rhythm is geared to the management disciplines that we've created and built together over the last 10 or 11 years. Those disciplines are NPI, enterprise growth initiatives, Lean, growth playbook, account management, et cetera. Let me tell you one thing, this team is hungry and competitive to continue the winning streak that they've been on now for a number of years.
Our first quarter results are noteworthy as they are compared to a very strong performance in the first quarter 2015. 2016 first quarter was a record quarter, which is on top of a record year in 2015. For the quarter, total revenue was $728 million, that was up 12% on a reported basis and up 15% on a local currency basis from the first quarter of 2015. Organic constant currency revenue growth was very strong, up almost 11% over last year. Also in the quarter, foreign exchange created a $19 million year-over-year headwind. 
The adjusted EBITDA margin was 34.2% compared to 34.5% in the first quarter of 2015, and that was in line with our expectations when we guided for the full year during our fourth quarter release. And John will talk about that in detail as will I if you have any questions. Adjusted EPS was $1.23, up 15% from $1.07 last year and significantly above the upper end of our guidance range.
As always, before John gives you the financial details, I'd like to briefly cover some highlights for the first quarter as I always do. I'll talk about the business units specifically first and then transition into some corporate-level highlights. And then John will take the financials.
Starting, obviously, with USIS. They delivered solid 4% revenue growth in the quarter. Double-digit growth in fraud, automotive, commercial and mortgage resellers helped offset slower growth in Mortgage Solutions, which, as you know, last year first quarter, was a really, really strong quarter for us. New product innovation is expected to have significant impact on USIS's future growth. While some of this is being driven by Cambrian, the initiatives at USIS, like the company, are very, very broad-based. 
Our current estimate, sticking with USIS, for 2016's class of new products are expected to have 3-year revenue that is double the estimate of our 2015 class. We'll talk more about NPI at the company level later in my comments, but it's off to a very, very good start for USIS.
Also the pipeline of new products is much more robust than prior years. Our current pipeline is estimated to deliver significantly more revenue -- incremental revenue growth, reflecting both greater market demand and our increasing investments in products.
Cambrian, which you've heard now about for a number of quarters, is having a very positive impact with our customers. Since launching Cambria, our mix of projects has shifted significantly towards multi-data sources and deeper insights for many of our customers' traditional decision activities. Data extraction and analysis time have been reduced by well over 50%. What that allows us to do is fail fast, and as I've talked before, it shortens the cycle time to bring new products to market.
Initial applications have addressed customer needs across diverse verticals, including banking, auto and telecommunications. That's enabling us to leverage our entire customer base with unified technology and skill sets.
Our work with Fannie Mae on trended data is on track and expected to go live as we committed to you earlier in the year and will go live at the end of June, 1st of July of this year. IT integration with Fannie Mae and the ongoing platform for trended data is complete, and our global operations team is in the final stages of establishing their support readiness program, again, anticipating an end of June, early July launch.
USIS is expected to have another strong year in 2016, with growth at the lower end of the long-term range of 5% to 7% despite our continuing expectations for a flat to down mortgage market in 2016. EBITDA margins are expected to be at or above 50% for the year, which is slightly better than what we were expecting as we entered 2016.
On to International. They delivered 30% local currency revenue growth, benefiting from broad-based organic growth, which is above the upper end of the long-term growth model, which is 8% to 10%. The growth was also, obviously, contributed from the support of the acquisition of Veda. And John will go into a lot of detail on that.
Within International, NPI has been and will continue to be an important growth driver for them. Innovation in International is very broad-based. For instance, in the first quarter, over 60% of new product revenue was driven by our customers' core decisioning activities. The remainder was driven by new solutions for high-value offerings in ID, authentication, Data 360, fraud and debt management.
The relationship with the U.K. government for our debt management services is strong, and the initiative is off to a very good start. We have 5 central government agencies operationalized, including the HMRC, which is, as you recall, the equivalent to our IRS. And this represents most of the debt that has been placed for collections. We have placed over $800 million of debt with various agencies, who are performing the analytics and the collections effort. Our data is fully integrated in the process of segmenting consumer and business accounts to determine which agency is best suited to collect that particular segment.
Revenue in International's 4 largest verticals, which are financial institutions, telcos, government and SMEs, grew a very strong 12% in the quarter, which is very broad-based across verticals and countries. The decisioning platforms, Analytical Services and debt management revenue across International grew a very solid 19% in the quarter. The high-value solutions are deepening our relationship -- our customer relationships and strengthening our competitive position globally. 
Many of you know we delivered very healthy double-digit local currency growth in Latin America for a number of years, and we expect to do so again this year. Although the significant devaluation of the Argentine peso will have a negative impact on our reported results in 2016, it appears that Argentina's new government is moving in the right direction to restore credibility in the financial markets. In fact, I just returned from Argentina to spend some time with our customers, government officials and economists, and the outlook for Argentina in the next 2, 3, 4 years is as strong as I've seen in my 10.5 years here. 
Across the region, in Latin America, we have a very good management team, a very strong market position and our strategy continues to resonate well with our customers.
Finally, the integration of Veda is going very well. Our primary focus at this point is threefold: one, is the thoughtful integration of the backroom processes; two, deploying products and capabilities from around the company that will add value to our local customers; and three, ensuring that all of our customer-facing teams in that region continues to service our customers well.
We continue to expect International to have a strong 2016. Organic revenue growth should be above the upper end of the long-term model, again, which is 8% to 10%, with EBITDA margins improving sequentially throughout the course of the year as planned.
On to Workforce Solutions. They delivered an outstanding 21% revenue growth and over 200 basis points of EBITDA margin expansion in the first quarter. Workforce Solutions continues to grow well above the upper end of our multiyear model of 9% to 11%. That's really being driven through strong execution of their core strategic growth initiatives, which are adding records to the database, a new product innovation, pursuing new growth opportunities in difficult verticals such as automotive, credit card, healthcare and government. The growth continues to be very broad-based across many verticals, penetrating new customers and offering new products.
Demand for our Affordable Care Act solutions, known as ACA, the solutions for employers, continue to be strong. And our current outlook for the year is now ahead of the expectations we stated earlier in the year. And you may recall that those expectations earlier in the year expected very significant growth over 2015, so that strength is getting even stronger as we move through 2016. 
We've also identified other interesting opportunities to help employers with their ACA compliance. That includes things like the IRS forms 1094 and 1095 and even beyond that. Workforce Solutions is emerging as a leader in what can be called compliance as a service to help employers solve increasingly complex compliance matters. A suite of services has expanded, and we continue to look for new opportunities to align our services for these emerging needs. An example that's an emerging need is new regulation coming out around overtime pay changes, and we are looking at leveraging our ACA analytic platform to solve those problems as well.
EWS' NPI Vitality Index is expected to be very strong again this year, reaching approximately 13%. The growth focus this year is on accelerating record growth in the work number database and deepening market penetration in targeted markets, again, such as auto, card and government, and maximizing opportunities to help employers with their compliance needs. Fourth, also continue to solve employer's complex HR compliance challenges. 
Workforce Solutions should have another outstanding year in 2016, with revenue growth well above the long-term range of 9% to 11%. EBITDA margins should be in the high 40s, just shy of a long-term target we gave to you early in the year of 50%.
On to Global Consumer Solutions. They also had an exceptional quarter, with 16% local currency revenue growth and 100 basis points margin -- hundred basis points of EBITDA margin expansion. Indirect revenue was up over 50% as the team continues to sign large deals with established companies who seek to deepen and broaden their relationships with consumers.
Our customers and our pipeline is robust across multiple industries, including banking, retail, consumer products and services as well as our expanding relationship that we established last year with Credit Karma. Mid-single-digit revenue growth for our direct-to-consumer activities was consistent with our expectations and largely driven by higher average revenue per subscriber in the U.S. and account acquisition outside the U.S.
Global Consumer Solutions first quarter performance was outstanding, and we now expect that they too will comfortably exceed their long-term growth target, comfortably delivering double-digit growth for the year, the adjusted EBITDA margin for the year is expected to exceed 30%.
Before I go on to John, let me just give a couple of highlights at the corporate level, and then John will give you the financials.
Our enterprise growth initiatives are off to a very good start this year. 3 of our 4 transformational initiatives are: one, developing the work network into a global exchange; two, disrupting innovation by expanding our Cambrian platform throughout our global footprint and; three, unifying our Global Consumer Solutions business with a single-operating platform around the world that we call Renaissance. Let me jump into each of those for a second.
We've already completed the scope and the time line for creating an income and employment verification exchange in a select group of our larger markets. We have a platform, we have strong customer demand and we'll be moving forward with this effort throughout 2016 and beyond.
We are -- the initial focus for globalizing Cambrian will be in Canada, Argentina and Australia. Canada will be the first while other geographies will complete their initial assessment and define their requirements. We'll give you an update on other countries as we exit 2016. But that bodes well for growth opportunities in '17, '18 and beyond. 
Our global IT platform supporting Global Consumer Solutions, again, called Renaissance, is expected to go live this year. After deployment in our core markets in the U.S., Canada and U.K., we'll evaluate other market opportunities, obviously, including Australia and Latin America.
Cambrian has substantially enhanced our ability to provide unique, high-value insights to our customers, and it positions us well for the future. The platform can easily incorporate very contemporary analytic technologies, i.e. machine learning algorithms, analyze all types of unstructured data and provide customers with dashboards customized to their specific needs. 
In fraud, we will apply machine learning algorithms to increase prediction by over 20% by reducing false positives. For Know Your Customer and anti-money laundering, we will incorporate an unstructured data to reduce false positives by approximately 60%.
Four of our largest customers, we're providing them with access to over 50 metrics on over $3 billion trade lines from their customers. We've created a dashboard portal that will be updated on a periodic basis. These types of services uniquely enable us to further deepen our customer relationships and position us as the premier source of insights on their consumers. 
Although in the early year, our new product pipeline for 2016 looks very promising. We expect year 3 revenue from our 2016 launches to be up significantly from 2015 product launches in their 3-year revenue expectation, which, as most of you may recall, 2015 class was up significantly over 2014. Two very solid product classes will fuel growth through 2018. 
Our Lean -- our work with our customers leveraging our operational experience with Lean is creating great client stickiness. The activities we're helping our clients with are numerous and includes such things as mortgage lending, collections, auto lending, marketing and employee onboarding. So again, the activities are far beyond their interaction with us, just trying to make their processes more efficient. 
We've also extended the program to International now and have either completed or have projects in the pipeline in countries such as the U.K. and Canada. We have a number of clients where we have repeat engagements, including 2 where we have had 5 separate engagements at 1 company since 2014.
Increasingly, client leaders are making Equifax a trusted adviser in times of change. With these relationships, we're able to increase utilization of our products and services across the enterprise, identify new customer opportunities we have from the value of our products and services and support and strengthen long-term relationships.
Our broad-based performance continues to position us very nicely to exceed the targets we set for ourselves and have committed to our employees, our customers, shareholders and consumers. We are now adding the second quarter with strong momentum and in many respects, have yet to fully realize the benefit of a number of these strategic initiatives that were expected to make meaningful contributions not only to this year, but again, to 2017 and '18. 
With that, let me turn it over to John for the financials.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, we'll generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis.As we indicated previously, with the Veda acquisition, we will start focusing on adjusted E
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, we'll generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis.
As we indicated previously, with the Veda acquisition, we will start focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin to more consistently present the operating performance of the segments and of the company as a whole. Adjusted EBITDA margin has been defined as adjusted net income plus depreciation, net interest expense and taxes. At the segment level, adjusted EBITDA margin is adjusted operating income plus depreciation, plus net equity and other income.
Given the change in our reporting structure, this metric will provide an improved understanding of segment performance as well as assessing their progress against our multiyear targets. 
The GAAP and non-GAAP reconciliation attached to our earnings release provides a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin.
As you will recall, we'll be excluding Veda transaction expenses and integration expenses incurred through 1Q '17, the first year after the Veda acquisition, from our adjusted EPS and adjusted EBITDA margin. In 1Q '16, total Veda transaction and integration pretax expense was about $22 million, virtually all of which was transaction-related. $16 million of these pretax expenses are reflected as operating expense. Of this $16 million, $12 million are investment banking, legal and accounting adviser transaction fees and impact the general corporate expense.
The remainder of the operating expense is acquisition-related employee compensation expenses of Veda, which is included in the International operating segment. Net FX losses related to Veda financing were approximately $6 million in the first quarter and are reflected as other income. As a reminder, we recognize $5 million in FX gains related to Veda financing in 4Q '15. 
Looking forward, the remaining Veda transaction expenses will be incurred in 2Q '16 and should be relatively smaller, principally final legal and financial advisory fees related to completing required government filings and FX losses of approximately $3 million related to completion of the extinguishment of certain Veda debts.
Veda integration expenses will increase in 2Q '16 as integration activities accelerate. Total Veda transaction and integration pretax expenses in 2Q '16 are expected to be approximately $7 million, which includes the $3 million in FX losses.
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the first quarter.
U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $295 million, up 4% when compared to the first quarter of 2015 and consistent with our expectation. Online Information Solutions revenue was $280 million, up 5% when compared to the year-ago period, reflecting double-digit growth in commercial information and fraud. Mortgage Solutions revenue was $32 million, up 1% compared to Q1 2015. 
Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 7% in the quarter, which compares favorably to the Mortgage Bankers Application Index, which was up 1% in the first quarter. USIS total mortgage revenue growth continues to outpace overall mortgage market growth, consistent with our historical performance. Although the mortgage market was slightly better than we anticipated for the quarter, our full year outlook for mortgage origination remains the same as last quarter at flat to down slightly. 
On to Financial Marketing Services in which revenue was $45 million, up 1% when compared to the year-ago quarter. The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions was a strong 48.7%. As expected, this was down from the very strong 50.8% delivered in the first quarter of 2015, reflecting the very strong mortgage market in 1Q '15. In addition, this decline reflects increased legal expenses versus 1Q '15. Legal expenses incurred in any given period can be choppy. And excluding this increased legal expense, the adjusted EBITDA margin for 1Q '16 would have been down only slightly versus the record levels of 1Q '15.
Workforce Solutions revenue was $180 million for the quarter, up 21% when compared to the first quarter of 2015. Verification Services revenue of $99.2 million, up 16%, was driven by strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto and preemployment market segments. This reflects increased penetration with verifiers as well as continued growth in records to the database.
Employer Services revenue of $80.9 million was up 29% from last year. Our traditional Employer Services businesses of unemployment claims, Watsi, I-9 validations and onboarding performed well, with combined revenue growth consistent with our long-term expectations in the mid-single digits. Workforce Analytics had a very strong quarter as 1Q '16 and 2Q '16 represent the first in which employers are providing Form 1095-Cs to employees as part of their annual tax filings and as required by the ACA. As these forms are principally delivering in the first half of the year, we expect the strong growth in Workforce Analytics to continue into 2Q '16. 
The Workforce Solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 49.5%, up from 47.3% in 1Q '15. This reflects a very strong growth of our higher-margin verifier and Workforce Analytics businesses.
Revenue from our combined USIS and Workforce Solutions businesses, which represent our total U.S. B2B business activities, was $475 million, representing organic growth of over 10%.
International's revenue was $158 million, up 17% on a reported basis and 30% on a local currency basis. Constant currency organic revenue growth, which excludes Veda revenue, was slightly above our long-term range of 8% to 10%. By region, Europe's revenue was 100 -- was $61 million, up 10% in U.S. dollars and 15% in local currency. Latin America's revenue was $43 million, down 11% in U.S. dollars, but up 15% in local currency. 
As you probably know, Argentina's average FX rate in 1Q '16 depreciated almost 40% from 1Q '15. Argentina, when combined with the impact on the currency in Uruguay, contributed almost 75% of the negative foreign exchange impact on revenue in Latin America.
Asia Pacific revenue was $28 million, which is comprised mostly of revenue from Veda as well as revenue from NettPositive and our TDX debt management operations in Australia. Our current debt management revenue in Australia is very small. As a reminder, the Veda transaction closed on February 24, with Veda being a part of Equifax for about 40% of the quarter. 
Canada revenue was $28 million, down 10% in U.S. dollars, both flat and local currency. We saw a continuing improvement in Equifax Canada during the second half of 2015, both in terms of revenue growth and, importantly, the pipeline of new products we expect to begin to deliver revenue later in 2016 and 2017. This flat performance in 1Q '16 reflects the relative weakness of the Canadian economy we referenced in our last earnings call. We expect improved performance as we -- as new products ramp later this year.
For the first quarter, International's adjusted EBITDA margin was 25.3% and, as expected, down slightly from 1Q '15. The slight decline reflects the benefit of adding higher-margin Veda as well as improved EBITDA margin performance in debt management, which was offset by a decline in EBITDA margin in Latin America. This decline in Latin America is due to the substantial weakness of local currencies. A portion of our cost is in U.S. dollars, which does not benefit from the devaluation of the currency. Over the remainder of 2016 in International, we expect to show EBITDA margin growth, reflecting revenue growth in our high-margin countries, coupled with the cost benefit of the regionalization program started last year.
Global Consumer Solutions revenue was $95 million, up 14% on a reported basis and up 16% on a local currency basis. Global Personal Solutions showed growth across all channels, B2C indirect and direct, and the strong growth in the quarter driven by -- principally by B2C and, to a lesser extent, our other channels. For the first quarter, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 30.8%, up 100 basis points from 1Q '15. This reflects strong revenue growth and leverage against GCS support costs.
In the first quarter, general corporate expense of $71.6 million was in line with our expectations and down 9% from last year. Onetime items impacted both 1Q '16 and 1Q '15. As I mentioned earlier, Veda integration expenses impacted corporate expense by just over $12 million in 1Q '16. As you will remember, in 1Q '15, we executed an organizational restructuring, which impacted corporate expense by $23 million. Excluding these items, general corporate expense was approximately $59 million in 1Q '16, an increase of about $4 million or about 8%.
For the second quarter, we expect general corporate expense to be in the range of $55 million to $60 million, including the Veda integration expenses. The adjusted EBITDA margin at 34.2% was down from 34.5% in 2015 and consistent with our expectations for the quarter. The reduction reflects the expected decline in USIS and International that we discussed earlier, partially offset by very strong EBITDA margin performance at both Workforce Solutions and Global Consumer Solutions. We expect to see year-over-year growth in EBITDA margins in each of the second through fourth quarters and continue to expect 2016 EBITDA margins to be up approximately 75 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015.
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the first quarter was 33.5%, which was in line with our expectations. Our adjusted effective tax rate, excluding the tax impact of the Veda transaction integration expenses, was 32.7%. This was consistent with the 33% guidance we have provided. For the remainder of 2016, we expect our effective tax rate to be slightly below this level, approaching 32%.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $40 million. We continue to expect capital expenditures for the year to be at the high end of our long-term range of 5% to 6% of revenue. This reflects expected spending related to the integration of Veda. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $90 million and consistent with our expectations. Operating cash flow was down from 1Q '15 due to working capital movements. We continue to expect strong growth in cash flow year-over-year for 2016.
Total debt in the quarter was $3.08 billion, slightly below our expectations. Yesterday we filed a Form 8-K, with the required Veda financial information as well as a new shelf registration statement, which will give us the flexibility to take advantage of market windows to refinance a portion of the Veda acquisition debt. 
As we indicated last quarter, we will suspend our share repurchases during 2016 and focus our very strong cash flow on debt reduction and returning our leverage to a level consistent with our target leverage. We will, however, continue with acquisitions beyond Veda in 2016, with the goal of delivering 1 to 2 points of additional ongoing revenue growth.
Finally, you'll recall that in our 2016 calendar year guidance, we had indicated that we expect revenue from Veda of USD 220 million to USD 230 million. And that we expected a benefit of Veda to adjusted EPS of $0.10 to $0.15 per share. In addition, when we provided outlook for 1Q '16, we did not include any impact from Veda. As we indicated at that time, once we have completed the initial integration of Veda into our financial statements and had progressed in the transition of Veda to U.S. GAAP accounting, we'll provide an update of these estimates.
Based on the completion of this work to date, we are increasing our full year expectation for EPS accretion to approximately $0.20 per share. Our expectation for revenue in 2016 is now $230 million to $235 million, which reflects improved growth expectations, partially offset by a larger negative impact on revenue recognition from the movement to U.S. GAAP accounting. Veda's performance in 1Q '16 was consistent on a pro rata basis with these expectations. Acquisition amortization in 2016 from the Veda acquisition is expected to be approximately $65 million.
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As I give you guidance for the second quarter and for the balance of the year, just to clarify, that does not assume any additional M&A at this juncture. So it's, obviously, been the full year of Veda in the numbers plus organic growth. And
componenttext:
Thanks, John. As I give you guidance for the second quarter and for the balance of the year, just to clarify, that does not assume any additional M&A at this juncture. So it's, obviously, been the full year of Veda in the numbers plus organic growth. And as John alluded to in his comments, we are expecting to do additional tuck-in M&A this year. That's just not in the guidance I'm about to give you. I want to make sure that was clear.
For the second quarter, we are increasing our outlook for both revenues and adjusted EPS. We now expect revenue, including Veda, to be between $795 million and $805 million, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of 20% to 22%. That's partially offset by 3% of FX headwind. Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.34 and $1.36. That's up 17% to 18% over 2015. Excluding $0.03 per share of negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency organic EPS growth of 19% to 21%.
With our strong first quarter performance and second quarter -- and outlook for the second quarter, we're also increasing our full year outlook for the year. We expect revenue, including the impact of Veda, to be between $3.05 billion to $3.15 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of 17% to 21%. Again, partially offset by 2 to 3 points of FX headwind. This is up from the previous guidance of $3.0 billion to $3.1 billion and will move us nicely above the high end of a multiyear financial model, a 6% to 8% organic growth. And we also, as we mentioned earlier, expect potential additional growth through acquisitions as the pipeline is strong, but not included in that outlook.
Adjusted EPS for the year is expected to be between $5.15 and $5.25, which is up 14% to 17% year-on-year. Excluding approximately $0.12 per share of negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency EPS growth of 17% and 19%. This, too, is up from the $4.95 to $5.05 that we guided to during the fourth quarter earnings call a few months ago. We also continue to expect, as John had mentioned, we expect our adjusted EBITDA margin to continue to expand by approximately 75 basis points for all of 2016.
So with that, operator, I'd like to open up for any questions we may have from our audience.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take your first question from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take your first question from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to first pick on -- I think, if I heard you right, you made some comments around trying to expand Workforce Solutions to other regions and you already had some increase on leads. I was hoping you could elaborate a bit more on that. And what
componenttext: I just wanted to first pick on -- I think, if I heard you right, you made some comments around trying to expand Workforce Solutions to other regions and you already had some increase on leads. I was hoping you could elaborate a bit more on that. And what sort of time line we should expect for sort of your application of the database you have here in those regions?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Manav. It's an important part of our multiyear strategy. We -- as I alluded to in the prepared comments, we have the technology platform exchange that will be moving to different parts of the world. We have strong customer interest. We're going to b
componenttext: Sure, Manav. It's an important part of our multiyear strategy. We -- as I alluded to in the prepared comments, we have the technology platform exchange that will be moving to different parts of the world. We have strong customer interest. We're going to be very focused on the countries in which wed go. That process is already underway in places like Australia, Canada, the U.K. and India, are ones that are moving our weight now. Think of it as a multiyear kind of contributor versus something where we all wake up tomorrow and there's a dramatic change. This is going to be a nice contributor to us. It is not contemplated. We're not talking to our investors and [indiscernible] and others about kind of multiyear financial outlook for EWS. That revenue was not contemplated, so this will be on top of that growth. But I have met with a number of customers internationally, as did Dann, when Dann was in the role, and now as has Rudy. And I can tell you, the interest is very, very high. And we have the unique technology to do -- to satisfy those needs in those parts of the world.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And I guess, it seems like you emphasized the guidance not including any future tuck-ins. Is that -- am I reading that too much into saying that there's probably a pipeline in the near term we should see and maybe which areas we sh
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And I guess, it seems like you emphasized the guidance not including any future tuck-ins. Is that -- am I reading that too much into saying that there's probably a pipeline in the near term we should see and maybe which areas we should expect that in?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our pipeline is good. My whole focus today has been getting Veda integrated properly. The team is focused on that, bringing products to Australia and New Zealand, and they're doing that. But at the same time, we have a strategy. That strategy has res
componenttext: Yes, our pipeline is good. My whole focus today has been getting Veda integrated properly. The team is focused on that, bringing products to Australia and New Zealand, and they're doing that. But at the same time, we have a strategy. That strategy has resulted in a pipeline, and we're moving forward on that. So while it's not in the guidance yet, to be very, very clear, you should expect that we do, do -- that we do a few strategic tuck-ins throughout the balance of the year.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one for me. It sounds like, obviously, there's a lot of internal momentum going on with Equifax. A lot of -- your peers are doing pretty well as well. Is there any -- I guess, could you provide some color on how we should, maybe,
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one for me. It sounds like, obviously, there's a lot of internal momentum going on with Equifax. A lot of -- your peers are doing pretty well as well. Is there any -- I guess, could you provide some color on how we should, maybe, try and understand the high growth rates in terms of x percent coming from just macro tailwinds, the industry tailwinds, versus the remaining coming from just pure internal innovation?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our long-term model is 1 or 2 points of kind of market kind of growth. And as you know, the balance of the growth is what we call initiatives, which are internal organic stuff. I'd say that markets around the world are consistent with that mo
componenttext: Yes, I think our long-term model is 1 or 2 points of kind of market kind of growth. And as you know, the balance of the growth is what we call initiatives, which are internal organic stuff. I'd say that markets around the world are consistent with that model. We're not -- you're seeing some areas of good growth like automotive in the U.S., but I would not say there's anything that's significantly changing the market dynamics of growth beyond the 1 or 2 points we're talking, but -- and I'm talking about 3 years. So it continues to be largely driven by internal initiatives, including NPI, EGI and others.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll hear next from Andre Benjamin from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll hear next from Andre Benjamin from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I sort of want to talk a bit about workforce solutions. Clearly, the growth area has been positively surprising, beating [ph] your own expectations. Could you maybe help us frame kind of what the TAM would look like there over, say, the next 5 years and t
componenttext: I sort of want to talk a bit about workforce solutions. Clearly, the growth area has been positively surprising, beating [ph] your own expectations. Could you maybe help us frame kind of what the TAM would look like there over, say, the next 5 years and then where you would believe you're the most penetrated today versus just getting started?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can continue to talk about the U.S. as being an unbelievable growth story for us not just since we bought it 9 years ago but over the next 10 years. And I'd like to describe it, Andre, as being very early stages of its growth. What I mean by that i
componenttext: Yes, I can continue to talk about the U.S. as being an unbelievable growth story for us not just since we bought it 9 years ago but over the next 10 years. And I'd like to describe it, Andre, as being very early stages of its growth. What I mean by that is we've talked to you and others about our path to 300 million records. We're well on our way to that. That's a huge lever for growth. We talked about further penetrating verticals in the United States, and you've heard John talk about the great growth, broad-based growth in government, collections, auto, card, mortgage. With the penetration levels, were still early and there's many, many years of growth still we have there. Third is the analytics, I alluded to that, John has alluded to that, is growing dramatically year-on-year. It was a good growth driver last year. Thats got a number of years [indiscernible]. And then we're now trying to take that platform and take it to other areas I alluded to, overtime pay, as an example, and IRS and 1094 and 1095. And then lastly is taking The Work Number exchange and technology platform we have and capabilities globally. So when you couple that together, theres so many years of growth left in that business. Yes, is it always going to grow like it was 21%, John (sic) [ Andre ], in the first quarter? No, but we gave you a very robust multiyear growth, and I clearly expect that business for as long as I can see to grow within that range that we've committed to.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the PSOL business, you mentioned you continue to sign more partnerships. How do you think about the sequential growth rate for that business as the partnerships that you signed recently scale and you continue to add new ones? And then I guess
componenttext: And then on the PSOL business, you mentioned you continue to sign more partnerships. How do you think about the sequential growth rate for that business as the partnerships that you signed recently scale and you continue to add new ones? And then I guess based on the list of partners that I'm sure you have, that you can continue to add to your list of partners, how do we think about how sustainable it is to keep growing above kind of the longer-term rate that you've laid out?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I gave you the guidance for this year. It's going to be a very good year for PSOL. They've signed up, as you know, the Credit Karma relationship last year. We've got another very big player that has been publicly announced late last year in LifeLock.
componenttext: Yes, I gave you the guidance for this year. It's going to be a very good year for PSOL. They've signed up, as you know, the Credit Karma relationship last year. We've got another very big player that has been publicly announced late last year in LifeLock. And then we have all these other great indirect partners that these guys are signing up. So I'm very bullish for Global Consumer this year. They'll be at or nicely above their multiyear model. And again, Dan [ph] is doing a great job now of taking that capability, and not just looking at the U.K. and Canada, our 2 international platforms, but looking at other opportunities in other parts of our globe where we can take that Renaissance platform, which I earlier referred to, which is a core platform, and bring it to other markets and grow outside the current footprint.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Brett Huff from Stephens.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the USIS, I think you walked through a little bit about why that revenue growth decelerated. But can you just give us more commentary on sort of that core business here in the U.S., both how you're seeing the macro maybe by vertical or something like t
componenttext: On the USIS, I think you walked through a little bit about why that revenue growth decelerated. But can you just give us more commentary on sort of that core business here in the U.S., both how you're seeing the macro maybe by vertical or something like that and then also kind of what your innovations are really focus on there that's going to maybe reaccelerate that growth at the back half of the year?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I'll jump in and, John, if I miss something, please put an add to it. So one, I'm trying to be very direct in my guidance. When we wrapped up 2015, when I talked about USIS, knowing that 2015 first quarter and really the first couple of months
componenttext: Yes, sure. I'll jump in and, John, if I miss something, please put an add to it. So one, I'm trying to be very direct in my guidance. When we wrapped up 2015, when I talked about USIS, knowing that 2015 first quarter and really the first couple of months of second quarter were very, very, very strong. I mean, the growth rates for mortgages in 2015 over 2014 in USIS in the first quarter was extremely strong double digit. So we knew there was some headwind there. So when I guided for USIS -- when we guided for USIS, right, I said it would be at the low end, if not below the low end of a multiyear range. So it came in exactly where we expected, and it's largely driven by those comps in mortgage. Business remains very healthy. It's got those first 2 quarters of headwind it's going to have to get through. But the great thing is we've got a great balance across the portfolio. Number two is if you think of NPI, it takes a while to gain momentum. And they started building some momentum late last year, May to mid-last year. That momentum is continuing now. So the number of products they have, like the rest of the company, are broad, theyre across many verticals. Obviously, the one we talked about with the investors that will pay big dividends in the second half of the year is the launching of trended data for USIS, and that goes live, as I alluded to, in the third quarter of this year. So automotive continues to be a good market for us in USIS. Everything else I describe as a stable economic environment. And I think John did a great job. When you think of the U.S. business, USIS, we separate 2 entities. We call one EWS; we call the other USIS. If you think about many of the activities that are going on, when you compare ourselves to others in the U.S. marketplace, a fair way to look at it, I think, for you guys is to compare either all of EWS in with USIS or you take the Verification Services and analytics, which is health care, and look at it that way. When you look at it that way, as John said, you're getting double-digit growth. And that's the way we look at the business. We bring all of our products to bear to our customers. And it doesn't matter if it's in analytics for a health care company, if it's a Work Number record or if it's Fraud, Identity management or a credit file. They're all solving problems for customers in the U.S., and that's a strong, healthy double-digit growth.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw great growth in Identity and Fraud all last year and again in the first quarter of this year. Very good growth in Commercial last year and again in the first quarter this year. So as Rick said, very broad based and, not forgetting, at very high EBI
componenttext: We saw great growth in Identity and Fraud all last year and again in the first quarter of this year. Very good growth in Commercial last year and again in the first quarter this year. So as Rick said, very broad based and, not forgetting, at very high EBITDA margins. Last year's EBITDA margins were 51%. Adjusting for legal, almost at that level this year. So very, very strong performance.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And just one other question for me. You gave us sort of the $800 million, I think, of debt from the U.K. that you've been working through. Can you -- any more insight on sort of the ultimate size of that, if you have more line of si
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And just one other question for me. You gave us sort of the $800 million, I think, of debt from the U.K. that you've been working through. Can you -- any more insight on sort of the ultimate size of that, if you have more line of sight to that? And any just broad thoughts on economics to you all and how that revenue model might work as it evolves?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's going well, Brett. So overall, the debt management platform, which, as you guys know by now, was TDX and was this business we call Inffinix, which we bought in Mexico. So we'll combine those capabilities. We're taking up those offerings global.
componenttext: Yes. It's going well, Brett. So overall, the debt management platform, which, as you guys know by now, was TDX and was this business we call Inffinix, which we bought in Mexico. So we'll combine those capabilities. We're taking up those offerings global. And so the growth rate is beyond just the government contract in the U.K., and we're gaining traction around the world. And hopefully, we'll have some nice wins to report later on in the year outside of the traditional footprint. But specific to the government contract, it's ramping up as expected. And as John alluded to and I've alluded to in the past, as that revenue continues to ramp, the international EBITDA margins will continue to expand nicely. So it's on track as expected. It will be a nice as contributor this year to top line and profits.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll just continue to caution people, right, that given it's our first big contract with the U.K. government like this, that in terms of the level of growth rate, we're just going to have to tell you what the growth is going to look like as it occurs
componenttext: And we'll just continue to caution people, right, that given it's our first big contract with the U.K. government like this, that in terms of the level of growth rate, we're just going to have to tell you what the growth is going to look like as it occurs because this is our -- this is the first contract of this size we've had with a government like this.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the Employer Services business. I'm used to thinking about this business as being countercyclical and typically a slower growth business than the verification business at this point in the cycle. Is this because of the contributio
componenttext: Just a quick question on the Employer Services business. I'm used to thinking about this business as being countercyclical and typically a slower growth business than the verification business at this point in the cycle. Is this because of the contribution you're now seeing from Workforce Analytics that you're getting this -- a high 20s growth? Or are there other big drivers that would tend to, let's say, modulate the countercyclicality of that business?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, and there's no doubt about it that the analytics push that we've had is fueling great growth there and will continue to fuel great growth for next couple of years. But it's also a change in mindset. We used to always assume th
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, and there's no doubt about it that the analytics push that we've had is fueling great growth there and will continue to fuel great growth for next couple of years. But it's also a change in mindset. We used to always assume that the important business was there to feed records into the verification side and it would be countercyclical. So when unemployment claims rise, that business would grow and -- as it did in 2009, '10. We changed our views there. We've been investing over the years fairly heavily in platforms and capabilities. We changed the mindset of the leadership team there to think of it as a growth business. So what you're getting is clear growth in analytics but also growth in the core non-analytics businesses within employer. Not at the same rate as analytics, but when you put the 2 together, you get really good growth.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just specific to the first quarter, as we mentioned, right, excluding analytics, the core -- the other businesses grew mid-single digit, which is consistent with our expectations. So great growth from Workforce Analytics. Please do remember, righ
componenttext: Yes. And just specific to the first quarter, as we mentioned, right, excluding analytics, the core -- the other businesses grew mid-single digit, which is consistent with our expectations. So great growth from Workforce Analytics. Please do remember, right? In general, Employer Services is stronger in the first quarter because of Work Opportunity Tax Credits. The revenue there is huge for the front half of the year.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: We'll hear next from Gary Bisbee from RBC Capital Markets.

Is that -- how does the revenue model work for the Workforce Analytics? Is there a separate billing for that so the revenue would then fall off in the second quarter? And should that -- should we think about that as within the year-to-year growth calculation or the seasonality's not going to change a lot?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A part of employer, the general seasonality of their revenue will be higher in the first quarter and second quarter and then lower in the back half specifically because the revenue model, as you -- the revenue is generated based on the level of activity e
componenttext: A part of employer, the general seasonality of their revenue will be higher in the first quarter and second quarter and then lower in the back half specifically because the revenue model, as you -- the revenue is generated based on the level of activity executed, and it's a deferred revenue model, right? So any revenue that -- any work that's done up front prior to delivery of the product had to be put on the balance sheet and then amortized over the period in which the product is delivered. So you end up seeing more revenue during the period of delivery, which is the first half of the year, and less revenue in the back half. Was that the question you were getting to?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: No, it's just bigger. It's just way bigger, right? So the business is growing dramatically, so that dynamic is just bigger in the overall growth rate of the Employer Services segment.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And then the bigger question. So you referenced a second straight year of sharply higher expected revenue from the innovation pipeline. What -- are there are a couple of factors that have led to such robust improvements in the last few years
componenttext: Great, great. And then the bigger question. So you referenced a second straight year of sharply higher expected revenue from the innovation pipeline. What -- are there are a couple of factors that have led to such robust improvements in the last few years? And I guess what are they? I mean, it seems like you've had such strength. I don't know if it's just the culmination of years of focusing on talking about innovation or technologys changed or more places where you're selling multiple services. I mean, what are the key factors that have driven this? I mean, is it sustainable? Or is it -- do you think you've just hit a spot that's great, but then will normalize at some point?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, I think -- if you think about it, one, it's a maturation process, right? We've been in NPI, in the company, I think, since 2006. So as you mature, it just becomes more effective, too. When we launched, as you'll recall, NPI 2.0 maybe 2 years ago, we
componenttext: Gary, I think -- if you think about it, one, it's a maturation process, right? We've been in NPI, in the company, I think, since 2006. So as you mature, it just becomes more effective, too. When we launched, as you'll recall, NPI 2.0 maybe 2 years ago, we kind of revamped the enthusiasm and the approach towards NPI. It was clearly not paying dividends. As you get other -- more business units into the game in a broader way. We've talked that USIS is now ramping up. We've talked about Canada ramping up in NPI. And lastly, you can't ignore the fact that the technology platforms we've invested in that facilitate the ability to build products faster with Cambrian, building platforms like TotalView, which allow our customers to consume multiple products quicker, so the combination -- maturation of NPI 2.0 plus the technology platforms of Cambrian and TotalView that we've invested in are all facilitating an unbelievable strength in innovation around the world.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last one. How much of that also is the vertical expansion? I mean, is that technology and what you just described more important? Or are you, let's say, today versus 2 years ago having a lot more progress?
componenttext: And just one last one. How much of that also is the vertical expansion? I mean, is that technology and what you just described more important? Or are you, let's say, today versus 2 years ago having a lot more progress?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Gary. I'll say, what we ended -- that's a really good question. What we ended up doing when we verticalized the company, as we have done the last 5 or 6 years, is you now have domain expertise in the verticals. You're building spe
componenttext: That's a great question, Gary. I'll say, what we ended -- that's a really good question. What we ended up doing when we verticalized the company, as we have done the last 5 or 6 years, is you now have domain expertise in the verticals. You're building specific products with great insight and knowledge to solve the problems in those verticals, and we couldn't do that before. So there's no doubt that having domain expertise in verticals facilitates greater knowledge and hence faster or more NPI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Tim McHugh from William Blair & Company.

componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked. But just quickly, I guess the ACA-related revenue, after this first year push, is it -- how optimistic are you about being able to continue to grow, I guess, on top of that or is this kind of a onetime step-up as you look at it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Tim, it's not a onetime step-up. It's -- and I've tried to give you some texture around that in my prepared comments, but it has had great growth this year. We're going to continue to expand the capabilities. I talked about 1094 and 1095 with the IRS.
componenttext: No, Tim, it's not a onetime step-up. It's -- and I've tried to give you some texture around that in my prepared comments, but it has had great growth this year. We're going to continue to expand the capabilities. I talked about 1094 and 1095 with the IRS. I've talked about bringing the platform to overtime pay compliance. We talked about bringing, once we get The Work Number up and running internationally, bringing the analyst platform of -- we built for ACA in other parts of the world. So no, it's an integral part of our growth strategy for EWS globally.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the customer base that we can apply the core ACA capability to is broader than we currently want. So there's more customers just within the core application.
componenttext: And the customer base that we can apply the core ACA capability to is broader than we currently want. So there's more customers just within the core application.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you at this point with -- I know there was -- a number of companies who have provided ACA solutions were basically rushing to try and get fully implemented with all their clients in time. Were you able to do that? Or is there still even a ba
componenttext: Okay. And are you at this point with -- I know there was -- a number of companies who have provided ACA solutions were basically rushing to try and get fully implemented with all their clients in time. Were you able to do that? Or is there still even a backlog of clients you haven't -- I guess, weren't fully implemented with that will continue to counteract the growth as well?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's no doubt there are other players in the marketplace. We think we have the unique value proposition versus many of them. But there are some good competitors. Number two is the pipeline continues to grow. Number three is when the fines start to
componenttext: Yes, there's no doubt there are other players in the marketplace. We think we have the unique value proposition versus many of them. But there are some good competitors. Number two is the pipeline continues to grow. Number three is when the fines start to be levied to these companies later on this year, it actually creates an awareness and concern that can facilitate even a stronger pipeline as we exit this year and go into 2018.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Toni Kaplan from Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: You mentioned that the Veda integration is on track. Just trying to think about how would you expect the opportunity of building out the products in Australia will take like basically cross-selling some of your products that you have in other regions? I imagine it might be a multiyear endeavor. So just how should we think about sort of the incremental growth in the outer years?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Toni, we think about the company as being a very well-run company, an established company, a company that's respected in the regions in which they play. So buying really good assets has got a good growth. We've already given you a kind of multiyear m
componenttext: Yes, Toni, we think about the company as being a very well-run company, an established company, a company that's respected in the regions in which they play. So buying really good assets has got a good growth. We've already given you a kind of multiyear model for that, which is at or above our multiyear organic growth model. Two, there will be some M&A opportunities when we get to know that part of the world better, which will add to the growth. Number three is bringing products like our fraud products, Cambrian, TotalView, InterConnect and others, Work Number, PSOL to Australia will help growth. Right now it's all about making sure we keep those assets focused on customers, get the back room integrated properly, building multiyear plan. I think the big bang on the transfer of products and knowledge that allow to be a very thoughtful transfer of those capabilities over many years to continue to grow that business nicely.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's evolving as we expected and communicated in the past. That is, there'll be a world of free and there'll be a world pay. And those 2 will coexist together. I think long term, the growth is -- will be greater in the free, which means that
componenttext: Yes, I think it's evolving as we expected and communicated in the past. That is, there'll be a world of free and there'll be a world pay. And those 2 will coexist together. I think long term, the growth is -- will be greater in the free, which means that the paid model around the world would be slower growth but still viable, still profitable, still growing.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, EWS clearly. My god, that is -- I dont know how else to describe it other than it has many, many, many years of very solid top line and bottom line growth. And we talked about it getting up to 50% EBITDA margins over some time and high growth that
componenttext: Yes, EWS clearly. My god, that is -- I dont know how else to describe it other than it has many, many, many years of very solid top line and bottom line growth. And we talked about it getting up to 50% EBITDA margins over some time and high growth that is just unbelievable. Number two, there was growth level I love. And Gary asked about it, but it's NPI. And it's refreshing as NPI. Combination of maturation and the technology bodes very well for the next 5 years. Number three, EGI, and we're really clicking. Andy and his team are an enterprise, growth initiatives, large, complicated, multi-business and multi-country growth objectives, and that's got a lot of growth left in it. I'm really, over multiple years, very optimistic about taking the Veda platform and growing it with Work Number going global. I think it gives -- as I said before about the company, it will give us access to other parts of that world with great scale. We already have great scale. We have people in that part of the region. So we'll do some acquisitions there. Trended data is going to be important to us not just for Fannie. We've been doing a lot of analytics around KS lists [ph] we're getting by different verticals. So I think that bodes well for us. And then maybe lastly is continue to look at different geographies around the world we want to expand, so...

componenttext: Okay. And if I may on trended data. You've got a lot of really nicely differentiated solutions. componenttext: Yes, I think so because our assets are different. If you talk about the ability to trend a utility database, who else can do that? If you talk about the ability to trend income data -- so is the solutions we're providing for Fannie different than what TU is doing today? No, it's largely the same. But the future is trending far beyond just Credit File, and that's why I think we're uniquely positioned.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, sure, thank you. Good questions, Judah. So one is, we are -- we bought a company a number of years ago, TrustedID, and it takes a while to ramp up the indirect business. We've done that now nicely. It took a while to get some momentum. Number two is, were partnering with some pretty good partners who are, after spending a lot of money, trying to advertise their product to the consumer. And obviously, that builds over time. And as they gain traction, we gain traction. So it's a combination of multiple factors kind of coming together at one time.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, can you just walk through again the reason why the International margins were low? How much of the year-over-year difference was due to the currency impact by having your expenses in the U.S. but the revenue in other currencies? And how much were fr
componenttext: John, can you just walk through again the reason why the International margins were low? How much of the year-over-year difference was due to the currency impact by having your expenses in the U.S. but the revenue in other currencies? And how much were from some of the other things?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we didn't give the exact numbers, right? But effectively, the drivers were -- our biggest driver was Latin -- in terms of reduction was Latin America. So Latin America because of this really substantial devaluation of currencies, which is much lar
componenttext: Yes, so we didn't give the exact numbers, right? But effectively, the drivers were -- our biggest driver was Latin -- in terms of reduction was Latin America. So Latin America because of this really substantial devaluation of currencies, which is much larger than we've seen in the last several years. We saw a margin impact there. It was planned. It was expected to occur. And that is specifically related to the fact that we do have non-local currency expenses and all-local currency revenues so that the margins just don't benefit on both the top and bottom line in the same way. Our Canada margins were slightly down as well because you saw our Canada revenue was flat on a local currency basis, expenses were up slightly. So yes, Canada margin down slightly. But the big driver was Latin America. And the positive side in terms of International margins that partially offset those declines were obviously the adding of Veda because they have very good EBITDA margins. And then also, as Rick mentioned during his prepared comments and after, debt management grew and performed better. We took out some costs and we thought some better performance in overall margins in debt management. So that -- those were the drivers of why you saw basically flat EBITDA margins in International.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so the growth that you're expecting in the EBITDA margins through the rest of the year is a -- basically a revenue leverage item? Is that the way we should think of it?
componenttext: Okay. And so the growth that you're expecting in the EBITDA margins through the rest of the year is a -- basically a revenue leverage item? Is that the way we should think of it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we'll get some revenue leverage. We'll also, obviously, get Veda for an entire quarter in the second quarter, where we only had them for 40% of a quarter in the first quarter. And as we said, we're expecting to see some leverage and improved revenue pe
componenttext: So we'll get some revenue leverage. We'll also, obviously, get Veda for an entire quarter in the second quarter, where we only had them for 40% of a quarter in the first quarter. And as we said, we're expecting to see some leverage and improved revenue performance in Canada as we move through the year. We're expecting to see also continued improved performance in Europe as we move through the year. So generally speaking, the continued good revenue performance in International, which we've had for multiple years, we think is going to drive some improved performance in EBITDA margin. As well as, we're expecting cost performance improvements because of the regionalizations we started last year and we've been talking about for the past year.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shlomo, Rick here. Just one other thing. The -- if I could, 5,000 feet on margins. We think of EBITDA margin as 2 points. One, I think you'll agree our EBITDA margin is starting, and this is for the company now, at a very high level, right? I think we're
componenttext: Shlomo, Rick here. Just one other thing. The -- if I could, 5,000 feet on margins. We think of EBITDA margin as 2 points. One, I think you'll agree our EBITDA margin is starting, and this is for the company now, at a very high level, right? I think we're in the top 25% of the S&P 500 or so for EBITDA margin. Secondly, we have committed to approximately 75 basis points on top of what is already a very high margin for the year. We've reaffirmed we're going to deliver that this year. The only way we'll deliver that for the company is if the individual components, including International, continue to improve and increase. So it's important we keep that in context.

componenttext: That's a great question, Shlomo. The answer is yes. And that success -- I gave you some numbers in the past on these calls. And that success is what we'd further enhance very shortly as we build a technology link that makes a transition from ACA into The Work Number database easier for our customers. So that technology link and capability will go live in July of this year. Said another way, it's been a more manual, grinded up population of the ordinary database from ACA clients. It'll be far easier and more seamless for our customers starting in the third quarter.

componenttext: Yes, I feel good about -- that's why we gave it. But at this juncture, I think if we can consistently year in and year out deliver 6% to 8% top line organically, another point or 2 inorganically and give us some capital structure leverage, operating leverage and a nice dividend and give a 13% to 15% return to our shareholders, I think that's a pretty damn good model year in and year out, okay? And you'll find here we'll outperform this, as we did last year, as we tracked it this year. Multiyear, that's pretty darn good model, I think. I hope you agree.
