headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. A
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations. And with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An  archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com in the Investor Relations section under the event Equifax tab. 
During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax's business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including the 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings.
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance. For the second quarter of 2016, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense, as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax, adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain one-time items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with the acquisition of Veda.
These non-GAAP measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with our earnings release and our also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Once again, thank you for joining us for our earnings call. As is normal practice, I will give you some high-level overview on the financials and go to some highlights and the individual business units, come back
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Once again, thank you for joining us for our earnings call. As is normal practice, I will give you some high-level overview on the financials and go to some highlights and the individual business units, come back and give you some insight on the major corporate initiatives, and John will take you through details dis in the financials, and I'll come back with a summary and I will do Q&A.
The second quarter performance continued to reflect outstanding execution across our business units, our verticals and our countries around the world. The team has developed good momentum which will carry us nicely through the remainder of the year and into 2017. Also, our Veda team has continued to deliver a performance that attracted us to the company, and they fully embraced the integration strategy, I'll give you more on that in a moment.
I'm optimistic about the opportunities that the Australia and Southeast Asian business will generate for us not just this year, but into the future.
For the quarter, total revenue was $811 million, up 20% on a reported basis and up 22% on local currency basis from the second quarter of 2015. Organic and constant currency revenue growth accelerated from the first quarter, up very strong at 12%. Also, for the quarter, FX created a $17 million of year-over-year headwind. The adjusted EBITDA margin was 36.6% compared to 35% in the second quarter of 2015, a very solid year-on-year increase.
Adjusted EPS was $1.43, up 24% from $1.15 last year, and better than our expectations when we guided back in April.
I'll now go into some of the individual businesses, starting with USIS. A 3% revenue growth in the quarter, driven largely by mortgage originations, credit marketing activities, commercial information services and our fraud solutions with an adjusted EBITDA margin of over 50%.
Trended data from mortgage industry is expected to go live on September 24. We've been delivering trended data to our customers since April of this year, so they could develop familiarity with the content and better understand the value to their underwriting processes. And we've already signed agreements with 3 of the largest mortgage resellers and we'll start billing for these services in August of this year.
Revenue from our credit marketing services product offerings grew up single digits, driven by double-digit growth in both prescreen and portfolio review offerings. We believe that the majority of these project were focused on new account acquisitions and cross-selling. The growth was also broad-based across all of our major verticals.
The team continues to make very good progress on our commercial information database and solutions. We've been operating under numerous extensions of our agreement with the small business financial exchange. We've been developing an alternative database, which we call the Commercial Financial Network. We currently have over 1,200 institutions providing data for the database, including some of the largest financial institutions. And once again, our commercial business delivered double-digit growth for the quarter.
Our fraud solutions revenue was primarily driven by customer needs to authenticate consumer identity to online access. Growth was broad-based, including financial services, telco, government and our direct-to-consumer resellers.
Year-to-date, new product revenue for USIS is ahead of our expectation, driven mostly by nonmortgage-related products. And as you know, once the NPI pipeline up and running, that bodes well for the next 3 years.
We continued to expect USIS to deliver growth in the full year at the lower end of the long-term range of 5% to 7%. This is the range that we guided to for USIS back in February. EBITDA margins are expected to be above 50% for the year, which is slightly better than we were expecting when we give you guidance during the first quarter earnings call.
And on to international. International delivered outstanding 13% local currency organic revenue growth, as well above the upper end of the long-term range growth model we've talked about, which is 8 -- 10%. This is driven by broad based organic initiatives. Total local currency revenue growth of 62% reflects this strong organic growth and the full quarter of revenues from Veda.
Organic revenue growth in international's 4 largest verticals, which are financial institutions, telcos, government and auto, accelerated to 18% growth in the quarter, up from 13% growth in the first quarter versus first quarter of a year ago.
International platforms, analytical services and debt management services revenue grew a solid 25% in the quarter, up from 19% in the first quarter, so again, accelerating growth sequentially. Our focus on delivering powerful insights continues to open new opportunities to help our customers operate their businesses more efficiently and effectively.
In the U.K., our customer management solutions, including loyal customer, have enhanced our competitive position and enabled us to continue winning share within the financial institutions.
Our U.K. government contract through TDX is performing well and in line with our expectations. Initial collections results and anticipated lift are consistent with our original expectations, and relationships with the departments and the Cabinet office remain very strong. We have also made proposals to other government agencies within the U.K. who are not included in the initial launch.
While still early, we do not expect Brexit to have any material impact on TALX or the U.K. government initiative. 
On to Canada. Canada has made great progress on extending our credit data capabilities into the markets. And the customers interest with both large banks and financial institutions has been very strong. Also in Canada, I think we've alluded to this a bit last call, we have recently landed a multi-year multimillion dollar deal to provide the TDX analytics solutions to one of our largest customers in Canada and that relationship started billing earlier this month.
We are excited about the opportunities in Australia to deliver solid long-term growth for the region. The integration really is going very, very well. To date, there have not been any surprises. The teams in both Australia and New Zealand are embracing the integration initiatives at all levels of their respective organizations. 
During the second quarter, we began the implementation of our global platforms in Australia, those including fraud management analytics, which were Cambrian and CAD technology. These are very important strategic platforms which we have been investing in for many years. These are best-in-class platforms and will provide Veda and our teams down there with tremendous capabilities to develop new products for their markets and customers who used to come. We have also identified a number of opportunities with Veda to both import and export new product ideas from that part of the world to other parts of the world and vice versa. 
Finally, the financial performance to date has met all of our expectations and is on track to beat our full year expectations.
International as a whole will have a very strong year 2016. We expect organic constant currency revenue growth will be above the upper end of the long-term model range of 8% to 10% and total growth for 2016 to be over 40% when you include Veda. EBITDA margins should exit the year comfortably above the second quarter level, which is up nicely, as you know, versus second quarter of a year ago.
On to the Workforce Solutions. They had another outstanding performance in the quarter with a 21% revenue growth and a 480 basis point expansion in their EBITDA margin. We continued to have records on the workforce create valuable insights for our customers. Our success in penetrating key verticals led to strong double-digit growth in auto, consumer finance, government, mortgage, preemployment and cars. Now for the healthcare vertical, which is comprised of our income and verification for CMS and ACA analytics for employers, grew almost 200% in the quarter and continues to look very promising going forward.
Within our suite of compliant center solutions, we've ed develop new series to help employers with the appeal management process under the Affordable Care Act. Employers can avoid penalties if they can prove to CMS that their employees were offered conforming affordable care coverage for those employees who applied and were approved for self-subsidies covered through the ACA exchange. 
During the quarter, we also announced the acquisition of Barnett Associates with EWS. The company we've known for a long time. This company with over 33 years of experience and is a nice tuck-in acquisition for EWS. We expect this acquisition to close during the current quarter.
Workforce Solutions. In summary, we'll have another outstanding year in 2016, with revenue growth substantially above the long-term range of 9% to 11% and adjusted EBITDA margins now in the high 40% range, just an outstanding strain of growth these guys have been on.
On to  -- We were used the word PSOL and our global consumer solutions. They delivered 22% local currency revenue growth, driven largely by our indirect retailer customers and also that solid adjusted EBITDA margins for the quarter. Indirect and resale revenue was up over 70%, primarily driven by our relationships with Credit Karma and Life Lock. Our direct to consumer activities continued to deliver revenue and margin consistent with our expectations. And global consumer solutions will easily exceed their long-term growth target, comfortably delivering strong double-digit growth for the year. The adjusted EBITDA margin for the year is expected to exceed 30%. And when John goes into his discussion, he will about margin in GCS in the second quarter to put some color and texture on that for you.
Back now to the corporate growth initiatives that you've grown familiar with. 
First is EGI, Enterprise Growth Initiatives, which you know we've been out for 7 years now. They're fundamental growth driver to our multi-year levers. This year, we have 8 initiatives in the EGI with very specific metrics and milestones with the management team of use, at least on a monthly basis, every 6 months, we are -- after 6 months, we are projecting the full year revenue from these 8 very important growth initiatives to now come in over 33% above the target we had set at the beginning of the year. That team just continues to execute at very high level.
Cambrian. You've heard us talk about that. It's truly have an amazing impact on how both we and our customers think about the effectiveness of our respective decisioning activities. For customers who are developing tools, they enabling them to increase approval rates while maintaining overall portfolio loss rates. By incorporating more data than just the credit data, we can expand the universe with applicants on which they can render decisions with competence. Both of which improve marketing effectiveness and contribute incrementally to the revenue growth with very modest to no increase in expenses for our customers.
And certainly, for Equifax, we use Cambrian to help us better understand the depth and quality of our data assets. With in Equifax, we can identify opportunities to broaden and enhance our data analysis, as well as specific steps to further improve the quality of our data.
On to NPI. New Product Innovation is also making strong contributions once again to our revenue growth. Through June, revenue from these initiatives is running 10% ahead of our expectations for 2016. You might recall that our expectations for third[ph] year revenue for our 2016 new product launches was already 130% greater than the 2015 launches third year revenue expectations. So we had come into the year with very high expectations when we classify some 2016, and it's already running at least 10% ahead of those expectations. 
International Workforce Solutions and USIS are all exceeding expectations, with the majority of the USIS growth coming from nonmortgage solutions when you think of new products. The pipeline is healthy. And we have a number of new launches scheduled for the second half of the year and expect to that to spur revenue growth in 2017 and beyond.
Our outlook for the mortgage market in the U.S. has changed given the recent trends in the yield on 10-year notes and the resulting strength in the refi activity. Previously, we expected mortgage originations for 2016 to be flat to slightly down. Our current view is that the mortgage originations will be in the range of now flat to up mid single digits for the full year. And that assumes that the 10-year treasury stays in the general range that they are now. Obviously, if they get weaker, that gives us some tailwind. If they rise at fast rate than anticipated, that might create some tailwind or headwind at the back end of the year.
Over the years, our annual growth playbook process has evolved to ensure we maintain an intense focus on the most critical opportunities that drive revenue growth. This year, we've completed, it's hard to believe, our 11th growth playbook. And with a focus on individual enterprisewide, vertical market growth playbooks develop much deeper insights into our opportunities across all of our business units. With these new playbooks, we can better leverage our resources, customer relationships and opportunities to capture incremental revenue growth going forward.
In summary, before I turn it over to John here, our strategic initiatives are at or ahead of what we have expected as we enter the year. My optimism for both 2016 and '17 continues to improve as the year unfolds. 
One comment I want to make, I'll spend a minute on before I give it to John is to put our USIS growth in perspective. A number of you have had an your early read last night, I want to make sure you understand how I think about that. 
We view our enterprisewide vertical market distribution efforts. You've heard us talk about that for a number of years now in the U.S. As a vital to our differentiation and our success in the U.S. marketplace. These vertical markets cut across our U.S. business units, so it's not just credit. So a good way to think about the health of our U.S. credit business is we combine, as we do, our USIS business with our Verification Services business, and as you know, besides in EWS, in our healthcare revenues, also residing in U.S. -- or in EWS. When you think about the enterprise of products we're bringing to the U.S. market, our revenue for the quarter actually grew a very solid 10%, well above the overall growth in our economy. And that's largely driven by, as you know, New Product Innovation, market penetration and insights. 
Let me talk more about that during the Q&A. With that, I'll turn it over to John for the performance summary.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margi
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally be referring to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin to more consistently present the operating performance of the segments and the company as a whole. The non-GAAP reconciliation attached to our earnings release provides a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin.
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the second quarter. 
U.S. Information Solutions revenue Was $308 million, up 3% when compared to the second quarter 2015. Online Information Solutions revenue was $220 million, up 2% when compared to the year ago period. Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 13% in the quarter. The Mortgage Bankers Application Index accelerated late in the quarter coincident with the drop in the 10-year treasury ending the quarter of 20%. Revenue mix shifted significant, in the quarter with almost 60% of USIS mortgage revenue coming through resellers where revenue grew 22%.
Financial Marketing Services revenue was $53 million, up 7% when compared to the year-ago quarter. Our Commercial business continues to grow nicely, up 10% in 2Q and year-to-date. 
Identity and Fraud Solutions also continued to grow strongly, up 20% in 2Q and 25% year-to-date. 
As you recall, in 4Q '15, we realigned our business units, moving revenue with customers that have only direct-to-consumer relationships with Equifax from USIS to Global Consumer. During this realignment, customers with broader relationships with Equifax, including direct-to-consumer, principally other credit reporting agency, were retained by USIS. USIS revenue in 2Q '16 and first half '16 has been negatively impacted by declines in revenues from these retained direct-to-consumer customers by about 2 percentage points. The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions for 2Q '16 was a very strong 50.4% and up from the 50.1% we had in the second quarter of 2015.
Workforce Solutions revenue was $177 million for the quarter, up 21% when compared to the second quarter of 2015. 
Verification Services revenue of $110 million, up 17%, continues to be driven by a strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto, preemployment and card segments. 
Employer Services revenue of $67 million was up 29% from last year. Again, the traditional employer service businesses of unemployment claims, I-9 validations and on boarding performed well, with combined revenue growth consistent with our long-term expectations of mid-single digits. 
Workforce Analytics, which provide services to employers to ensure they are in compliance with the Affordable Care Act, grew several hundred percent in 2Q '16. Seasonally, the first half of the year was the highest revenue for Workforce Analytic. This is the period in which employers are required to provide form 1095-C[ph] to employees, a service that Equifax provides. 
Employer Services revenue in 3Q '16 is expected to grow double digits, but will not be as strong as first half '16, reflecting the seasonal nature of Workforce Analytics revenue.
The Workforce Solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 50.2%, up from 45.4% in 2Q '15. Seasonally, Workforce Solutions has higher adjusted EBITDA margins in the first half, reflecting seasonality in both and Workforce Analytics. The adjusted EBITDA margin for Workforce Solutions in 3Q '16 are expected to be up strongly year-to-year, but down sequentially due to the seasonality.
Revenue from USIS and Workforce Solutions, our total U.S. B2B revenue, was $485 million, representing organic growth exceeding 9%.
International's revenue was $219 million, up over 50% on a reported basis and over 60% on a local currency basis. Constant currency organic revenue growth, which excludes Veda revenue, was nicely above our long-term range of 8% to 10%.
By region, Europe's revenue was $67 million, up 12% in U.S. dollars and 18% in local currency. Given the sharp decline in the British pound following the Brexit vote, we anticipate that 3Q '16 Europe revenue measured in U.S. dollars will be negatively impacted by FX by approximately 10%.
Latin America's revenue was $47 million, down 8% in U.S. dollars, but up 14% in local currency. The depreciation of the Argentinian peso that occurred in Q4 of last year represented almost 75% of the FX impacts in Latin America. 
Asia-Pacific revenue was $72 million, which was comprised mostly of revenue from Veda.
Canada revenue was $32 million, flat in U.S. dollars, but up 5% in local currency. This was a nice growth for Canada and reflects the renewed focus on NPI in Canada we referenced last quarter. 
For the second quarter, International's adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.4%, up nicely from 25.9% in 2Q '15. We saw a nice growth in the adjusted EBITDA margins in Canada and Europe, as well as benefiting from a full quarter's EBITDA contribution from Veda in Asia-Pacific.
Global Consumer Solutions revenue was $107 million, up 21% on a reported basis and 22% on a local currency basis. Growth was driven by our direct to consumer reseller customers. For the second quarter, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 26.4%, down from 30.6% in 2Q '15. During the second quarter, we have program-related revenue and startup expenses associated with the launching of a relationship with a new B2C customer. Both these program revenue and the startup expenses will not continue into 3Q. As a result, revenue growth in 3Q is still expected to be double-digit, but will be below the level generated in 2Q. Also, as a result, adjusted EBITDA margin will improve significantly in the third quarter and for the remainder of the year.
In the second quarter, general corporate expense was $46 million. Excluding Veda integration expense, 2Q '16 general corporate expense was $44 million. 2Q '16 was down from 1Q '16, as in the first quarter, executive equity comp was issued with the bulk of that expense in the period. 2Q '16 corporate expense was lower than expected, as total employee bonuses accrued in the period were as expected, but more the bonuses were incurred in the business units than in corporate. Also, some corporate investments expected to be incurred in 2Q '16 were delayed. With the third and fourth quarters, we expect general corporate expense to be in the range of $50 million to $55 million, reflecting higher levels of corporate investments. 
The adjusted EBITDA margin for Equifax was 36.6%, up from 35% in 2015. The strength in adjusted EBITDA margins in 2Q '16 reflects the very strong adjusted EBITDA margins in Workforce Solutions, International and USIS, as well as lower corporate expenses. We expect that 3Q '16 EBITDA margin to decrease Sequentially, but increase year-to-year at a rate slightly lower than our expectations for full year improvement. We expect our full year 2016 EBITDA margin to be up about 75 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the second quarter was 34%, which was slightly above our expectations due to unfavorable discrete items. Our expectations is that the full year 2016 effective tax rate will be just under 33%, consistent with our guidance at the beginning of the year. In the third quarter, the effective tax rate will be below the full year rate.
Capital expenditures for the quarter were $43 million and year-to-date are $83 million. Capital expenditures for the year are expected to be at approximately 6% of revenue, which is at the high-end of our long-term range, reflecting investments made related to Veda integration. 
Year-to-date, operating cash flow remains strong at $280 million and consistent with our expectations. The slight decline from first half '15 was principally due to changes in working capital.
Total debt in the quarter was $2.95 billion. During the quarter, we issued $775 million of 5 and 10-year notes that refinanced the 364-day credit facility used to finance the acquisition of Veda.
As we indicated last quarter, we have suspended our share repurchase program and we will focus on debt reduction until we return credit metrics to a level consistent with our current credit ratings. We are contending with acquisitions, and in the quarter, announced acquisition of Barnet Associates, as rick referenced earlier. With regards to the Veda acquisition, integration continues to go well, and we continued to expect 2016 revenue from Veda to be $230 million to $235 million, with adjusted EPS accretion from Veda at approximately $0.20 a share.
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. A quick summary before we go to Q&A. It's the guidance looking forward. For the third quarter, we're increasing our outlook for both revenue and adjusted EPS. We now expect revenue to be between $795 million and $805 million, reflecting
componenttext:
Thanks, John. 
A quick summary before we go to Q&A. It's the guidance looking forward. 
For the third quarter, we're increasing our outlook for both revenue and adjusted EPS. We now expect revenue to be between $795 million and $805 million, reflecting constant currency revenue growth between 22% and 24%, which is partially offset by 3 points of FX headwind.
Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.33 and $1.36 for the quarter, which is up 17% to 19%. Excluding $0.03 per share of negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency EPS growth for the third quarter of 19% to 22%.
With our strong second quarter performance and our outlook -- strong outlook for the third quarter, we are also increasing our full year outlook. 
For the full year, we expect revenue to now be between $3.13 billion and $3.16 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of 20% to 22%, partially offset again by 3 points of FX headwind. This is an improvement from the previous guidance we provided you, which was $3.05 billion to $3.15 billion, and increases our confidence that we will end the year nicely above the high end of a multi-year model of 6% to 8% of organic revenue growth.
From a revenue perspective, 2016, I think you'll agree it's shaping up nicely. Constant currency organic revenue growth of 11% in the third quarter -- first quarter, accelerated to 12% in second quarter, and we're holding in the range of 11% to 13% in the second half, that gives 2 years of double-digit constant currency organic revenue growth. This will also, as you might guess, give us good momentum as we go into 2017.
Adjusted EPS for the year is expected to be now between $5.35 and $5.40, which is up 19% to 20%, excluding approximately $0.12 per share for the full year of negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency EPS growth for the year of 22% to 23%. These 2[ph] is up from the $5.15 to $5.25 we guided to during our first quarter earnings call. And as John alluded to, we now expect our EBITDA -- adjusted EBITDA margin to expand by 75 basis points as we have guided you earlier for the full year of 2016.
So with that, operator, we're going to open up to any questions.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

I'm wondering, more broadly, are the lower interest rates we're seeing in the U.S. and globally driving an increase in consumer credit demand more broadly as well? For example, auto, mortgage and other key drivers?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. We're seeing a good strength in the U.S. in auto, in car and in mortgage so. And obviously beyond that, really heavily influenced by interest rates, great strength with in the debt management, and we're talking about the TJX, we got a nice win in Canada that I've just announced. So broadly speaking, the interest rate environment in the U.S. I think is healthy for the U.S. consumer. We're not seeing dramatic changes quarter-to-quarter, David, but just good strength.

componenttext: So 2 great questions. I did not call it out. We are well in path, we could learn to get to a number of 300 million. Total records, we focus on total records. There is so much value in historical, not just the active. And with that -- and with other things that we're used doing, the hit rate across EWS on a Work Number continues to rise really solidly.

componenttext: Understood. And then just a quick final question. It was great to see the 480 basis points of margin expansion, EBITDA margin expansion in Workforce Solutions. How much operating leverage is left in this business over the next 2 to 3 years? And what do you see as a ceiling on margins?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've tried to guide long-term model for EWS, in the 50% range, about 50%[ph] to [indiscernible]  , and I think we'll get there. It is remarkable, Dave, when you done an analysis, when you look at the rate of increase in EBITDA margins over the past
componenttext: Yes. We've tried to guide long-term model for EWS, in the 50% range, about 50%[ph] to [indiscernible]  , and I think we'll get there. It is remarkable, Dave, when you done an analysis, when you look at the rate of increase in EBITDA margins over the past 5 years, that's the beauty of that model that margins were high. And so yes, we expect that to be in the low 50% range moving forward, which is extremely healthy.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just finally, as Workforce Solutions becomes the bigger part of Equifax's total profit pool, how do you think about capital allocation across the businesses over time?
componenttext: And just finally, as Workforce Solutions becomes the bigger part of Equifax's total profit pool, how do you think about capital allocation across the businesses over time?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continued to invest heavily. We're fortunate because our models have the ability to invest significantly in growth businesses. We've grown, we have invested heavily in EWS over the years, core of the structure products, new products, new platforms, and
componenttext: We continued to invest heavily. We're fortunate because our models have the ability to invest significantly in growth businesses. We've grown, we have invested heavily in EWS over the years, core of the structure products, new products, new platforms, and we'll continue to do so. When I think about a kind of long-term horizon, David, for EWS, the next horizon for them which is we're looking at it now is taking into global markets, taking our exchange technology platforms or know-how of our products, that requires capital investment, so we have the wherewithal and the ability to invest in those countries to create the vision we have for EWS, which is a truly global enterprise over the next 10 years.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: This is Greg calling on for Manav. Just I wanted to ask about USIS in bridge to the low end of 5% to 7% for the full year. I think it was about 3% in the first half. So just wondering what's driving the acceleration? I think you've mortgage and the Fannie Mae contract, but any other things we should be thinking about?

componenttext: Right. 2 things, and John, you jump in if you want to add, please. The point is that that John has made in his prepared comments I think is important before I get to the acceleration, if I may. One is if you think in 3% or 3-point something, just 3-point something in the first quarter, 3-point something in the second quarter. As John alluded to, we made the restructuring of our PSOL business, now we call GCS, in the last year, [indiscernible] this year. We left behind some traditional relationships that did the same thing. They sell products, but not to the Credit Karma. We left that behind with USIS. We could easily move that whole thing over to PSOL, then we behind as the shrinking business, as you know. And with that came about 2 points ahead and when you think about the health and the core USIS as business, it actually grew with tough comps year-on-year because of mortgage last year, actually grew when the direct to consumer business over 5% and that baseline. Now when you think of the acceleration going into second half of the year, it's really NPI, and part of the NPI you alluded to was credit data for Fannie Mae, but it's NPI generically and total also then the trended data for Fannie Mae.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. Yes, Barnett is a company we've known for a long, long time, might be 20 years plus. And in his time when he ran his business, Greg, and even before him, established really good relationships with the owners of the company. I got to know
componenttext: Thank you, Greg. Yes, Barnett is a company we've known for a long, long time, might be 20 years plus. And in his time when he ran his business, Greg, and even before him, established really good relationships with the owners of the company. I got to know him over the last 4 or 5 years, they've gotten along well and that's our philosophy posted is to get to know the cultures, the product, the opportunities, so we've done that here. It's a small deal, but it was a nice deal on EWS. They're the largely it fits in nicely, there's good synergies for us there. And as we -- I think I said in my comments, we should close that in August. As far as the pipeline, pipeline continues to be healthy. We did not include any other acquisitions in the guidance that we provided you. We continued to be very thoughtful, so obviously driven by the strategy as we are going to acquire, but we have the capacity, and the pipeline and the ability to do more acquisitions as sure if they make sense.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And Ato Garrett of Deutsche Bank has our next question.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one more question on the auto end market. I know you guys called out some very strong results there. But just given the fact that we're seeing like declining auto sales or decelerating auto sales, I should say, this year, can you go through and say h
componenttext: Just one more question on the auto end market. I know you guys called out some very strong results there. But just given the fact that we're seeing like declining auto sales or decelerating auto sales, I should say, this year, can you go through and say how -- like how dependent is that business on the strong auto sales volume? And how will you be able to get that to strong growth despite those trends?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one, obviously, a growing market helps all, right? And we have been a benefactor if the market itself growing. But having said that, our forecast calls, I don't know the exact numbers, but it largely calls over the next x number of years kind of a mode
componenttext: So one, obviously, a growing market helps all, right? And we have been a benefactor if the market itself growing. But having said that, our forecast calls, I don't know the exact numbers, but it largely calls over the next x number of years kind of a moderation in growth in new and used car deals, and I'm talking to Us in the U.S. So we expected the dramatic uptick from the market that we've seen post global recession to today. Having said that, we are relatively underpenetrated in auto. #2, we have got great new products and we have been launching that help us penetrate the auto market. Within the penetration, a long [indiscernible] still is the use of our work number workers to validate, verify and plugged in income. So that will fuel our auto growth for a number of quarters and years to come.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then also looking at the Global Consumer Solutions, I mean you mentioned that you're getting some strong growth in your indirect channels and that. Can you just give us your comments or your thoughts on some of the long-term agreements that som
componenttext: Great. And then also looking at the Global Consumer Solutions, I mean you mentioned that you're getting some strong growth in your indirect channels and that. Can you just give us your comments or your thoughts on some of the long-term agreements that some of your competitors have signed in that space or some of the transactions that happened in that space in terms of acquisition?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. And when we think of partners out there, it's beyond the Credit Karma -- I'll come back to that. It's beyond Credit Karma. There are 2 very, very nice and important good partners of ours, but we had this business called TrustedID who have got
componenttext: Sure, sure. And when we think of partners out there, it's beyond the Credit Karma -- I'll come back to that. It's beyond Credit Karma. There are 2 very, very nice and important good partners of ours, but we had this business called TrustedID who have got a variety of partners, you've heard us talk about, out of over the years, and those continue to grow nicely. Specific to Credit Karma, yes, as you know, we have a contract with Credit Karma. That contract expires through the end of this year. And as is common practice with any good customer that we deal with. It's in both of our best interest to negotiate those contracts well before exploration, you might guess the team is doing that now. But beyond just that, we're looking at ways to enhance the partnership, add value to Credit Karma. And that value would be through things like insights we provide, the unique data assets that we have and interested partnering with them it makes sense in countries around the world, we've got very strong sizable platforms to help them expand their revenue streams beyond just the U.S. So all of those are being intertwined, as you might guess, in the discussion of a contract negotiation. And we remain very, very confident that we'll get a good expansion on our relationship with Credit Karma.

componenttext: I wanted to ask you about the international margin expansion, a very solid this quarter. Is that just a question of increasing kind of operating leverage as you scale in global markets? Is there mix related kind of impacts? Are there other leverage you can work in order to get the margin going internationally?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start, and John, please jump in. It is consistent with the expectation when we gave a multi-year guidance for margin for international. So first and foremost, no surprises at all. There are a couple of things I think about, and John, you may have a c
componenttext: I'll start, and John, please jump in. It is consistent with the expectation when we gave a multi-year guidance for margin for international. So first and foremost, no surprises at all. There are a couple of things I think about, and John, you may have a couple more on this, that are coming together that aid that margin increase. #1, you may recall sometime in 2015, we announced some restructuring, some regionalization across the international marketplace to get greater scale. That was investment, we're yielding some benefits. #2, we talked about the government contract for debt management analytics in the U.K., heavily burdened with investments in the past, no revenue. You're now getting revenue. And #3 is like our model is just incremental margin, it's nice. As you grow, your margin expense. #4 is as you know, we bought Veda. Veda had margins. When we announced the acquisition, that were accretive to the international margins you now seen that flow through. So I think those 4 things are the vast majority. John, I missed something?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those are biggest areas. We're also globalizing platforms which allow you to reduce your cost more rapidly, yes.
componenttext: Those are biggest areas. We're also globalizing platforms which allow you to reduce your cost more rapidly, yes.

componenttext: That's a great one. So where we deploy these global platforms around the world over the next x number of years, you should continued see some margin enhancement from international.

componenttext: It's small, Ramsey. It's nice for us. At the corporate level, it's very small, and very small this year. We closed in August, we'll have less than half year in revenue. But we've got great plans for synergies and growth as we take that asset under our wings for 2017 and beyond.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Patrick in for Tony. I wanted to ask about Global Consumer growth, which is obviously very robust this quarter, but remains well above the kind of 5% to 8% multi-year organic growth framework you've talked about in the past. Do you have any sense
componenttext: This is Patrick in for Tony. I wanted to ask about Global Consumer growth, which is obviously very robust this quarter, but remains well above the kind of 5% to 8% multi-year organic growth framework you've talked about in the past. Do you have any sense of that market for providing consumers with credit scores and personal finance websites, credit card statements, et cetera, is becoming increasingly saturated?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will become saturated at some point in time. We don't see any signs -- I must talk about the U.S. first. We don't see any signs that there's saturation of that marketplace yet in the U.S. Having said that, you also know that we directly and indirectly
componenttext: It will become saturated at some point in time. We don't see any signs -- I must talk about the U.S. first. We don't see any signs that there's saturation of that marketplace yet in the U.S. Having said that, you also know that we directly and indirectly through partners just alluded in one of the last questions is taking that capability to other markets around the world. So our Global Consumer or GCS business is truly global. So if there is a need and opportunity with our partners will directly to build those pricing capabilities in other parts of the world, we're going to do so.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to ask about potential investments in alternative data. I know you're getting data from telecom and utility companies now, but I wanted to ask about that from an M&A and an OpEx perspective going forward.
componenttext: And then I wanted to ask about potential investments in alternative data. I know you're getting data from telecom and utility companies now, but I wanted to ask about that from an M&A and an OpEx perspective going forward.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have under trade locked leadership, we have got a debt analytics and marketing have a data team, the team's tied back to our strategy. So as you might guess, Patrick, as you look at each country around the world, as you look at every vertical arou
componenttext: Yes. We have under trade locked leadership, we have got a debt analytics and marketing have a data team, the team's tied back to our strategy. So as you might guess, Patrick, as you look at each country around the world, as you look at every vertical around the world, there's a strategy that says, where are we taking our data capabilities, where are the gaps in data capabilities, what's the process to fill those gaps, is it to build it, is it partner, or is it buy, so there is continual focus we have, that granular level of detail around the world.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then lastly, I do want to ask about kind of growth in peer to peer lending in marketplaces over the last number of years, it's a sort of longer-term question. But do you anticipate any impacts from that trend this intermediation on the USIS bus
componenttext: Great. And then lastly, I do want to ask about kind of growth in peer to peer lending in marketplaces over the last number of years, it's a sort of longer-term question. But do you anticipate any impacts from that trend this intermediation on the USIS business over the long term?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I do not. I think, obviously, the whole marketplace is adjusting a bit, because is ahead of them, as you know. They are customers of ours. They buy our credit data, as you know. They buy our plan to data. They buy our income data. They buy some fraud data. So these are good customers of ours. And I don't know, but if I had to make a guess, I think in the future if you think about that, unsecured lending which you call peer to peer lending. It wouldn't surprise me if those become really a part of the banking capabilities as opposed to entities.

componenttext: Yes. Well, just a clarification on the outlook. We didn't change it versus the prior guidance. headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary Anthony for Gary. I guess just thinking longer-term, I think what you mentioned that 2016 NPI is running 10% above planned through June. Any insight into what's driving that? Is it kind of greater market potential that you guys are seeing or
componenttext: This is Gary Anthony for Gary. I guess just thinking longer-term, I think what you mentioned that 2016 NPI is running 10% above planned through June. Any insight into what's driving that? Is it kind of greater market potential that you guys are seeing or penetration or new adjacent market that some of these products can be heavily used by? Or what is driving it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a couple of things, Conner. I think you may recall, I can remember what it was no, but we launched our innovation 2.0 maybe late '14, and that was a catalyst just when we think about innovation, we think about NPI, it also focus on how we bec
componenttext: I think it's a couple of things, Conner. I think you may recall, I can remember what it was no, but we launched our innovation 2.0 maybe late '14, and that was a catalyst just when we think about innovation, we think about NPI, it also focus on how we become better at executing we launched products in time, the revenue is better, was a big focus as well. The other thing is, you can recall, we've launched this capability called Cambrian, which allows us to build products in a fraction of time. It used to take us to build products, modified products to meet customers needs. So the combination of Innovation 2.0, a high level of execution and it's like we do build the launch, we actually get the right sooner and faster. And then the third element is Cambrian. Those 3, you're seeing the maturation of those 3 now result in greater confidence in our revenue outlook for NPI. It's a plan that NPI was the growth coming out of our enterprise growth initiatives which is substantially higher than one we thought and also than last year. So that team is executing at very high level as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And I guess on a similar front, the international organic growth that some of the key vertical you pointed out accelerated pretty strongly there in the second quarter. I guess are there particular markets or within those verticals, particular product that you guys are seeing particular strength or?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The rewarding thing is their aspect is so broad-based. So I think I mentioned a number of verticals. International that sequentially were stronger in the second quarter versus first quarter. And as you brought that down by country, by vertical, you'd see
componenttext: The rewarding thing is their aspect is so broad-based. So I think I mentioned a number of verticals. International that sequentially were stronger in the second quarter versus first quarter. And as you brought that down by country, by vertical, you'd see similar things, so it's not that it is being driven by 1 vertical, 1 country, it's really broad-based countries and verticals. That's marginally due to the fact that the focus we launched a number of years ago become experts in different verticals that were important to our long-term growth. But the resources, the data assets, the technology platforms, the analytics, focus on those verticals to drive growth and we're seeing it as a continued benefit of that focus.

componenttext: I probably tackle that. I'd say the process is the same. NPI is NPI. What we're doing it's a rigorous tollgate process we've been at it now for 10 years that applied us much of there. We are not developing products very explicit in EWS that are detailed products, you don't get the kind of margin enhancements we get in EWS for 400 basis points, which we said was over 50% total EBITDA margin going to BPO products is going a lot fast products. We talked about and I think the last couple of calls this concept with compliance center and the suite of products underneath compliance center that Dan started building out and our usability and take those see ASP products largely, 99[ph] will be an example, ACA will be an example and others. But SaaS margin, as you know, is a great revenue model, how are we incurred in revenue in good incremental margin. So think about that, no differently are you going to think about the facts as you think about new products.

componenttext: I can talk about that for a particular client. But no, I think you know as well that our philosophy is we think about relationships with clients is we try to continue to add unique value and insights, make their business better, that make their revenue stronger, that make their profits stronger. If we can do things by leveraging capabilities we have that are unique to us like the employment data, the income data and fraud data, Cambrian, and I'd mentioned, I think in my comments earlier, helping them get to countries that they want to get to that we are in and we are very significant players as a way to make their business better and stronger, you wrap all those things together as we've done over the years, you tend to move away from price discussion or the value discussion we do the same thing. By the way, they are very, very good customer of ours. I'd say even more than a customer, a partner of ours. And the attitude is along the lines I just described, and that's value creation for both sides.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know Equifax has made kind of strong growth drivers. I do want to ask more about the trended credit data, specifically the Fannie Mae initiative. And how much that might add to Equifax revenues by fourth quarter of this year? Our team calculated about 1
componenttext: I know Equifax has made kind of strong growth drivers. I do want to ask more about the trended credit data, specifically the Fannie Mae initiative. And how much that might add to Equifax revenues by fourth quarter of this year? Our team calculated about 1.2% for that, thinking about the price increases that only to to Fannie Mae loans, but maybe that's too low because I think I understand now these trended data price increases are also go to Freddie loans as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the latter piece and then I'll come to the first piece. What you're saying occurring with the support of Fannie Mae making this a standard for all loans securitized to them, making trend data a standard, when you say emerging as the only
componenttext: Let me start with the latter piece and then I'll come to the first piece. What you're saying occurring with the support of Fannie Mae making this a standard for all loans securitized to them, making trend data a standard, when you say emerging as the only product being offered to the marketplace going forward for mortgage will be a product that has data that has been trended. So it's a result -- so Freddie does not have that technical capabilities yet to consume the trended data. It's our understanding that they're highly interested in doing so. But to be very clear, the product that we're going to offer to the mortgage market in the U.S. is trended product only. When it comes at a different price point than the past. But when as far what is the price point, Andrew? You're pretty smart. You have got ways to think about that and get to a number. I'm not going to disclose that here.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. No, I understand the resellers price increase. But you do admit that when you add it all up, it's over 1 point of additional revenue for Equifax, right?
componenttext: Right. No, I understand the resellers price increase. But you do admit that when you add it all up, it's over 1 point of additional revenue for Equifax, right?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're good, Andrew. We have not -- no -- yes, it will go to all of our resellers and our direct customers as well. We're just not going to disclose -- by the way, and you know this, you've been with us a long time. Where we can add value to a customer, i
componenttext: You're good, Andrew. We have not -- no -- yes, it will go to all of our resellers and our direct customers as well. We're just not going to disclose -- by the way, and you know this, you've been with us a long time. Where we can add value to a customer, in this case, the mortgage market, Fannie, others, make their underlying decisions better, and we can add value from or product, in this case, trended, and charge more from that, we've done it more for years. We're always trying to create value to our customers. And I think you'll be trended data, we know for a fact as the decision mortgages, we had investments and resources behind that, resulted to higher prices. That's more different from what we're doing for 10 years. It just happens that a different product has trended element to it, but we're not going to disclose what that percentage amount is.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Rick, could you remind us where we are in terms of getting ACA clients to contribute more of the employment records to The Work Number database? You mentioned in the past that you're going to start defaulting their -- or is that happening in the contracts and are you actively working on migrating that?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great questions, Shlomo. I think we've talked about this generically. The floor is ready in maybe a quarter or so ago, so think about -- we had to be done, #1, was a technology built that enabled a client when they signed up for ACA to seamlessly t
componenttext: Great, great questions, Shlomo. I think we've talked about this generically. The floor is ready in maybe a quarter or so ago, so think about -- we had to be done, #1, was a technology built that enabled a client when they signed up for ACA to seamlessly the data from the ACA database into The Work Number database. And that work was launched earlier this year, and I believe went live in June, July, guys, you can make that right, June or July, okay, and there's a bunch of out to. So June or July, so it is now out and running today. So then if you set that aside, Shlomo, think about those 2 buckets of customers, they are customers who have already been clients at ACA and there are new guys or companies signing up for ACA. We're going -- the new ones are easy. You sign them up, over to The Work Number database. The teams are not going back to those clients who have previously been customers of ACA and working with them now to port their data from ACA into The Work Number. So yes, we're adding, we have a number of records for at least a month or so to The Work Number database out of ACA.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is this -- are the customers amenable to that? In other words, the old customers or the relatively old customers there are amenable to going back and actively putting in on this platform?
componenttext: Okay. And is this -- are the customers amenable to that? In other words, the old customers or the relatively old customers there are amenable to going back and actively putting in on this platform?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, yes. The answer is yes. It's almost virtually no work required from then as well. So the existing consumers who've been clients of ACA for the last year, yes, are amenable to becoming contributors to The Work Number database. It's the process we put them through make sure we're clearly aware of that population of work number database.

componenttextpreview: So you talked about the importance of your enterprisewide vertical focused distribution strategy. Which verticals do you view as having the most with space, maybe both in the U.S. and also international? And then also, would it make sense to start reporti
componenttext: So you talked about the importance of your enterprisewide vertical focused distribution strategy. Which verticals do you view as having the most with space, maybe both in the U.S. and also international? And then also, would it make sense to start reporting your business based on verticals?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That answer to that last piece first and then I'll go to the first piece. We run the business, we don't run our business by verticals and if this [indiscernible]. We have verticals focuses across the globe, however, which gives us the main expertise and t
componenttext: That answer to that last piece first and then I'll go to the first piece. We run the business, we don't run our business by verticals and if this [indiscernible]. We have verticals focuses across the globe, however, which gives us the main expertise and the ability to invest specifically on products and technologies and most they need. So I don't see a time, Oscar, in the near future whether that means in the next 3 or 4 years where we report and vertical focus. But it does not mean we are not running full speed around verticals. Having said that, where our main verticals, and John, you jump in, that as I think about the next 5 years globally that add a lot of excitement and energy for long-term growth, obviously, fraud, and identity management will be one. Government is another, around the world where there are some really cool things in U.S., as you know, around government. The debt management platform in the U.K. is government. So government is going to be a continued big growth area for us. Healthcare is I think we talked growing almost 200% in the second quarter would be another one. So those are a couple, then there is the traditional ones you always thinking about us, underpenetrated in auto, but growing very nicely the financial services and all the important, words will also be reported.

And as we talked about before, the hope there is that that gives us credibility which is starting to view right now into other arms of the U.K. government to help build more revenue streams than we have today and take our product capability once it's at certain inflection point and bring in other countries as well and help other governments around the world to solve the same problem.
