componenttext: Yes. Like, where you guys have your own kind of subscription-based business that I go up there on the equifax.com and sign myself up per month or something like that.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's flat.
componenttext: It's flat.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Oscar Turner of SunTrust has a question.
componenttext: And Oscar Turner of SunTrust has a question.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you talked about the importance of your enterprise-wide vertical focused distribution strategy. Which verticals do you view as having the most white space, maybe both in the U.S. and then also international? And then also, would it make sense to start
componenttext: So you talked about the importance of your enterprise-wide vertical focused distribution strategy. Which verticals do you view as having the most white space, maybe both in the U.S. and then also international? And then also, would it make sense to start reporting your business based on verticals?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that last piece first, and then I'll go to the first piece. I'm a firm believer that you report the business the way you run the business. We don't run our business today by verticals. We run our business by the 4 BUs. We have verticals focu
componenttext: Let me answer that last piece first, and then I'll go to the first piece. I'm a firm believer that you report the business the way you run the business. We don't run our business today by verticals. We run our business by the 4 BUs. We have verticals focuses across the globe, however, which give us the domain expertise and the ability to invest specifically in products and technologies and address what they need. So I don't see a time, Oscar, in the near future, whatever the heck that means, in the next 3 or 4 years, where we'd report and run as a vertical focus. But it does not mean we are not running full speed around verticals. Having said that, what are the main verticals -- and John, you jump in -- that as I think about the next 5 years, globally, that add a lot of excitement and energy for long-term growth, obviously, fraud prevention and identity management would be one. Government is another. Around the world, we're doing some really cool things, in the U.S., as you know, around government. The debt management analytic platform in the U.K. is government. So government is going to be a continued big growth area for us. Healthcare is, I think, when we talked about growing almost 200% in the second quarter, would be another one. So those are a couple. Then there is the traditional ones you always think about us, we were underpenetrated in auto, but growing nicely. Financial services will always be important. War will always be important.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Commercial is an opportunity.
componenttext: Commercial is an opportunity.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Commercial is an opportunity. We talked about, Oscar, in the early days, if your horizon is like ours, which is what might the next 5 to 10 years look like, bringing our exchange capability and product capability from EWS to select countries around the wo
componenttext: Commercial is an opportunity. We talked about, Oscar, in the early days, if your horizon is like ours, which is what might the next 5 to 10 years look like, bringing our exchange capability and product capability from EWS to select countries around the world and opening up a whole new realm of growth opportunities there would be yet another.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

What's the volume in the database? And also, how should we think about the timing of the revenue growth ramp?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Revenue is coming through nicely. It's on expectations and relationships are fabulous. They have given us, I can't remember how many billions of pounds, but they gave us about GBP 1 billion of debt that we have now analyzed and we are placing. So that's at the expected level when we launched this thing. Almost under any dimension you can think of for managing a complicated project like the U.K. debt management analytics platform is at or ahead of our expectations. So it's really going well. And as we talked about before, the hope there is that gives us credibility, which it's starting to do right now, into other arms of the U.K. government, to help build more revenue streams than we have today and take that product capability, once it's at a certain inflection point, and bring it to other countries as well and help other governments around the world to solve the same problem.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the third quarter 2016 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archiv
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com in the Investor Relations section under the event Equifax tab.
During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including the 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings.
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance.
For the third quarter of 2016, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense, as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax, adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain onetime items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with the acquisition of Veda.
These non-GAAP financial measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with our earnings release and are also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details.
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for for joining us. As I [indiscernible] some high-level observations for the quarter. The corporation some details in the business unit level. John will go through the financial details and I'll c
componenttext:
Yes, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for for joining us. As I [indiscernible] some high-level observations for the quarter. The corporation some details in the business unit level. John will go through the financial details and I'll come back with some closing comments before questions. 
Third quarter was just another outstanding broad-based performance by the team. This really continues to impress me. The growth we had in the third quarter accelerated from the first half of the year and that added to our strong outperformance year-to-date. 
All the 4 business units continue to execute at a very high level, driving impressive expansion at our revenue, adjusted EBITDA margins and the bottom line results. 
For the quarter, total revenue was $804 million, up 20% on a reported basis and up 23% on a local currency basis from the third quarter of last year. 
Organic constant currency revenue growth accelerated from the first half coming in strongly at 13%, up over last year. 
In the quarter, FX created a $19 million year-over-year headwind. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9% compared to 34.6% in the third quarter of 2015, representing a very solid year-on-year increase and well above our annual 25 basis point target increase and the -- well above our 75 basis points expectation we have for the full year of 2016. 
Adjusted EPS was $1.44, up 26% from $1.14 in the third quarter last year and better than our expectations when we gave third quarter guidance back in July of this year. 
So let's jump to the individual BU, as always, I'll start with USIS. They delivered a solid 9% revenue growth, significant acceleration from the first half, driven by broad-based new product revenue, including trended data, and we can talk more about trended data in a second and we'll get it into the Q&A as well. 
Trended data now is a reality. As expected, Fannie Mae launched its desktop underwriter in late September and as we indicated in our second quarter call, billing for trended data began in August for all mortgage-related inquiries. Revenue for the third quarter largely came in as we had expected. 
We have a very good relationship with Fannie Mae, and initiated a discussion on trended data with them nearly 3 years ago. We continue to see opportunities to work with Fannie and transforming the mortgage space, including the announcement just this week of a launch of Fannie's desktop underwriter validation services, which incorporates verified consumer income and employment information from Workforce Solutions. We believe that will be a nice catalyst for continued growth for EWS going forward. 
Additionally, from our data and analytics team, they continue its efforts in -- to completed a variety of analyses to assess the lift from trended data for other decisioning activities. We've talked to you about that in the past. It's really going to granular levels by vertical, by subvertical, by unique data assets and understanding what the lists is. In catalyst, trended data provides approximately a 15% lift in assessing prime accounts for the propensity to open a home equity loan and a 20% lift in assessing prime accounts with default risk on home equity loans. 
With the advent of Cambrian, which you're familiar with, we now have an analytical environment containing over 80 months or more of the historical data across many of our unique data assets. 
Data Cambrian is a nonproduction environment providing unparallel ability to deliver compelling customer insights. But today, we building analytics and insights on trended data is 80 months or more, including the credit file and other unique data assets. In 2017, we're going to move the 24 months of trended data we have for the credit file to significantly beyond the 24 months in the production environment. I think that will open up a whole new realm of opportunities the work of our customers and solve problems that we couldn't solve before. 
Second, with USIS on September 30, we reached a long-term agreement with SBFE to become a certified vendor. We now will be able to combine our CFN, Commercial Financial Network, data assets with SBFE data to deliver best-in-class solutions for small business information customers. 
USIS is expected to deliver revenue growth for the fourth quarter at the high end of the targeted range, which we communicated, it's 5% to 7% and EBITDA margins will continue to be above 50% in the fourth quarter and for the full year. 
International. They continue to make great progress on its most -- on their most important strategic initiative while delivering third quarter local currency revenue growth of 60% and organic local currency revenue growth of 10%. 
In the quarter reported, adjusted -- in the quarter they reported, adjusted EBITDA margins expanded by over 200 basis points from the year prior. Data integration continues to go well and remains on schedule. Some [indiscernible] bullets [indiscernible] we talked before our global platform deployments into Veda, which includes Cambrian and [ph], our fraud platform, are underway and expected to be operational in mid-2017. 
The NPI process has been established, the local leadership team and will be incorporating the Veda NPI revenue into our Vitality Index beginning in 2017. 
We've also identified a number of opportunities to export some of Veda's products to other international geographies. Debt placement from the U.K. government is now up to GBP 1.6 billion and our promotional date is exceeding the baseline performance we had established. 
We now have all 6 founding agencies of the U.K. government boarded and have analytical projects underway with 2 additional agencies. While the initiative is still in the early stages, we're extremely pleased with both our relationship with the U.K. agencies and the financial results we're delivering. 
Organic revenue in international's 5 largest verticals, FI, telco, government, retail and auto. In aggregate, it was up 13% for the quarter. International decisioning platforms, analytical services and debt management services revenue were 19% in the quarter. This high-value -- the high-value solutions continues strengthen our relationships with customers and our market position. 
In the coming quarters, we will easily more sophisticated technology platforms i.e., InterConnect, our platform and Cambrian throughout our international footprint to drive future revenue growth. 
Canada continues to grow very good momentum with trended data. In the third quarter, we launched Cambrian platform, which will further enhance our competitive position with best-in-class solutions, leveraging trended data. 
International is expected to deliver organic constant currency revenue growth in the fourth quarter and the full year, above the upper end of the long-term model of 8% to 10%. 
Reported revenue growth for 2016 is expected to approach 55% and adjusted EBITDA margins should increase sequentially and exit the year approaching 30%. 
Workforce Solutions, a strong moment has resulted in another outstanding performance in the third quarter, with 23% revenue growth and a 350 basis point expansion in the EBITDA -- adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Total records in the Work Number database now approaches our short-term goal of $300 million with over 6,600 different data contributors to that database. Our initiative is to further penetrate key verticals lead to strong double-digit growth in mortgage, auto, government and preemployment, to name a few. 
Revenue from our health care vertical comprised of income and employment verification for CMS and ACA analytics from porters grew over 240% in the quarter. 
In the quarter, Workforce Solutions completed the acquisition of Barnet/VJS, a small regional provider of employment and income verification and unemployment insurance services, to further accelerate the growth of the Work Number database. It's early days, that's going very well. 
As I stated earlier this week, a little more color around Fannie Mae, they announced the integration of our full suite of employment and income verification services into their desktop underwriting platform. The employment and income verification Services includes data from Workforce Solutions that work number database providing instant and waterfall employment and income verification services. 
With these services, our earnings cycle times will be reduced and the lender's reliance on applicant providing W-2, [ph] or other income or documentation will be eliminated, and this gives them protection should they not perform protection from having the banks put the mortgages back to them. So it's a great benefit for EWS. 
Workforce Solutions is having an outstanding year in 2016 both organic and reported revenue growth are expected to exceed 15% in the fourth quarter and 20% for 2016, substantially above the long-term range of 9% to 11%. Adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to be nicely over 45% for the fourth quarter 2016 and high 40s for the full year. Global Consumer Solutions continues their great aggressive on strategic initiatives particularly noting strong market is and in both the DTC reseller and Indirect markets that include partnerships with a number of very successful companies that we've talked about before, such as Credit Karma, Life Lock, H&R Block and others. 
We're pleased to announce we have executed a new longer-term partnership with Credit Karma. The new and expanded partnership is focused on growing both of our businesses by leveraging unique data assets, innovation and analytics, including the use of our Cambrian platform and expanding our partnerships beyond the borders of the U.S. 
This quarter, we deployed our new Global Consumer platform called renaissance, a best-in-class SaaS-based e-commerce platform, which provides much greater marketing facility sort of our partners. During the quarter, we successfully transitioned one of our largest customers to this new platform and by the end of 2017, we will deploy this platform across all portions of our U.S. business and will be well in our way to deploying it across other geographies in which we operate. 
Global Consumer Solutions is expected to deliver fourth quarter and full year 2016 constant currency revenue growth exceeding 15% with fourth quarter and full year adjusted EBITDA margin at approximately 30%. 
A few high-level points at the corporate level before John gets into the financial details. As we're talking about before, this is so important into our culture, now results. First is our enterprise growth initiatives, which are our largest and most complex growth initiatives we have. They're performing very well in 2016, with revenue generation projected to be up over 35% from our expectations earlier this year and over 3x the revenue generated from AGI in 2015. 
Our overall performance in new product innovations, initiatives in 2016 is also outstanding. The 3-year revenue of our 2016 launches is expected to be more than 170% above the expected 3-year revenue on 2015 launches. This is the strongest NPI performance we've had since it was built and created some 10 years ago. 
Our Vitality Index that held last year and the pipeline of new products continues to be very robust. To date, we've launched approximately 40 new products and expect to launch another 20 products before year-end. 
In summary, our strategic initiatives continue to perform well and are ahead of our expectations that we have at the beginning of the year. With this continued focus on improving the process, allows us to drive continuous growth, expect these business will continue to drive and deliver incremental revenue growth in 2017 and beyond. 
So with that, John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin. So w
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin. So we'll consistently present the operating of the segments and the company as a whole. The non-GAAP reconciliation attached to our earnings release provides a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Now let me turn to the business units financial performance for the third quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $317 million, up 9% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. 
Online Information Solutions revenue was $230 million, up 7% when compared to the year-ago period. Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 39% in the quarter. The Mortgage Bankers Application Index growth accelerated significantly, up 35% in the third quarter compared to the 20% growth we saw in the second quarter. 
Given a much stronger mortgage market performance on 3Q '16 and continued accommodated interest rate environment, we now expect the mortgage market to grow solidly double-digit in 2016. 
Financial marketing services revenue was $48 million, up 3% when compared to the year-ago quarter. Our commercial products suite grew 8% in 3Q. We have made great progress building the Equifax commercial financial network, which includes trade line data from banking and other financial institutions similar to BFE, as well as communications and utilities, wholesale trade, printing, publishing and chemicals and other products and rental and leasing data. 
When combined Equifax consumer credit data, we can offer substantially differentiated data analytics to our U.S. commercial customers. 
Identity and Fraud Solutions also continue to grow strongly, up 19% in 3Q and 23% year-to-date. USIS direct-to-consumer revenue principally our revenue with other CRAs was down over 20% in the quarter and largely in line with the first half. 
The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions in 3Q '16 was 50.6%, up from 49.9% in the third quarter of 2015. Workforce Solutions revenue was $171 million for the quarter, up 23% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. Verification Services revenue of $115 million was also up 23% and continues to be driven by strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto and preemployment. 
Employer Services revenue of $57 million was up 23% from last year as well. Revenue growth from unemployment insurance, I-9, tax incentives and other HR services was consistent with annual model of mid-single digit growth. 
ACA analytics revenue was up substantially in the quarter versus 3Q '15, driving much of the growth. As we had indicated previously, ACA analytics revenue was down sequentially and from the first half run rate. As expected, given that the ACA business is seasonal with higher revenue in the first half of the year when 1095 are delivered to employees. 
The Workforce Solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 47%, up from 43.5% in 3Q '15 and in line with our expectations. Revenue from USIS and Workforce Solutions are total U.S. B2B revenue was $489 million, representing organic growth of 13%. 
International's revenue was $214 million, up 47% on a reported basis and 60% on a local currency basis when compared to 3Q '15. Organic constant currency revenue growth was approximately 10%. 
By region, Europe's revenue was $62 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and up 16% in local currency. We have seen some moderate impact on local currency revenue following the Brexit vote, with selected large U.K. financial solutions. 
Debt management grew nicely in the quarter as our relationship with the U.K. government continues to perform as we had expected. The sharp depreciation of the British pound following the Brexit vote in late July significantly impacted U.S. dollar revenue growth in the region for the third quarter. 
The almost 7% decline in the British pound in early October will further impact 4Q '16 U.S. dollar revenue growth. Latin America's revenue was $47 million, down 9% in U.S. dollars but up 9% in local currency. The over 60% depreciation of the Argentinian peso from late December of 2015 through March of '16 has negatively impacted the U.S. dollar performance of our largest and most profitable country in the region. 
Asia Pacific revenue was $74 million, which is comprised mostly of revenue from Veda. Canada revenue was $32 million, up 4% in U.S. dollars and up 3% in local currency. Canada continues to perform in line with our expectations, including substantial improvements and the New Product Innovation initiatives, which includes trended data. 
For the third quarter, international's adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.4%, up nicely from 26.2% in 3Q '15. On a constant currency basis, margins expanded over 300 basis points versus 3Q '15 and almost 50 basis points sequentially. As Rick indicated, 4Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to increase sequentially and approach 30% in 4Q '16. 
Global Consumer Solutions revenue was $101 million, up 12% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis. Growth, again, was driven by our direct-to-consumer reseller customers. For the third quarter, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 30%, in line with our expectations. The adjusted EBITDA margin was down from 30.8% in 3Q '15, but up significantly from the 26.4% in 2Q '16 when we were boarding LifeLock. 
In the third quarter, general corporate expense was $52 million consistent with our expectations. For the fourth quarter, total general corporate expense is expected to be slightly above $55 million. The adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9%, up 130 basis points from 34.6% in 2015. The strength in adjusted EBITDA margins reflect year-over-year growth in USIS, Workforce Solutions and international. 
We expect the fourth [ph] Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margin to be above Q3 adjusted EBITDA margin and our full year 2016 adjusted EBITDA margin to be up more than 100 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015. 
As Rick mentioned before, this is nicely above the target for 2016 of a 75 basis point expansion in our adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter at 29.1% was below the anticipated level of 32.5%, which we communicated during our July earnings call. 
The lower effective tax rate reflects several discrete or onetime items, which benefited our effective tax rate by over 3 percentage points and our adjusted EPS by about $0.05 a share. 
Our current expectation is that Q4 tax rate will be approximately 32.5%. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $48 million and year-to-date are $131 million. We continue to expect capital expenditures for the year to be about 6% of revenue, which is at the high-end of our long-term range as investments are made related to our integration of Veda. 
Year-to-date, operating cash flow remain strong at $525 million. Total debt in the quarter was $2.86 billion. We continue to reduce our leverage following the Veda acquisition, which is now down at 2.58x. Our target is to reduce leverage back to approximately 2.25x EBITDA, which we expect to occur in 2017. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Of course, you agree, 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the companies resulted in broad-based performance significantly exceeded expectations we had at the beginning of the year. We
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Of course, you agree, 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the companies resulted in broad-based performance significantly exceeded expectations we had at the beginning of the year. We firmly this positions us well for growth in 2017. 
For the fourth quarter, at current exchange rates, we expect revenue to be between $797 million and $801 million. The effect in constant currency revenue growth of just over 22%, partially offset by about 2% of FX headwind. This reflects organic growth of over 12%. The almost 7% depreciation in the U.K. pound in early October, which John just referenced, resulted in the majority of the incremental $6 million of FX headwind versus our expectations for the fourth quarter when we gave guidance back in July. 
Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.35 and $1.38, which is up 18% to 21% for the fourth quarter. Excluding $0.03 per share of negative FX, this reflects constant currency adjusted EPS growth of 21% to 24%. 
With this outlook, our second half organic constant currency growth is approximately 12% and in line with the outlook we gave in the second half revenue growth during our second quarter earnings call, which I recall which we guided to 11% to 13%. 
For the year now, we expect revenue to be approximately $3.145 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of approximately 21%, partially offset by 3% of FX headwind. 
Adjusting for the significant depreciation and FX, principally the British pound, this is at the high-end of the guidance we provided in July. This is also impressive performance but it's a more when compared to the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year. For revenue, as you recall, we guided more than $3 billion, $3.1 billion in revenue. 
Adjusted EPS for the year is expected to be between $5.45 and $5.48, which is up 21% to 22%. Excluding approximately $0.14 per share full year negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency of adjusted EPS growth of 24% to 25%. This is up significantly from the guidance we provided you in July and compares favorably to the guidance we gave to the beginning of the year of our adjusted EPS, which you remember was $4.95 to $5.05. 
For the year, we now expect adjusted EBITDA margins to expand by over 100 basis points up from the previous expectations, which were 75 basis points. As we look forward, we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our long-term constant currency financial model of total revenue growth of 7% to 10% per year with organic revenue growth of 6% to 8%. 
As we look to 2017, considering all the acquisitions closed to-date, which to refresh your memory, Veda and the small Barnett acquisition, we expect to achieve revenue growth at the high end of our total growth model. As it's too early to make a call in the U.S. mortgage market, this is the U.S. mortgage market will be largely flat in 2017. And as always, we'll provide you more detail on our outlook 2017 during our February call. 
But at this point in time, with the way the team is executing on the growth initiatives in EGI and NPI, we remain very bullish throughout [indiscernible] 2017. 
So operator, with that, John, I'd like to open up the line for questions.

There growth opportunity, you know our long-term model is very, very bullish, up single digits to low double digits. There are specific projects going on right now, and we continue to find ways to build the hit rate and work on the records. So generally speaking, it is long term, our highest growth opportunity business we have and we remain very bullish.

componenttext: Yes, I expect refinancing to -- assuming they do, with the board that's why we said, in February, we'll give you a better look and hopefully some better insight, that's I'm sure. You're saying rate is from 1 rate increase to 2 to 3 rate increases up to 75 basis points, as low as 25 basis points next year. Historically, low rates. componenttext: Thank you. I think I was trying to find a way around the trended data. I've been very consistent with that. We were [ph] with batch firstly, trended data years few years ago. So clearly, to you and Equifax we are at the literacy if you look at holistically batch and online. However, we have move aggressively and have moved aggressively over the years in all of our geographies to to embrace trended data. I mentioned on the call, we have the most unique data assets, so it's not just the credit file is trended. We talked about it over 80 months of trended data in Cambrian, our analytical environment. And that's many different data assets, not just the credit file. And we're moving, you'll see us move dramatically beyond the 24-month of credit data that trended's in a production environment in 2017, well beyond even 30 months, which I think, is a benchmark out in the marketplace today. So we're not handicapped in any way, in fact, I leading many cents on trended data.

componenttext: First of all, thank you, Manav, for your kind words. NPI is so integrated we do. When you think about it, you're launching 50 to 75 products a year or in this case, 60 products. It's different biogeography. Most of our NPIs you know, tend to be singles and doubles, I've used a baseball analogy. Every once in a while you hit some big ones like trended data. Fraud, obviously, is a very important growth opportunity for us in the international environment. We've talked that moving we call Ostrava around the world that will be a nice contributor. Mobile, we're doing a lot now on the mobile world and finding out pleased to participate in the mobile environment. So we get some great product launches planned later on this year and next year in mobile. Those are 2 examples, I can give you 100 more. But think about it again, as you know us overall, there's a lot of singles and doubles. That's where we're winning NPI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the third quarter 2016 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the third quarter 2016 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archiv
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com in the Investor Relations section under the About Equifax tab tab.
During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including the 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings.
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance.
For the third quarter of 2016, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense, as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax, adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain onetime items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
These non-GAAP financial measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with our earnings release and are also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details.
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us. As I always do, I'll talk some high-level observations for the quarter. For the corporation, we'll get into some details of the business unit level. John will go through the fina
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us. As I always do, I'll talk some high-level observations for the quarter. For the corporation, we'll get into some details of the business unit level. John will go through the financial details. I'll come back with some closing comments before questions. 
Third quarter was just another outstanding broad-based performance by the team. This really continues to impress me. The growth we had in the third quarter accelerated from the first half of the year that added to our strong outperformance year-to-date. 
All our 4 business units continue to execute at a very high level, driving impressive expansion at our revenue, adjusted EBITDA margins and the bottom line results. 
For the quarter, total revenue was $804 million, up 20% on reported basis and up 23% on a local currency basis from the third quarter of last year. 
Organic constant currency revenue growth accelerated from the first half coming in strongly at 13%, up over last year. 
In the quarter, FX created a $19 million year-over-year headwind. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9% compared to 34.6% in the third quarter of 2015, representing a very solid year-on-year increase and well above our annual 25-basis-point target increase and the -- well above our 75-basis-point expectation we have for the full year of 2016. 
Adjusted EPS was $1.44, up 26% from $1.14 in the third quarter last year and better than our expectations when we gave third quarter guidance back in July of this year. 
So let's jump in to the individual BU's. As always, I'll start with USIS. They had delivered a solid 9% revenue growth, significant acceleration from the first half, driven by broad-based new product revenue, including trended data. We can talk more about trended data in a second and we'll get it into the Q&A as well. 
Trended data now is a reality. As expected, Fannie Mae launched its desktop underwriter in late September and as we indicated during our second quarter call, billing for trended data began in August for all mortgage-related inquiries. Revenue for the third quarter largely came in as we had expected. 
We have a very good relationship with Fannie Mae, and initiated a discussion on trended data with them nearly 3 years ago. We continue to see opportunities to work with Fannie in transforming the mortgage space, including the announcement just this week of a launch of Fannie's desktop underwriter validation services, which incorporates verified consumer income and employment information from Workforce Solutions. We believe that will be a nice catalyst for continued revenue growth for EWS going forward. 
Additionally, from our data and analytics team, they continue its efforts in -- to completed a variety of analyses to assess the lift from trended data for other decisioning activities. We've talked to you about that in the past. It's really getting on the granular levels by vertical, by subvertical, by unique data assets and understanding what the lifts is. In catalyst, trended data provides approximately a 15% lift in assessing prime accounts for the propensity to open a home equity loan and a 20% lift in assessing prime accounts with default risk on home equity loans. 
With the advent of Cambrian, which you're familiar with, we now have an analytical environment containing over 80 months or more of the historical data across many of our unique data assets. 
Data Cambrian is a nonproduction environment providing unparallel ability to deliver compelling customer insights. But today, we're onto building analytics and insights on trended data is 80 months or more, including the credit file and other unique data assets. In 2017, we're going to move the 24 months of trended data we have for the credit file to significantly beyond the 24 months in the production environment. I think that will open up a whole new realm of opportunities to work with our customers and solve problems that we couldn't solve before. 
Second, with USIS on September 30, we reached a long-term agreement with SBFE to become a certified vendor. We now will be able to combine our CFN, Commercial Financial Network data assets with SBFE data to deliver best-in-class solutions for small business information customers. 
USIS is expected to deliver revenue growth for the fourth quarter at the high-end of the targeted range, which we communicated, it's 5% to 7%. And EBITDA margins will continue to be above 50% in the fourth quarter and for the full year. 
International. They continue to make great progress on its most -- on their most important strategic initiatives while delivering third quarter local currency revenue growth of 60% and organic local currency revenue growth of 10%. 
In the quarter reported, adjusted -- In the quarter, they reported, adjusted EBITDA margins expanded by over 200 basis points from the year prior. Veda integration continues to go well and remains on schedule. Some sub-bullets [ph] under Veda where we talked before our global platform deployments into Veda, which includes Cambrian and  [indiscernible], our fraud platform, are underway and expected to be operational in mid-2017. 
The NPI process has been established with the local leadership team and will be incorporating the Veda NPI revenue into our Vitality Index beginning in 2017. 
We've also identified a number of opportunities to export some of Veda's products to other international geographies. Debt placement from the U.K. government is now up to GBP 1.6 billion. And our performance year-to-date, it's exceeding the baseline performance we had established.  
We now have all 6 founding agencies of the U.K. government boarded and have analytical projects underway with 2 additional agencies. While the initiative is still in the early stages, we're extremely pleased with both our relationship with the U.K. agencies and the financial results we're delivering. 
Organic revenue in international's 5 largest verticals, FI, telco, government, retail and auto. In aggregate, it was up 13% for the quarter. International decisioning platforms, analytical services and debt management services revenue were 19% in the quarter. This high-value -- the high-value solutions continues to strengthen our relationships with customers and our market position. 
In the coming quarters, we will be installing more sophisticated technology platforms i.e., InterConnect, our [indiscernible] platform and Cambrian throughout our international footprint to drive future revenue growth. 
Canada continues to grow very good momentum with trended data. In the third quarter, we launched Cambrian platform, which will further enhance our competitive position with best-in-class solutions, leveraging trended data. 
International is expected to deliver organic constant currency revenue growth in the fourth quarter and the full year, above the upper end of this long-term model of 8% to 10%. 
Reported revenue growth for 2016 is expected to approach 55%.  Adjusted EBITDA margins should increase sequentially and exit the year approaching 30%. 
Workforce Solutions' strong moment has resulted in another outstanding performance in the third quarter, with 23% revenue growth and a 350-basis-point expansion in the EBITDA -- adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Total records in the Work Number database now approaches our short-term goal of $300 million with over 6,600 different data contributors to that database. Our initiatives that further penetrate key verticals, lead a strong double-digit growth in mortgage, auto, government and preemployment, to name a few. 
Revenue from our health care vertical comprised of income and employment verification for CMS and ACA analytics from employers grew over 240% in the quarter. 
In the quarter, Workforce Solutions completed the acquisition of Barnett/VJS, a small regional provider of employment and income verification and unemployment insurance services, to further accelerate the growth of the Work Number database. Early days, that's going very well. 
As I stated earlier this week, a little more color around Fannie Mae, they announced the integration of our full suite of employment and income verification services into their desktop underwriting platform. The employment and income verification services includes data from Workforce Solutions with Work Number database providing instant and waterfall employment and income verification services. 
With these services, our earnings cycle times will be reduced and the lender's reliance on applicant providing W-2, pay stubs or other income or documentations will be eliminated, and this gives them protection since they normally is not performing a protection from having the banks put the mortgages back to them. So it's a great benefit for EWS. 
Workforce Solutions is having an outstanding year in 2016 both organic and reported revenue growth are expected to exceed 15% in the fourth quarter and 20% for 2016, substantially above this long-term range of 9% to 11%. Adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to be nicely over 45% for the fourth quarter 2016 and the high 40s for the full year. Global Consumer Solutions continues to make great progress on strategic initiatives particularly building out a strong market position in both DTC reseller and indirect markets that include partnerships with a number of very successful companies that we've talked about before, such as Credit Karma, LifeLock, H&R Block and others. 
We're pleased to announce we have executed a new longer-term partnership with Credit Karma. The new and expanded partnership is focused on growing both of our businesses by leveraging unique data assets, innovation and analytics, including the use of our Cambrian platform and expanding our partnerships beyond the borders of the U.S. 
This quarter, we deployed our new Global Consumer platform called renaissance, a best-in-class SaaS-based e-commerce platform, which provides much greater marketing flexibility to serve our partners. During the quarter, we successfully transitioned one of our largest customers to this new platform and by the end of 2017, we will deploy this newest platform across all portions of our U.S. business and will be well in our way to deploying it across other geographies in which we operate. 
Global Consumer Solutions is expected to deliver fourth quarter and full year 2016 constant currency revenue growth exceeding 15% with fourth quarter and full year adjusted EBITDA margin at approximately 30%. 
Few high-level points at the corporate level before John gets into the financial details. As we're talking about before, this is so important to our culture and our results. First is our enterprise growth initiatives, which are our largest and most complex growth initiatives we have. They're performing very well in 2016, with revenue generation projected to be up over 35% from our expectations earlier this year and over 3x the revenue generated from EGI in 2015. 
Our overall performance in new product innovations, initiatives in 2016 is also outstanding. The 3-year revenue of our 2016 launches is expected to be more than 170% above the expected 3-year revenue from out 2015 launches. This is the strongest NPI performance we've had since it was built and created some 10 years ago. 
Our Vitality Index that held last year and the pipeline of new products continues to be very robust. To date, we've launched approximately 40 new products and expect to launch another 20 products before year-end. 
In summary, our strategic initiatives continue to perform well and are ahead of our expectations that we have at the beginning of the year. With this continued focus on improving the process, allows us to drive continuous growth. I expect these initiatives will continue to drive and deliver incremental revenue growth in 2017 and beyond. 
So with that, John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin. So w
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin. So we'll consistently present the operating of the segments and the company as a whole. The non-GAAP reconciliation attached to our earnings release provides a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Now, let me turn to the business units financial performance for the third quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $317 million, up 9% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. 
Online Information Solutions revenue was $230 million, up 7% when compared to the year-ago period. Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 39% in the quarter. The Mortgage Bankers Application Index growth accelerated significantly, up 35% in the third quarter compared to the 20% growth we saw in the second quarter. 
Given a much stronger mortgage market performance on 3Q '16 and continued accommodated interest rate environment, we now expect the mortgage market to grow solidly double-digit in 2016. 
Financial marketing services revenue was $48 million, up 3% when compared to the year-ago quarter. Our commercial products suite grew 8% in 3Q. We have made great progress building the Equifax commercial financial network, which includes tradeline data from banking and other financial institutions similar to the SBFE, as well as communications and utilities, wholesale trade, printing, publishing, chemicals and alloy products and rental and leasing data. 
When combined with Equifax consumer credit data, we can now offer substantially differentiated data and analytics to our U.S. commercial customers. 
Identity and Fraud Solutions also continue to grow strongly, up 19% in 3Q and 23% year-to-date. USIS direct-to-consumer revenue, principally our revenue with other CRAs, was down over 20% in the quarter and largely in line with the first half. 
The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions in 3Q '16 was 50.6%, up from 49.9% in the third quarter of 2015. Workforce Solutions revenue was $171 million for the quarter, up 23% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. Verification Services revenue of $115 million was also up 23% and continues to be driven by strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto and preemployment. 
Employer Services revenue of $57 million was up 23% from last year as well. Revenue growth from unemployment insurance, I-9, tax incentives and other HR services was consistent with the annual model of mid-single digit growth. 
ACA analytics revenue was up substantially in the quarter versus 3Q '15, driving much of the growth. As we had indicated previously, ACA analytics revenue was down sequentially and from the first half run rate. As expected, given that the ACA business is seasonal with higher revenue in the first half of the year when 1095s are delivered to employees. 
The Workforce Solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 47%, up from 43.5% in 3Q '15 and in line with our expectations. Revenue from USIS and Workforce Solutions are total U.S. B2B revenue was $489 million, representing organic growth of 13%. 
International's revenue was $214 million, up 47% on a reported basis and 60% on a local currency basis when compared to 3Q '15. Organic constant currency revenue growth was approximately 10%. 
By region, Europe's revenue was $62 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and up 16% in local currency. We have seen some moderate impact on local currency revenue following the Brexit vote, with selected large U.K. financial institutions. 
Debt management grew nicely in the quarter as our relationship with the U.K. government continues to perform as we had expected. The sharp depreciation of the British pound following the Brexit vote in late July significantly impacted U.S. dollar revenue growth in the region for the third quarter. 
The almost 7% decline in the British pound in early October will further impact 4Q '16 U.S. dollar revenue growth. Latin America's revenue was $47 million, down 9% in U.S. dollars but up 9% in local currency. The over 60% depreciation of the Argentinian peso from late December of 2015 through March of '16 has negatively impacted the U.S. dollar performance of our largest and most profitable country in the regions. 
Asia Pacific revenue was $74 million, which is comprised mostly of revenue from Veda. Canada revenue was $32 million, up 4% in U.S. dollars and up 3% in local currency. Canada continues to perform in line with our expectations, including substantial improvements and the New Product Innovation initiatives, which includes trended data. 
For the third quarter, international's adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.4%, up nicely from 26.2% in 3Q '15. On a constant currency basis, margins expanded over 300 basis points versus 3Q '15 and almost 50 basis points sequentially. As Rick indicated, 4Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to increase sequentially and approach 30% in 4Q '16. 
Global Consumer Solutions revenue was $101 million, up 12% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis. Growth, again, was driven by our direct-to-consumer reseller customers. For the third quarter, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 30%, in line with our expectations. The adjusted EBITDA margin was down from 30.8% in 3Q '15, but up significantly from the 26.4% in 2Q '16 when we were boarding LifeLock. 
In the third quarter, general corporate expense was $52 million consistent with our expectations. For the fourth quarter, total general corporate expense is expected to be slightly above $55 million. The adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9%, up 130 basis points from 34.6% in 2015. The strength in adjusted EBITDA margins reflects year-over-year growth in USIS, Workforce Solutions and international. 
We expect the fourth Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margin to be above Q3 adjusted EBITDA margin and our full year 2016 adjusted EBITDA margin to be up more than 100 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015. 
As Rick mentioned before, this is nicely above the target for 2016 of a 75-basis-point expansion in our adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter at 29.1% was below the anticipated level of 32.5%, which we communicated during our July earnings call. 
The lower effective tax rate reflects several discrete or onetime items, which benefited our effective tax rate by over 3 percentage points and our adjusted EPS by about $0.05 a share. 
Our current expectation is that Q4 tax rate will be approximately 32.5%. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $48 million and year-to-date are $131 million. We continue to expect capital expenditures for the year to be about 6% of revenue, which is at the high-end of our long-term range as investments are made related to our integration of Veda. 
Year-to-date, operating cash flow remained strong at $525 million. Total debt in the quarter was $2.86 billion. We continue to reduce our leverage following the Veda acquisition, which is now down at 2.58x. Our target is to reduce leverage back to approximately 2.25x EBITDA, which we expect to occur in 2017. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Of course, you agree, 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the companies resulted in a broad-based performance that significantly exceeded the expectations we had at the beginning of t
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Of course, you agree, 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the companies resulted in a broad-based performance that significantly exceeded the expectations we had at the beginning of the year. We firmly believe this positions us well for growth in 2017. 
For the fourth quarter, at current exchange rates, we expect revenue to be between $797 million and $801 million. The effect in constant currency revenue growth of just over 22%, partially offset by about 2% of FX headwind. This reflects organic growth of over 12%. The almost 7% depreciation in the U.K. pound in early October, which John just referenced, resulted in the majority of the incremental $6 million of FX headwind versus our expectations for the fourth quarter when we gave guidance back in July. 
Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.35 and $1.38, which is up 18% to 21% for the fourth quarter. Excluding $0.03 per share of negative FX, this reflects constant currency adjusted EPS growth of 21% to 24%. 
With this outlook, our second half organic constant currency growth is approximately 12% and in line with the outlook we gave in the second half revenue growth during our second quarter earnings call, which you will recall, which we guided to 11% to 13%. 
For the year now, we expect revenue to be approximately $3.145 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of approximately 21%, partially offset by 3% of FX headwind. 
Adjusting for the significant depreciation and FX, principally the British pound, this is at the high-end of the guidance we provided in July. This is also impressive performance by the team when compared to the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year. For revenue, as you recall, we guided more than $3 billion, $3.1 billion in revenue. 
Adjusted EPS for the year is expected to be between $5.45 and $5.48, which is up 21% to 22%. Excluding approximately $0.14 per share full year with negative impact from FX, this reflects constant currency of adjusted EPS growth of 24% to 25%. This is up significantly from the guidance we provided you in July and compares favorably from the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year for adjusted EPS, which you remember was $4.95 to $5.05. 
For the year, we now expect adjusted EBITDA margins to expand by over 100 basis points up from the previous expectations, which were 75 basis points. As we look forward, we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our long-term constant currency financial model of total revenue growth of 7% to 10% per year with organic revenue growth of 6% to 8%. 
As we look to 2017, considering all of the acquisitions closed to-date, which to refresh your memory were Veda and the small Barnett acquisition, we expect to achieve revenue growth at the high-end of our total growth model. As it's too early to make a call in the U.S. mortgage market, this assumes the the U.S. mortgage market will be largely flat in 2017. And as always, we'll provide you more detail on our outlook for 2017 during our February call. 
But at this point in time, with the way the team is executing on the growth initiatives in EGI and NPI, we remain very bullish throughout this in 2017. 
So operator, with that, John, I'd like to open up for questions for our participants.

componenttext: Yes, I mean historically, to get these specifics. You've heard me talk in the past, David, with the things going on with the growth perspective starting with the -- really again, it's 5, 6 years ago, continuing -- really now are just phenomenal. They're so broad based. If you think about it, the penetration, which is one way to think about hit rate, in each vertical continues to go up. And we continue to expand the size of the database, continue -- analytics on the data. There growth opportunity, you know our long-term model is very, very bullish, up single digits to low double digits. Though there are specific projects going on right now, and we continue to find ways to build the hit rate and work on the records. So generally speaking, it is long term, our highest growth opportunity business we have and we remain very bullish.

componenttext: Yes, as we've talked in the past, this business should -- because of the great leverage we have, much like the core USIS business or pockets of international, you get high incremental margin, especially on the verification side. We're doing great things on the employer side and automation, enhanced margin there. So there's no reason to believe that business over multiple years should not be approaching 50%-plus EBITDA margins.

componenttext: Got it. And then shifting gears to U.S. CIS, mortgage continues to outperform and I got your comment about next year and conservatively expecting flattish mortgage market. How do you think about what the Fed might do in the next couple of months? And how that might impact mortgage, which is benefited from an incredibly positive environment with rates as low as they are?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I expect refinancing to -- assuming they do, they're all with the board. That's why we said, in February, we'll give you a better look. We'll have a -- and hopefully some better insight, that's I'm sure. You're saying rate is from 1 rate increase to
componenttext: Yes, I expect refinancing to -- assuming they do, they're all with the board. That's why we said, in February, we'll give you a better look. We'll have a -- and hopefully some better insight, that's I'm sure. You're saying rate is from 1 rate increase to 2 to 3 rate increases up to 75 basis points, as low as 25 basis points next year. Still historically low rates. You may see some softening in the refinancing but continue to see good strength in home equity and home sales. I think the thing that we got to keep our eye on general terms on mortgage is affordability. So where the pricing -- as pricing go across the country and what affordability index look like, but beyond that said, there are so many great things when we talk about, that the team has done for -- I don't know, it's been and 7, 8, 9, 10 years, which has outperformed the revenue index through penetration and innovation. And we talked about, obviously, trended data for Fannie Mae for USIS. We've talked about the use now of the verification income employment. Those are just 2 small examples, but the important example is how we're trying to grow regardless what the market does.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I was trying to find a way around the trended data. I've been very consistent with that. We were spearing with that. At first, with batch trended data years ago. So clearly, to you, Equifax, we are not the leaders, if you look at it holistically t
componenttext: I think I was trying to find a way around the trended data. I've been very consistent with that. We were spearing with that. At first, with batch trended data years ago. So clearly, to you, Equifax, we are not the leaders, if you look at it holistically through batch and online. However, we have move aggressively and have moved aggressively over the years in all of our geographies to embrace trended data. I mentioned on the call, we have the most unique data assets, so it's not just the credit file that's trended. We talked about it over 80 months of trended data in Cambrian, our analytical environment. And that's many different data assets, not just the credit file. And we're moving. You'll see us move dramatically beyond the 24-month of credit data that's trended in a production environment in 2017, well beyond even 30 months, which I think, is a benchmark out in the marketplace today. So we're not handicapped in any way, in fact, I think we're leading in many senses on trended data.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned 2017 is shaping up to be at the long term of the constant currency revenue growth rate of 7% to 10%. I just want to check my math that, that would be about 2 points of closed acquisition, right? So we're talking 5 to 8 organic? And the secon
componenttext: You mentioned 2017 is shaping up to be at the long term of the constant currency revenue growth rate of 7% to 10%. I just want to check my math that, that would be about 2 points of closed acquisition, right? So we're talking 5 to 8 organic? And the second question is, at that level of revenue growth, will margin expansion pay above the long-term range for 2017?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I'm trying to say, my words to you is -- in total, will be at the upper end of our 7% to 10%. So you can decipher what that means but possibly in the upper end of that range. So the organic growth by default, if you use your math is 2.7% [ph] wi
componenttext: Yes. What I'm trying to say, my words to you is -- in total, will be at the upper end of our 7% to 10%. So you can decipher what that means but possibly in the upper end of that range. So the organic growth by default, if you use your math is 2.7% [ph] within the organic range of 6% to 8%. But we also have very strong pipeline and other M&A things we can be doing, tuck-in acquisitions that makes sense to us and all of our strategic areas and geographies around the world. So we've been very disciplined this year with only the small acquisition of Barnett. You should expect us to be thoughtful in doing strategic M&A on top of that next year. And the margin, our target is to deliver 25 basis points per year of margin expansion over multiple years. So you should continue to expect margin expansion next year in that range.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Firstly, congratulations on another board-based quarter, and I'm sure we'll keep asking you for updates on trended data and the collections contract and so forth. But what I wanted to ask you is after your 16 new products that you are scheduled to launch this year, as we look out into '17 and '18, like what are some of the other products or initiatives we should be focused on outside of just trended data and so forth? It sounded like the fraud platform you said that launches next summer, maybe one of those? I was just hoping you could give us a sneak preview at other stuff we should be looking out for?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, thank you, Manav, for your kind words. NPI is so [indiscernible]. When you think about it, you're launching 50 to 75 products a year, or in this case, 60 products. It's different biogeography. Most of our NPIs you know, tend to be singles an
componenttext: First of all, thank you, Manav, for your kind words. NPI is so [indiscernible]. When you think about it, you're launching 50 to 75 products a year, or in this case, 60 products. It's different biogeography. Most of our NPIs you know, tend to be singles and doubles, I've used a baseball analogy. Every once in a while you hit some big ones like trended data. Fraud, obviously, is a very important growth opportunity for us in the international environment. We've talked about moving, what we call Ostrav  [ph] around the world that will be a nice contributor. Mobile, we're doing a lot now around the mobile world and finding out ways to participate in the mobile environment. So we get some great product launches planned later on this year and next year in mobile. Those are 2 examples, which I can give you 100 more. But think about it again, as you know us overall, there's a lot of singles and doubles. That's where we're winning NPI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair enough. And then just on the Credit Karma contract. So I think in the past, you gave us your revenue contribution from them. I was hoping you could do that. But it does sounds like the contract is much broader than what in the past I thi
componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. And then just on the Credit Karma contract. So I think in the past, you gave us your revenue contribution from them. I was hoping you could do that. But it does sounds like the contract is much broader than what in the past I think, you guys were giving just reports and the scores. I just want to confirm, if I heard that right. And in terms of expanding internationally, when we heard from Credit Karma at The Money 2020 Conference, they mentioned Canada, but is there anything more than that, that you were referring to?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. We don't disclose Credit Karma revenue, but I'll tell you this. It's been a great partnership. It's been a wonderful win-win partnership for 2 years. We've now signed a multiyear contract, much longer term. we utilize our environment in Ca
componenttext: Yes, thank you. We don't disclose Credit Karma revenue, but I'll tell you this. It's been a great partnership. It's been a wonderful win-win partnership for 2 years. We've now signed a multiyear contract, much longer term. we utilize our environment in Cambrian, which is different than the past. It will be focused on innovation, so building products out of Cambrian together. It will focus on our unique data assets, way beyond just the credit file itself. And then as you alluded to, in your closing thoughts here, it will be going global as well and beyond Canada. I'm not going to disclose the specific countries, but there are some countries that they're very interested in, that we have good market positions and capabilities in, good data assets in. And together, we'll both grow business opportunities for us and the consumers in those geographies. It is a really good -- it was a very complicated long process, but the 2 change came to a great win-win for both of us for many years to come.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And just last question from me. You've talked about this active M&A pipeline for some time now. I was hoping if you could just characterize it in terms of the varying sizes of the deal you're looking at? Because I think the one that you guys are rumored to be looking at in Australia seems a little bigger than tuck-in, but I was just curious on if you could give any color to there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you noticed and you noticed for years, if you think about my 11 years here, we've done 3 large deals. We did TALX 9.5, 10 years. We did CSC. We did Veda. And the vast majority of anything else we've done are small tuck-ins, trying to get us t
componenttext: Yes, I think you noticed and you noticed for years, if you think about my 11 years here, we've done 3 large deals. We did TALX 9.5, 10 years. We did CSC. We did Veda. And the vast majority of anything else we've done are small tuck-ins, trying to get us that 1 to 2 points growth per year as your model. You should expect us to be in that range. Looking for small tuck-in acquisitions well aligned with our strategy and deliver 1 to 2 points of economic growth next year. That would be our goal.

componenttext: Great. What are your start off? I'm sure, you're not going to size the impact in the quarter of the trended data mortgage contribution. Should we not expect a little bit of a step-up from the 3Q levels given the full quarter of trended data and then just sort of normal seasonality?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me jump in the first part and John, if you want address margin. And I'll give you general vision on margin. We don't breakout trended data for any specific line item. But George, you should think of it this way, as we set up guidance back in July, in
componenttext: Let me jump in the first part and John, if you want address margin. And I'll give you general vision on margin. We don't breakout trended data for any specific line item. But George, you should think of it this way, as we set up guidance back in July, in the second half of the year and specifically for the third quarter, the trended data contribution for USIS came in largely as expected, almost no -- in fact, no mutual deviation from our expectations. It was performing, as expected. It's fairly predicable for us to model that contribution. As far as margins, you've got -- you have fluctuations month-by-month, quarter-by-quarter. There are mix changes each and every quarter. There are seasonality changes. Mortgage is lower volume in the fourth quarter and other quarter. So you put it altogether, I don't really worry about minor changes by quarter. It's really with the multiyear trends and USIS is starting up with a very, very high margin trending in the right direction.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've seen really nice growth in our margin, obviously, in the third quarter. Good performance in the second quarter. So I'd say our margin performance is accelerating, and you should expect to continue to see very good margin accretion in the fourth
componenttext: And you've seen really nice growth in our margin, obviously, in the third quarter. Good performance in the second quarter. So I'd say our margin performance is accelerating, and you should expect to continue to see very good margin accretion in the fourth quarter. We gave a range of over 50%, but you'll see very nice margin accretion on the fourth quarter as well. And again, consistent -- the company has delivered outstanding performance overall as we said year-to-year. USIS is a contributor to that, and we expect it to continue, and we feel very confident in our long-term model of moving for our 40% in our long-term model.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: No. It's -- I would describe it really as an apples-and-range contract. If you think of the old contract, it was one geography, one basic product. And as we alluded to, it is now multiple geographies, multiple products and innovations. So it is -- it can be a growth driver for Credit Karma. This can be a long-term growth driver for us as well.

componenttext: Here's my first question. Lenders, as we listen to commentary from large banks have been largely talking a lot about plan for the prime consumers. But I was wondering as you continue to rule out deeper analytics, how much your conversation is talking about the ability to use Cambrian, trended data, alternative data to get more comfortable lending to weaker credit consumers? Largely, because I know when you frame trended data, you also talk about the uplift to plan loans, I don't know how, but how looks like for subprime as well?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good questions. The answer is yes. We are and have been actively engaged in leveraging our unique data assets to give the underwriters a more holistic view of risk. I'd like to be as things like leveraging the debt-to-income data we have, not model b
componenttext: Yes, good questions. The answer is yes. We are and have been actively engaged in leveraging our unique data assets to give the underwriters a more holistic view of risk. I'd like to be as things like leveraging the debt-to-income data we have, not model but actual debt income, it can be using our MCE plus database, which gives insight to how consumers will pay off their utility obligations. You have a score. And, in fact, many parts of Latin America where the credit markets relation were leveraging alternative data assets there to help bring people into the credit markets. So that's an active part of our strategy and has been for quite some time and will be going forward.

componenttext: It really depends on the vertical you're looking at and geography you're looking. So there are set of nuances. There's no one generic answer. You can get back about the [indiscernible] the teams, the D&A teams, and I mentioned in my prepared comments, are deeply engaged with our customers around the world looking at ways to make the smarter underwriting decisions, including subprime.

The acceptance from a customers of the things we can help bring to those mortgage has been warmly received. So all in all, it's going very well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
