componenttext: Our next question comes from Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to ask about the breadth of the various factors that are contributing to the EGI and NPI success this year. I mean, obviously trended, as you said, it's sort of an outsized relative to the singles and doubles you've targeted. But if
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to ask about the breadth of the various factors that are contributing to the EGI and NPI success this year. I mean, obviously trended, as you said, it's sort of an outsized relative to the singles and doubles you've targeted. But if you were to look at what you've done without trended, has the momentum been in line with what it's been the last couple of years? Has it picked up? And are there -- just how do we think about the breadth of it?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gary. The trended data, as you recall, went live in August of 2016. And, if you go back, so the EGI financial benefit and the NPI Financial benefit are way, way, way beyond the trended data. I don't recall the exact numbers. But we talked about 2014,
componenttext: Yes, Gary. The trended data, as you recall, went live in August of 2016. And, if you go back, so the EGI financial benefit and the NPI Financial benefit are way, way, way beyond the trended data. I don't recall the exact numbers. But we talked about 2014, 2015 class of products in NPI being some of our stronger classes in quite some time, if not ever. We talked about the full class of products in 2016. It was trended data was one small part of that.  It was up in third year revenue some 170% above 2015. We talked about EGI -- our enterprise growth initiatives, Gary, it ebbs and flows in any 1 year or maybe 8 big initiatives to I think, the highest I remember seeing is 12, 13, 14 initiatives. And in this case, trended data is only one piece of those. And in my prepared comments, I'm talked about that being up some 35%.  I think, it was over our expectations at the beginning of the year. So while  it turns out as important. There is so much more going on in this company around innovation and growth initiatives than just trended data.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about it, every one of the BUs has a substantial EGI contributing. Certainly, you've seen trended in USIS, you've seen ACA and then other tremendous opportunities being delivered in Workforce Solutions. The direct -- the entire direct-to-cons
componenttext: If you think about it, every one of the BUs has a substantial EGI contributing. Certainly, you've seen trended in USIS, you've seen ACA and then other tremendous opportunities being delivered in Workforce Solutions. The direct -- the entire direct-to-consumer initiative that you heard about in GCS, including the rollout of the Renaissance platform, which we've talked about this quarter is a major driver in GCS. And the great success in debt management internationally driving growth also, right? So there's one in every BU, as well as ongoing success in NPI beyond that, which is also substantial. So it's very broad based.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up question. Given how strong and broad the results' momentum has been this year, are there any points this early in the process that you'd point out we should think about as really tough comp areas or anything for next
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up question. Given how strong and broad the results' momentum has been this year, are there any points this early in the process that you'd point out we should think about as really tough comp areas or anything for next year? And I guess trying to think about phasing of the U.K. contract. Do you we see Europe slow towards how you described the longer-term in Employer Services? Is there the ability maybe at least to comment on those 2 to grow on top of such strong growth with ACA this year? And then anything else you can think of.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's macro stuff. You could factor in the macro stuff, but what goes out might create headwinds next year. Interest rates I think, that  [indiscernible]. Mortgage, I think you said the mortgage market, John, was up strong double digits, 20% or so,
componenttext: Yes. There's macro stuff. You could factor in the macro stuff, but what goes out might create headwinds next year. Interest rates I think, that  [indiscernible]. Mortgage, I think you said the mortgage market, John, was up strong double digits, 20% or so, or 30% this year. You should not expect that, and I said that in my comments, mortgage to be up anywhere close to that next year and flattish will be a good number. You'll always have nuances and further challenges that  [indiscernible] and his team have on NPIs. You have ramp up surprise and they may decelerate over some period of time. You got to replace that with a next great product. Again, we've been like that for 11 years now. So that's nothing new. So specifically one part of your question, which is U.K. contract, you should expect that to the ramp in the next year. It went live-- not even a full year this year. We'll have a full year next year. So, you'll expect that to continue to ramp next year. So that was contemplated in the framework that, John and I gave you when we talked about guidance for next year in that upper end of our long-term total growth rate of 7% to 10%.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then we talked about Workforce Solutions and Personal Solutions that are both growing dramatically higher than their long-term model. We said over time, they'll start to move back towards their model still with outstanding growth, still next year grow
componenttext: And then we talked about Workforce Solutions and Personal Solutions that are both growing dramatically higher than their long-term model. We said over time, they'll start to move back towards their model still with outstanding growth, still next year growing incredibly well. But we have indicated they'll start to move back towards their model over time.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ato Garrett with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ato Garrett with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys have pointed out the strength that you've seen within Workforce Solutions coming from your health care or ACA compliance software this year. As we think about going forward, how much runway do we really have left? And as we think about 2017, are
componenttext: You guys have pointed out the strength that you've seen within Workforce Solutions coming from your health care or ACA compliance software this year. As we think about going forward, how much runway do we really have left? And as we think about 2017, are we likely to see the same kind of first half seasonality that we saw this year?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It may go, generic and specific to ACA. Generically, there's a lot of runway left in EWS to grow. There's so many levers they have to grow ACA's one component. But I would expect ACA had this surge of ACA in 2015 and '16. It depends on what happens w
componenttext: Yes. It may go, generic and specific to ACA. Generically, there's a lot of runway left in EWS to grow. There's so many levers they have to grow ACA's one component. But I would expect ACA had this surge of ACA in 2015 and '16. It depends on what happens with fines and the fines because the intention of employers and hence they renewed interest from another surge. Our expectation is ACA tends to modulate a bit going forward after 2 really good years. It doesn't mean it goes negative. It probably will go at the same rate it's grown. I mean, it's 240% in the third quarter. But think about the overall model of EWS, which is strong, strong up a single to low double-digit growth. That should continue for not only '17 but moving on that.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the seasonality of ACA, it's a seasonal business. From revenue recognition, there's more revenue recognized in the first half than the second half, because 1095s are delivered to employees in the first half. And the way revenue recognition
componenttext: And in terms of the seasonality of ACA, it's a seasonal business. From revenue recognition, there's more revenue recognized in the first half than the second half, because 1095s are delivered to employees in the first half. And the way revenue recognition works, you have the require -- you have to record more of the revenue with the delivery of the product of 1095s that you do for the remainder of the year. So that's just accounting in terms of the way that revenue is recognized during the year.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And you mentioned that you now you have EUR 1.6 billion already processed through that debt contract with the U.K. government. And you're looking at onboarding 2 more government agencies. Just -- can you just discuss like what that's going to do yo
componenttext: Great. And you mentioned that you now you have EUR 1.6 billion already processed through that debt contract with the U.K. government. And you're looking at onboarding 2 more government agencies. Just -- can you just discuss like what that's going to do your overall pipeline for the amount of debt that you're going to be placing for the contract and where you are of what's already been secured?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I alluded to the fact that it's early days right now, Ato, on that. And the primary focus right now is making sure we deliver the value proposition that the government expects on that GBP 1.6 billion and that GBP 1.6 billion, if it grows, great. And we're
componenttext: I alluded to the fact that it's early days right now, Ato, on that. And the primary focus right now is making sure we deliver the value proposition that the government expects on that GBP 1.6 billion and that GBP 1.6 billion, if it grows, great. And we're seeing outperformance versus expectation from our perspective and our consumers perspective, which bodes well. If that continues, that creates a halo effect, as other agencies are going to give us some of their data. A lot of breakout, that's the expectation at this time[ph]. When we have more progress on the other agencies we'll be first one to let you know how that's going.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: You do have to remember that HMRS [ph] is the contributor now and they are, by far, the largest source of that, right?

componenttext: Great. componenttext: The $6 million FX headwinds since we give guidance in July, so versus our guidance in July. And specific to the fourth quarter, to be clear. The $6 million is specific to the fourth quarter, not the second half.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Next we have Andrew Jeffrey with SunTrust.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lots of good information on the call, as usual, Rick. I wanted to ask about Veda, just in so for as it seems year-to-date that perhaps it's outperforming the expectations you had when you closed the transaction. Would you just characterize that? And then
componenttext: Lots of good information on the call, as usual, Rick. I wanted to ask about Veda, just in so for as it seems year-to-date that perhaps it's outperforming the expectations you had when you closed the transaction. Would you just characterize that? And then as you think about Cambrian and NPI and enterprise investments in the region next year, what's the sort of ballpark organic revenue growth that we should be thinking about for Veda?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- as you mentioned Cambrian, what largely I'd say, holistically, the Veda is going as expected. And in fact, it's slightly better than expected. We talked about the increased accretion as one measure of our performance. As I mentioned in my comments,
componenttext: The -- as you mentioned Cambrian, what largely I'd say, holistically, the Veda is going as expected. And in fact, it's slightly better than expected. We talked about the increased accretion as one measure of our performance. As I mentioned in my comments,  Ostra[ph] which is our fraud platform in Cambrian, when we roll it out some time mid to late next year. Think about that as being multiyear kind of benefit. It takes a while to ramp that up and gain traction. So I don't see it significantly changing the financial performance of Veda in 2017. Veda, we talked about being organic growth within our range of 6% to 8% over multiple years. Another thing we talked about is that Veda gives us access to a whole new geography. We look over months and years to come using that platform to acquire other strategic assets in the region that makes sense for us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: I guess $22 billion or so. And maybe that's the wrong way to think about the TAM on that contract and if so, gives me the notion?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, they're not modeled as far as I   equate that with yes, the universe of opportunity is GBP 20 billion. Our whole focus now is on the stuff they've given us to date, make sure it's the right quality, right mix of debt and our team is perform
componenttext: Well, clearly, they're not modeled as far as I   equate that with yes, the universe of opportunity is GBP 20 billion. Our whole focus now is on the stuff they've given us to date, make sure it's the right quality, right mix of debt and our team is performing analytics at the right level to provide value. And that's been that case. And I'm a firm believer if you prove value to the customer in this case, the U.K. government, they will continue to find ways to expand all the way at GBP 1.6 billion up and get other agencies to contribute as well. So all of it right now is making sure to deliver on the promise from agencies to the government.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Important to remember that those agencies do collect some of the debt themselves internally.

componenttext: Absolutely.

componenttext: And they have the right to do that within the contract. So at this point, it's not unclear as to what that mix will be overtime.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: So what we're saying is of the GBP 22 billion, they find a piece of it we think that our analytics could add value they place that to us. So as we continue to add value and increase the lift on the collectability, they'll give us more of it -- they'll think about as big as GBP 22 million.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we have Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next we have Bill Warmington with Wells Fargo.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one question for you. On mortgage, mortgage-related revenue, it looked like it was about 18% of total revenue. I just wanted to confirm that first. And then I think, in your comments, you mentioned that you viewed the mortgage market -- your assumption
componenttext: So one question for you. On mortgage, mortgage-related revenue, it looked like it was about 18% of total revenue. I just wanted to confirm that first. And then I think, in your comments, you mentioned that you viewed the mortgage market -- your assumption for 2017 was that the mortgage market was going to be flat. The MBA forecast that came out on Tuesday is projecting the 2017 market down 14% on a dollar basis. So assuming price appreciation on houses of maybe 6%, I guess, to around 20% down in terms of unit volumes. So I guess my question is, is the expectation that the higher revenue per unit on trended data and the Fannie Mae DU validation service is going to be able to, and another products, are going to be able to offset that expected decline in unit volume, is that the rationale?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will, I think -- the mortgage business in the U.S. is important for our customers and is important for us. We told you, seriously, we're in the range of 15% to 20% of our revenue comes from mortgage-related activities. We're clearly still in that range. W
componenttext: Will, I think -- the mortgage business in the U.S. is important for our customers and is important for us. We told you, seriously, we're in the range of 15% to 20% of our revenue comes from mortgage-related activities. We're clearly still in that range. We expect to stay in that range for the balance of the year. If you go back and look historically, at the mortgage banking index and forecast versus actual, it's all over the board. We take a series of economists, including our own economist and analyze different trends and from that make assumptions. We build guidance for it. We're going to historically, that was in the framework. We just gave you a flat next year. We're going to do a lot more come February. Only try to do for you is you know how big mortgage is. You can make your assumptions, what you think mortgage market is going to do. We think at this juncture, a market performing somewhat in that flat range is reasonable. And we've-- the market has been around for a number of years now out on the low side and the high side. We'll know a lot more in February. That's a good starting point for us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair point on the MBA forecast. It's tough.
componenttext: Okay, fair point on the MBA forecast. It's tough.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Next we have Jeff Meuler with Baird.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: How can Verification Services solutions evolve over time? I'm thinking the things like more attributes collected, you'd hit lightly on analytics, maybe better leveraging the historical records. But if you can talk about innovation in that segment specifically and how much of the growth it drives?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's important. So, as I think about it, Jeff, it's continued to add more records to database, it continued to penetrate more and more verticals at a deeper level. And we talked in the past like in automotive, card and others being good penetration.
componenttext: Yes, it's important. So, as I think about it, Jeff, it's continued to add more records to database, it continued to penetrate more and more verticals at a deeper level. And we talked in the past like in automotive, card and others being good penetration. There is a lot of room to go, still a lot of room to go in penetrating the mortgage market. We just talked about launching the verification business on a global basis. It's early days, that's an investment that I can now -- I think pays dividends 3, 4, 5, 10 years down the road as a long-term great growth lever. Analytics will continue to be a big part of what we do as well, so it's really really broad-based.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, there's been a lot of innovation in the way we obtain records and partners, right? So a lot of the investment has been around building out partnerships to get more records faster and also about the technology that we use to allow smaller employers t
componenttext: Also, there's been a lot of innovation in the way we obtain records and partners, right? So a lot of the investment has been around building out partnerships to get more records faster and also about the technology that we use to allow smaller employers to much more easily board their records to Equifax. So that they can get the benefits at a much, much lower cost.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, John, can you just comment on year-to-date free cash flow and the full year expectation?
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, John, can you just comment on year-to-date free cash flow and the full year expectation?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So year-to-date free cash flow we think continues to be very strong. We're expecting to have a very strong fourth quarter. So no -- for the full year, we're expecting our free cash flow to be very, very good and continue to be good as it has been. I
componenttext: Sure. So year-to-date free cash flow we think continues to be very strong. We're expecting to have a very strong fourth quarter. So no -- for the full year, we're expecting our free cash flow to be very, very good and continue to be good as it has been. It's a little below where it was last year, generally because in a year where we have very strong earnings like we had last year, we pay out all of our incentive compensation in the next year. It tends to drive down cash flow in the year following a very strong year. And we've had a little bit weaker working capital before working on to recover. So we're expecting very strong free cash flow again.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Shlomo Rosenbaum with Stifel.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rick, can give a little bit more of an update on Europe. It looks to me if I normalize for the FX headwinds in the quarter, on a sequential basis, the European business seems flat sequentially. I understand that you need a good growth year-over-year. But
componenttext: Rick, can give a little bit more of an update on Europe. It looks to me if I normalize for the FX headwinds in the quarter, on a sequential basis, the European business seems flat sequentially. I understand that you need a good growth year-over-year. But I would of expected that the U.K. government contract would have put in some more growth over there. Can you talk about some of the dynamics that are going on because of Brexit outside of FX in Europe?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I haven't had the numbers committed to memory, maybe John does, but overall, Europe continues to perform year-on-year growth is good. And one of the things we are seeing is that the Brexit has created some uncertainty for the U.K. market. And kind of a pa
componenttext: I haven't had the numbers committed to memory, maybe John does, but overall, Europe continues to perform year-on-year growth is good. And one of the things we are seeing is that the Brexit has created some uncertainty for the U.K. market. And kind of a pause button, if you will, for some of our customers, things are a little slower in their activity than maybe we had expected. But where that goes is hard to say, I mean, it's still a 2 year timeline before the full exit. But overall, I mean, if you think about the U.K., you think about Spain, you think about that universe in which we operate, the team has continued to deliver solid growth results in a very kind of sluggish environment.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the pattern of our revenue sequentially, it's fairly normal with what you'd normally see in Europe. Yes, we're seeing growth in the U.K. government contract. But again, it's not the largest piece of revenue we have in Europe. Obviously, our traditiona
componenttext: And the pattern of our revenue sequentially, it's fairly normal with what you'd normally see in Europe. Yes, we're seeing growth in the U.K. government contract. But again, it's not the largest piece of revenue we have in Europe. Obviously, our traditional business is much larger so we are seeing continued growth, but the pattern of revenue looks very normal to us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Probably, Shlomo, Spain continues to do some amazing things and deliver some great results largely aided by NPI.

componenttext: Okay, that's good color. And then where are we in terms of being able to use the U.K. government as a model for other countries. componenttext: Yes, we just set up global government vertical. componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked. But just one maybe Latin America, I apologize if I missed it. But the growth it's kind of gradually slowed a little bit the last few quarters. headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Argentina is our largest country in the region obviously Argentina's GDP growth is negative this year. So their performance is a little weaker. But now we do think, so we think Latin America continues to be an opportunity for us to grow.
componenttext: Argentina is our largest country in the region obviously Argentina's GDP growth is negative this year. So their performance is a little weaker. But now we do think, so we think Latin America continues to be an opportunity for us to grow.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's one thing that, Tim, that gives me great hope for Latin America. It's a great market for us as you know in general terms, it has been for years. I am more bullish about the outlook for Argentina. What the government is doing locally in Argentina to
componenttext: Here's one thing that, Tim, that gives me great hope for Latin America. It's a great market for us as you know in general terms, it has been for years. I am more bullish about the outlook for Argentina. What the government is doing locally in Argentina to fuel growth and the economists now see that the projections for GDP growth for the outer years are stronger than I've seen in quite some time. The projections for currency stabilization are better than what we have seen some time. I guess Jeff's got some numbers right here. The forecast right now, we have Argentina, as John alluded to us, is negative this year about 1% or so in GDP growth in the next 3 years, the consensus forecast is between 3% to 4% GDP growth through '17, '18 and '19. So we're in good position in Argentina. We're a leader in Argentina in all verticals. And analytics, as well as is the core credit business. So I think better days lie ahead in Argentina when you see that you see an updraft in general terms through Latin America for us.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Can you site -- is there any -- will you be willing to tell us roughly how much Latin America, which you about is coming from Argentina?

componenttext: It is our largest operation in Latin America. We don't size that externally.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's any one lever that on MGI [ph]-- EGI that gives us -- at a business unit level. As I've said for quite some time, EWS, it has got the longest growth potential we have and all of which are during 2017 as well. But the neat thing is th
componenttext: I don't think there's any one lever that on MGI [ph]-- EGI that gives us -- at a business unit level. As I've said for quite some time, EWS, it has got the longest growth potential we have and all of which are during 2017 as well. But the neat thing is the performance spread as you've seen is so broad-based across verticals, countries, BUs, EGI and products. It might will be another big EGI that comes up or another big NPI product that might come up. I think mobile offers some really interesting opportunity for us. I think shredded data beyond just a credit file offers some opportunity for us. Maybe we'll see this underwriter -- the desktop underwriter platform that's incorporating the use of verification income employment that might provide some upside, but it's really not broad-based.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and then my second question is, again, all the bigger pictures. You guys have done a good job of creating or buying proprietary databases that you could kind of use in conjunction with the credit file to differentiate your products. What is the next phase of that? Is there a particular database or type of data that you're looking to build or buy, the next [indiscernible] or the next telco credit filing or anything like that?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: So, what we have in Trey's organization of the data analytics team is a strategy that's linked to each country and then every vertical of the country. So I always tell people, there is no generic answer. It might be in Argentina, in the auto vertical there's a data asset we want to buy and build a partner with. In Australia there might be something different there. So that's a big core part of our strategy. So we don't try to divulge on a forward-looking basis which assets we want to build about. The one we have talked about that you've seen is the Work Number database going global.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day. And welcome to the third quarter 2016 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day. And welcome to the third quarter 2016 earnings call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jeff Dodge. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. Today's call is being recorded. An archiv
componenttext:
Thanks. And good morning. Welcome to today's conference call. I'm Jeff Dodge, Investor Relations, and with me today are Rick Smith, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Gamble, Chief Financial Officer. 
Today's call is being recorded. An archive of the recording will be available later today at www.equifax.com in the Investor Relations section under the About Equifax tab.
During this call, we will be making certain forward-looking statements to help you understand Equifax and its business environment. These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. Certain risk factors inherent in our business are set forth in our filings with the SEC, including the 2015 Form 10-K and all subsequent filings.
During this call, we will be referring to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax and adjusted EBITDA margin, which will be adjusted for certain items that affect the comparability of the underlying operational performance.
For the third quarter of 2016, adjusted EPS attributable to Equifax excludes acquisition-related amortization expense, as well as the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
Adjusted EBITDA margin is defined as net income attributable to Equifax, adding back income tax expense, interest expense net of interest income, depreciation, amortization and the impact of certain onetime items, including the transaction and integration expenses associated with our acquisition of Veda.
These non-GAAP financial measures are detailed in the reconciliation tables, which are included with our earnings release and are also posted on our website. Also, please refer to our investor presentations, which are posted in the Investor Relations section of our website for further details.
Now I'd like to turn it over to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us. As I always do, I'll pull out some high-level observations for the quarter. For the corporation, we'll get into some details of the business unit level. John will go through the
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Thanks, as always, for joining us. As I always do, I'll pull out some high-level observations for the quarter. For the corporation, we'll get into some details of the business unit level. John will go through the financial details. I'll come back with some closing comments before questions. 
Third quarter was just another outstanding broad-based performance by the team. This really continues to impress me. The growth we had in the third quarter accelerated from the first half of the year that added to our strong outperformance year-to-date. 
All our 4 business units continue to execute at a very high level, driving impressive expansion in our revenue, adjusted EBITDA margins and the bottom line results. 
For the quarter, total revenue was $804 million, up 20% on reported basis and up 23% on a local currency basis from the third quarter of last year. 
Organic constant currency revenue growth accelerated from the first half coming in strongly at 13%, up over last year. 
In the quarter, FX created a $19 million year-over-year headwind. Adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9% compared to 34.6% in the third quarter of 2015, representing a very solid year-on-year increase and well above our annual 25-basis-point target increase and the -- well above our 75-basis-point expectation we have for the full year of 2016. 
Adjusted EPS was $1.44, up 26% from $1.14 in the third quarter last year and better than our expectations when we gave third quarter guidance back in July of this year. 
So let me jump in to the individual BU's. As always, I'll start with USIS. They had delivered a solid 9% revenue growth, significant acceleration from the first half, driven by broad-based new product revenue, including trended data. We can talk more about trended data in a second and we'll get into it the Q&A as well. 
Trended data now is a reality. As expected, Fannie Mae launched its desktop underwriter in late September and as we indicated during our second quarter call, billing for trended data began in August for all mortgage-related inquiries. Revenue for the third quarter largely came in as we had expected. 
We have a very good relationship with Fannie Mae, and initiated discussions on trended data with them nearly 3 years ago. We continue to see opportunities to work with Fannie in transforming the mortgage space, including the announcement just this week of a launch of Fannie's desktop underwriter validation services, which incorporates verified consumer income and employment information from Workforce Solutions. We believe that will be a nice catalyst for continued mortgage growth for EWS going forward. 
Additionally, from our data and analytics team, they continue its efforts in -- to completed a variety of analyses to assess the lift from trended data for other decisioning activities. We've talked to you about that in the past. It's really getting on the granular levels by vertical, by subvertical, by unique data assets and understanding what the lifts is. In catalyst, trended data provides approximately a 15% lift in assessing prime accounts for the propensity to open a home equity loan and a 20% lift in assessing prime accounts for default risk on home equity loans. 
With the advent of Cambrian, which you're familiar with, we now have an analytical environment containing over 80 months or more of the historical data across many of our unique data assets. 
Data Cambrian is a nonproduction environment providing unparalleled ability to deliver compelling customer insights. But today, we're onto building analytics and insights on trended data is 80 months or more, including the credit file and other unique data assets. In 2017, we're going to move the 24 months of trended data we have in the credit file to significantly beyond the 24 months in the production environment. I think that will open up a whole new realm of opportunities to work with our customers and solve problems that we couldn't solve before. 
Second, with USIS on September 30, we reached a long-term agreement with SBFE to become a certified vendor. We now will be able to combine our CFN, Commercial Financial Network data assets with SBFE data to deliver best-in-class solutions for small business information customers. 
USIS is expected to deliver revenue growth for the fourth quarter at the high-end of the targeted range, which we communicated as 5% to 7%. And EBITDA margins will continue to be above 50% in the fourth quarter and for the full year. 
International. They continue to make great progress on its most -- on their most important strategic initiatives while delivering third quarter local currency revenue growth of 60% and organic local currency revenue growth of 10%. 
In the quarter reported, adjusted -- In the quarter, they reported, adjusted EBITDA margins expanded by over 200 basis points from the year prior. Veda integration continues to go well and remains on schedule. Some sub-bullets under Veda where we talked before our global platform deployments into Veda, which includes Cambrian and Ostra [ph], our fraud platform, are underway and expected to be operational in mid-2017. 
The NPI process has been established with the local leadership team and will be incorporating the Veda NPI revenue into our Vitality Index beginning in 2017. 
We've also identified a number of opportunities to export some of Veda's products to other international geographies. Debt placement from the U.K. government is now up to GBP 1.6 billion. And our performance year-to-date, it's exceeding the baseline performance we had established.  
We now have all 6 founding agencies of the U.K. government boarded and have analytical projects underway with 2 additional agencies. While the initiative is still in the early stages, we're extremely pleased with both our relationship with the U.K. agencies and the financial results we're delivering. 
Organic revenue in international's 5 largest verticals, FI, telco, government, retail and auto. In aggregate, was up 13% for the quarter. International decisioning platforms, analytical services and debt management services revenue grew 19% in the quarter. This high-value -- the high-value solutions continues to strengthen our relationships with customers and our market position. 
In the coming quarters, we will be installing more sophisticated technology platforms i.e., InterConnect, our Ostra [ph] platform and Cambrian throughout our international footprint drive future revenue growth. 
Canada continues to grow very good momentum with trended data. In the third quarter, we launched Cambrian platform, which will further enhance our competitive position with best-in-class solutions, leveraging trended data. 
International is expected to deliver organic constant currency revenue growth in the fourth quarter and the full year, above the upper end of this long-term model of 8% to 10%. 
Reported revenue growth for 2016 is expected to approach 55%.  Adjusted EBITDA margins should increase sequentially and exit the year approaching 30%. 
Workforce Solutions' strong moment has resulted in another outstanding performance in the third quarter, with 23% revenue growth and a 350-basis-point expansion in the EBITDA -- adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Total records in the Work Number database now approaches our short-term goal of $300 million with over 6,600 different data contributors to that database. Our initiatives to further penetrate key verticals led to strong double-digit growth in mortgage, auto, government and preemployment, to name a few. 
Revenue from our health care vertical comprised of income and employment verification for CMS and ACA analytics from employers grew over 240% in the quarter. 
In the quarter, Workforce Solutions completed the acquisition of Barnett/VJS, a small regional provider of employment and income verification and unemployment insurance services, to further accelerate the growth of the Work Number database. It's early days but it's going very well. 
As I stated earlier this week, a little more color around Fannie Mae, they announced the integration of our full suite of employment and income verification services into their desktop underwriting platform. The employment and income verification services includes data from Workforce Solutions with Work Number database providing instant and waterfall employment and income verification services. 
With these services, our earnings cycle times will be reduced and the lender's reliance on applicant providing W-2, pay stubs or other income or documentations will be eliminated, and this gives them protection should a mortgage not perform and protects them from having the banks put the mortgages back to them. So it's a great benefit for EWS. 
Workforce Solutions is having an outstanding year in 2016 both organic and reported revenue growth are expected to exceed 15% in the fourth quarter and 20% for 2016, substantially above its long-term range of 9% to 11%. Adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to be nicely over 45% for the fourth quarter 2016 and the high 40s for the full year. Global Consumer Solutions continues to make great progress on strategic initiatives particularly building out a strong market position in both DTC reseller and indirect markets that include partnerships with a number of very successful companies that we've talked about before, such as Credit Karma, LifeLock, H&R Block and others. 
We're pleased to announce we have executed a new longer-term partnership with Credit Karma. The new and expanded partnership is focused on growing both of our businesses by leveraging unique data assets, innovation and analytics, including the use of our Cambrian platform and expanding our partnerships beyond the borders of the U.S. 
This quarter, we deployed our new Global Consumer platform called renaissance, a best-in-class SaaS-based e-commerce platform, which provides much greater marketing flexibility to serve our partners. During the quarter, we successfully transitioned one of our largest customers to this new platform and by the end of 2017, we will have deployed this newest platform across all portions of our U.S. business and will be well in our way to deploying it across other geographies in which we operate. 
Global Consumer Solutions is expected to deliver fourth quarter and full year 2016 constant currency revenue growth exceeding 15% with fourth quarter and full year adjusted EBITDA margin at approximately 30%. 
Few high-level points at the corporate level before John gets into the financial details. Things we've talked to you about before that's so important to our culture and our results. First is our enterprise growth initiatives, which are our largest and most complex growth initiatives we have. They're performing very well in 2016, with revenue generation projected to be up over 35% from our expectations earlier this year and over 3x the revenue generated from EGI in 2015. 
Our overall performance in new product innovations, initiatives in 2016 is also outstanding. The 3-year revenue from our 2016 launches is expected to be more than 170% above the expected 3-year revenue from out 2015 launches. This is the strongest NPI performance we've had since it was built and created some 10 years ago. 
Our Vitality Index we had last year and the pipeline of new products continues to be very robust. To date, we've launched approximately 40 new products and expect to launch another 20 products before year-end. 
In summary, our strategic initiatives continue to perform well and are ahead of our expectations that we had at the beginning of the year. With this continued focus on improving the process, allows us to drive continuous growth. I expect these initiatives will continue to drive and deliver incremental revenue growth in 2017 and beyond. 
So with that, John?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin so we
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and good morning, everyone. As before, I will generally refer to the financial results from continuing operations represented on a GAAP basis. As a reminder, following the Veda acquisition, we started focusing on adjusted EBITDA margin so we're consistently present the operating of the segments and the company as a whole. The non-GAAP reconciliation attached to our earnings release provides a more detailed description of what is included in the adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Now, let me turn to the business units financial performance for the third quarter. U.S. Information Solutions revenue was $317 million, up 9% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. 
Online Information Solutions revenue was $230 million, up 7% when compared to the year-ago period. Total mortgage-related revenue in USIS was up 39% in the quarter. The Mortgage Bankers Application Index growth accelerated significantly, up 35% in the third quarter compared to the 20% growth we saw in the second quarter. 
Given a much stronger mortgage market performance on 3Q '16 and continued accommodative  interest rate environment, we now expect the mortgage market to grow solidly double-digit in 2016. 
Financial marketing services revenue was $48 million, up 3% when compared to the year-ago quarter. Our commercial products suite grew 8% in 3Q. We have made great progress building the Equifax commercial financial network, which includes tradeline data from banking and other financial institutions similar to the SBFE, as well as communications and utilities, wholesale trade, printing, publishing, chemicals and allied products and rental and leasing data. 
When combined with Equifax consumer credit data, we can now offer substantially differentiated data and analytics to our U.S. commercial customers. 
Identity and Fraud Solutions also continue to grow strongly, up 19% in 3Q and 23% year-to-date. USIS direct-to-consumer revenue, principally our revenue with other CRAs, was down over 20% in the quarter and largely in line with the first half. 
The adjusted EBITDA margin for U.S. Information Solutions in 3Q '16 was 50.6%, up from 49.9% in the third quarter of 2015. Workforce Solutions revenue was $171 million for the quarter, up 23% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. Verification Services revenue of $115 million was also up 23% and continues to be driven by strong double-digit growth across mortgage, government, auto and preemployment. 
Employer Services revenue of $57 million was up 23% from last year as well. Revenue growth from unemployment insurance, I-9, tax incentives and other HR services was consistent with the annual model of mid-single digit growth. 
ACA analytics revenue was up substantially in the quarter versus 3Q '15, driving much of the growth. As we had indicated previously, ACA analytics revenue was down sequentially and from the first half run rate. As expected, given that the ACA business is seasonal with higher revenue in the first half of the year when 1095s are delivered to employees. 
The Workforce Solutions adjusted EBITDA margin was 47%, up from 43.5% in 3Q '15 and in line with our expectations. Revenue from USIS and Workforce Solutions, our total U.S. B2B revenue was $489 million, representing organic growth of 13%. 
International's revenue was $214 million, up 47% on a reported basis and 60% on a local currency basis when compared to 3Q '15. Organic constant currency revenue growth was approximately 10%. 
By region, Europe's revenue was $62 million, up 2% in U.S. dollars and up 16% in local currency. We have seen some moderate impact on local currency revenue following the Brexit vote, with selected large U.K. financial institutions. 
Debt management grew nicely in the quarter as our relationship with the U.K. government continues to perform as we had expected. The sharp depreciation of the British pound following the Brexit vote in late July significantly impacted U.S. dollar revenue growth in the region for the third quarter. 
The almost 7% decline in the British pound in early October will further impact 4Q '16 U.S. dollar revenue growth. Latin America's revenue was $47 million, down 9% in U.S. dollars but up 9% in local currency. The over 60% depreciation of the Argentinian peso from late December of 2015 through March of '16 has negatively impacted the U.S. dollar performance of our largest and most profitable country in the region. 
Asia Pacific revenue was $74 million, which is comprised mostly of revenue from Veda. Canada revenue was $32 million, up 4% in U.S. dollars and up 3% in local currency. Canada continues to perform in line with our expectations, including substantial improvements and the New Product Innovation initiatives, which includes trended data. 
For the third quarter, international's adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.4%, up nicely from 26.2% in 3Q '15. On a constant currency basis, margins expanded over 300 basis points versus 3Q '15 and almost 50 basis points sequentially. As Rick indicated, 4Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margins are expected to increase sequentially and approach 30% in 4Q '16. 
Global Consumer Solutions revenue was $101 million, up 12% on a reported basis and up 14% on a local currency basis. Growth, again, was driven by our direct-to-consumer reseller customers. For the third quarter, the adjusted EBITDA margin was 30%, in line with our expectations. The adjusted EBITDA margin was down from 30.8% in 3Q '15, but up significantly from the 26.4% in 2Q '16 when we were boarding LifeLock. 
In the third quarter, general corporate expense was $52 million consistent with our expectations. For the fourth quarter, total general corporate expense is expected to be slightly above $55 million. The adjusted EBITDA margin was 35.9%, up 130 basis points from 34.6% in 2015. The strength in adjusted EBITDA margins reflects year-over-year growth in USIS, Workforce Solutions and international. 
We expect the fourth Q '16 adjusted EBITDA margin to be above Q3 adjusted EBITDA margin and our full year 2016 adjusted EBITDA margin to be up more than 100 basis points from the 34.7% we achieved in 2015. 
As Rick mentioned before, this is nicely above the target for 2016 of a 75-basis-point expansion in our adjusted EBITDA margin. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter at 29.1% was below the anticipated level of 32.5%, which we communicated during our July earnings call. 
The lower effective tax rate reflects several discrete or onetime items, which benefited our effective tax rate by over 3 percentage points and our adjusted EPS by about $0.05 a share. 
Our current expectation is that Q4 tax rate will be approximately 32.5%. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $48 million and year-to-date are $131 million. We continue to expect capital expenditures for the year to be about 6% of revenue, which is at the high-end of our long-term range as investments are made related to our integration of Veda. 
Year-to-date, operating cash flow remained strong at $525 million. Total debt in the quarter was $2.86 billion. We continue to reduce our leverage following the Veda acquisition, which is now down at 2.58x. Our target is to reduce leverage back to approximately 2.25x EBITDA, which we expect to occur in 2017. 
Now let me turn it back to Rick.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I trust you agree 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the company has resulted in a broad-based performance that significantly exceeded the expectations we had at the beginning of the
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I trust you agree 2016 has been an outstanding year for the company. Strong and consistent execution throughout the company has resulted in a broad-based performance that significantly exceeded the expectations we had at the beginning of the year. We firmly believe this positions us well for growth in 2017. 
For the fourth quarter, at current exchange rates, we expect revenue to be between $797 million and $801 million. Effective constant currency revenue growth of just over 22%, partially offset by about 2% of FX headwind. This reflects organic growth of over 12%. The almost 7% depreciation in the U.K. pound in early October, which John just referenced, resulted in the majority of the incremental $6 million of FX headwind versus our expectations for the fourth quarter when we gave guidance back in July. 
Adjusted EPS is expected to be between $1.35 and $1.38, which is up 18% to 21% for the fourth quarter. Excluding $0.03 per share of negative FX, this reflects constant currency adjusted EPS growth of 21% to 24%. 
With this outlook, our second half organic constant currency growth is approximately 12% and in line with the outlook we gave in the second half revenue growth during our second quarter earnings call, which you will recall, which we guided to 11% to 13%. 
For the year now, we expect revenue to be approximately $3.145 billion, reflecting constant currency revenue growth of approximately 21%, partially offset by 3% of FX headwind. 
Adjusting for the significant depreciation and FX, principally the British pound, this is at the high-end of the guidance we provided in July. This is also impressive performance by the team when compared to the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year. For revenue, as you recall, we guided to more than $3 billion, $3.1 billion in revenue. 
Adjusted EPS for the year is expected to be between $5.45 and $5.48, which is up 21% to 22%. Excluding approximately $0.14 per share full year in negative impact from FX. This reflects constant currency adjusted EPS growth of 24% to 25%. This is up significantly from the guidance we provided you in July and compares favorably from the guidance we gave at the beginning of the year for adjusted EPS, which you remember was $4.95 to $5.05. 
For the year, we now expect adjusted EBITDA margins to expand by over 100 basis points up from the previous expectations, which were 75 basis points. As we look forward, we remain confident in our ability to deliver on our long-term constant currency financial model of total revenue growth of 7% to 10% per year with organic revenue growth of 6% to 8%. 
As we look to 2017, considering all of the acquisitions closed to-date, which to refresh your memory were Veda and the small Barnett acquisition, we expect to achieve revenue growth at the high-end of our total growth model. As it's too early to make a call in the U.S. mortgage market, this assumes the U.S. mortgage market will be largely flat in 2017. And as always, we'll provide you more detail on our outlook for 2017 during our February call. 
But at this point in time, with the way the team is executing on the growth initiatives in EGI and NPI, we remain very bullish throughout this in 2017. 
So operator, with that, John, I'd like to open up for questions for our participants.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next -- our first question from David Togut from Evercore ISI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, to just talk generically, to get these specifics. You've heard me talk in the past, David,  the things going on from a growth perspective starting with really Dan Adams[ph] 5, 6 years ago, continuing under Rudy now are just phenomenal. They're so bro
componenttext: Yes, to just talk generically, to get these specifics. You've heard me talk in the past, David,  the things going on from a growth perspective starting with really Dan Adams[ph] 5, 6 years ago, continuing under Rudy now are just phenomenal. They're so broad based. If you think about it, the penetration, which is one way to think about hit rate, each vertical continues to go up. And we continue to expand the size of the database, continue to grow analytics on the data. Their growth opportunity, you know our long-term model is very, very bullish, up single digits to lower double digits. There based on specific projects going on right now, and continue to find ways to build the hit rate and work on the records. So generally speaking, it is long term, our highest growth opportunity business we have and we remain very bullish.

componenttext: Yes, as we've talked in the past, this business should -- because of the great leverage we have, much like the core USIS business or pockets of international, you get high incremental margin, especially on the verification side. We're doing great things on the employer side, add automation, enhanced margin there. So there's no reason to believe that business over multiple years should not be approaching 50%-plus EBITDA margins.

componenttext: Got it. And then shifting gears to U.S. CIS, mortgage continues to outperform and I caught your comment about next year and conservatively expecting flattish mortgage market. How do you think about what the Fed might do in the next couple of months? And how that might impact mortgage, which has benefited from an incredibly positive environment with rates as low as they are?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I expect refinancing to -- assuming they do, they're all with the board. That's why we said, in February, we'll give you a better look. We'll have a -- and hopefully some better insight, that's I'm sure. You're saying ranges from 1 rate increase to 2
componenttext: Yes, I expect refinancing to -- assuming they do, they're all with the board. That's why we said, in February, we'll give you a better look. We'll have a -- and hopefully some better insight, that's I'm sure. You're saying ranges from 1 rate increase to 2 to 3 rate increases up to 75 basis points, as low as 25 basis points next year. Still historically low rates. You may see some softening in the refinancing but continue to see good strength in home equity and home sales. I think the thing that we got to keep our eye on general terms on mortgage is affordability. So where the pricing -- as pricing go across the country and what affordability index look like, but beyond that said, there are so many great things we talk about, that the team has done for -- I don't know, it's been and 7, 8, 9, 10 years, which has outperformed whatever the index does through penetration and innovation. And we talked about, obviously, trended data for Fannie Mae for USIS. We've talked about the use now of the verification income and employment. Those are just 2 small examples, but the important examples of how we're trying to grow regardless what the market does.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just final question on trended data, just trying to assess competitively where you stand versus your Chicago-based competitor, which is also been pretty aggressive here. You seem to have a very deep offering. They may have a little bit of
componenttext: Understood. And just final question on trended data, just trying to assess competitively where you stand versus your Chicago-based competitor, which is also been pretty aggressive here. You seem to have a very deep offering. They may have a little bit of a time lead if that's an accurate perception, but it seems like you have a deeper range of services coming to market in the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I was trying to find a way around the trended data. I've been very consistent with that. We were experimenting with that there first, with batch trended data years ago. So clearly, to you, Equifax, we are not the leaders, if you look at it holisti
componenttext: I think I was trying to find a way around the trended data. I've been very consistent with that. We were experimenting with that there first, with batch trended data years ago. So clearly, to you, Equifax, we are not the leaders, if you look at it holistically through batch and online. However, we have move aggressively and have moved aggressively over the years in all of our geographies to embrace trended data. I mentioned on the call, we have the most unique data assets, so it's not just the credit file that's trended. We talked about it over 80 months of trended data in Cambrian, our analytical environment. And that's many different data assets, not just the credit file. And we're moving. You'll see us move dramatically beyond the 24-month of credit data that's trended in a production environment in 2017, well beyond even 30 months, which I think, is a benchmark out in the marketplace today. So we're not handicapped in any way, in fact, I think we're leading in many senses on trended data.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned 2017 is shaping up to be at the long term of the constant currency revenue growth range of 7% to 10%. I just want to check my math that, that would be about 2 points of closed acquisitions, right? So we're talking 5 to 8 organic? And the sec
componenttext: You mentioned 2017 is shaping up to be at the long term of the constant currency revenue growth range of 7% to 10%. I just want to check my math that, that would be about 2 points of closed acquisitions, right? So we're talking 5 to 8 organic? And the second question is, at that level of revenue growth, will margin expansion pay above the long-term range for 2017?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I'm trying to say, my words to you is -- in total, will be at the upper end of our 7% to 10%. So you can decipher what that means but possibly in the upper end of that range. So the organic growth by default, if you use your math is 2.7% [ph] wi
componenttext: Yes. What I'm trying to say, my words to you is -- in total, will be at the upper end of our 7% to 10%. So you can decipher what that means but possibly in the upper end of that range. So the organic growth by default, if you use your math is 2.7% [ph] within the organic range of 6% to 8%. But we also have very strong pipeline and other M&A things we can be doing, tuck-in acquisitions that makes sense to us and all of our strategic areas and geographies around the world. So we've been very disciplined this year with only the small acquisition of Barnett. You should expect us to be thoughtful in doing strategic M&A on top of that next year. And on margin, our target is to deliver 25 basis points per year of margin expansion over multiple years. So you should continue to expect margin expansion next year in that range.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Manav Patnaik from Barclays.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Firstly, congratulations on another board-based quarter, and I'm sure we'll keep asking you for updates on trended data and the collections contract and so forth. But what I wanted to ask you is after these 16 new products that you are scheduled to launch
componenttext: Firstly, congratulations on another board-based quarter, and I'm sure we'll keep asking you for updates on trended data and the collections contract and so forth. But what I wanted to ask you is after these 16 new products that you are scheduled to launch this year, as we look out into '17 and '18, like what are some of the other products or initiatives we should be focused on outside of just trended data and so forth? It sounded like the fraud platform you said that launches next summer, may be one of those? I was just hoping you could give us a sneak preview at other stuff we should be looking out for?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, thank you, Manav, for your kind words. NPI is so ingrained in everything we do now. When you think about it, you're launching 50 to 75 products a year, or in this case, 60 products. It's different by geography. Most of our NPIs you know, ten
componenttext: First of all, thank you, Manav, for your kind words. NPI is so ingrained in everything we do now. When you think about it, you're launching 50 to 75 products a year, or in this case, 60 products. It's different by geography. Most of our NPIs you know, tend to be singles and doubles if I used a baseball analogy. Every once in a while you hit some big ones like trended data. Fraud, obviously, is a very important growth opportunity for us in the international environment. We've talked about moving, what we call Ostra  [ph] around the world that will be a nice contributor. Mobile, we're doing a lot now around the mobile world and finding out ways to participate in the mobile environment. So we get some great product launches planned later on this year and next year in mobile. Those are 2 examples, which I can give you 100 more. But think about it again, as you know us so well, there's a lot of singles and doubles. That's where we're winning NPI.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair enough. And then just on the Credit Karma contract. So I think in the past, you gave us your revenue contribution from them. I was hoping you could do that. But it does sounds like the contract is much broader than what in the past I thi
componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. And then just on the Credit Karma contract. So I think in the past, you gave us your revenue contribution from them. I was hoping you could do that. But it does sounds like the contract is much broader than what in the past I think you guys were giving just reports and the scores. I just want to confirm, if I heard that right. And in terms of expanding internationally, when we heard from Credit Karma at The Money 2020 Conference, they mentioned Canada, but is there anything more than that, that you were referring to?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. We don't disclose Credit Karma revenue, but I'll tell you this. It's been a great partnership. It's been a wonderful win-win partnership for 2 years. We've now signed a multiyear contract, much longer term. It will utilize our environment,
componenttext: Yes, thank you. We don't disclose Credit Karma revenue, but I'll tell you this. It's been a great partnership. It's been a wonderful win-win partnership for 2 years. We've now signed a multiyear contract, much longer term. It will utilize our environment, Cambrian, which is different than the past. It will be focused on innovation, so building products out of Cambrian together. It will focus on our unique data assets, way beyond just the credit file itself. And then as you alluded to in your closing thoughts here, it will be going global as well and beyond Canada. I'm not going to disclose the specific countries, but there are some countries that they are very interested in, that we have good market positions and capabilities in, good data assets in. And together, we'll both grow business opportunities for us and the consumers in those geographies. It is a really good -- it was a very complicated long process, but the 2 teams came to a great win-win for both of us for many years to come.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just last question from me. You've talked about this active M&A pipeline for some time now. I was hoping if you could just characterize it in terms of the varying sizes of the deal you're looking at? Because I think the one that you guys are r
componenttext: Got it. And just last question from me. You've talked about this active M&A pipeline for some time now. I was hoping if you could just characterize it in terms of the varying sizes of the deal you're looking at? Because I think the one that you guys are rumored to be looking at in Australia seems a little bigger than tuck-in, but I was just curious on if you could give any color to there?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you noticed and you noticed for years, if you think about my 11 years here, we've done 3 large deals. We did TALX 9.5, 10 years. We did CSC. We did Veda. And the vast majority of anything else we've done are small tuck-ins, trying to get us t
componenttext: Yes, I think you noticed and you noticed for years, if you think about my 11 years here, we've done 3 large deals. We did TALX 9.5, 10 years. We did CSC. We did Veda. And the vast majority of anything else we've done are small tuck-ins, trying to get us that 1 to 2 points of growth per year, which is our model. You should expect us to be in that range looking for small tuck-in acquisitions well aligned with our strategy and deliver 1 to 2 points of incremental growth next year. That would be our goal.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Next we have George Mihalos with Cowen.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Wanted to start off, I'm sure you're not going to size the impact in the quarter of the trended data mortgage contribution. But is it safe to say, it came in somewhere, ballparking, at a little bit below a percentage point of overall revenue growth
componenttext: Great. Wanted to start off, I'm sure you're not going to size the impact in the quarter of the trended data mortgage contribution. But is it safe to say, it came in somewhere, ballparking, at a little bit below a percentage point of overall revenue growth? And then John, your comments on the margins for USIS being, I think, at least 50% for 4Q. Should we not expect a little bit of a step-up from the 3Q levels given the full quarter of trended data and then just sort of normal seasonality?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me jump in the first part and John, if you want address margin. And I'll give you general vision on margin. We don't breakout trended data as a specific line item. But George, you should think of it this way, as we set up guidance back in July, in the
componenttext: Let me jump in the first part and John, if you want address margin. And I'll give you general vision on margin. We don't breakout trended data as a specific line item. But George, you should think of it this way, as we set up guidance back in July, in the second half of the year and specifically for the third quarter, the trended data contribution for USIS came in largely as expected, almost no -- in fact, no mutual deviation from our expectations. It was performing, as expected. It's fairly predictable for us to model that contribution. As far as margins, you've got, and you know this, you have fluctuations month-by-month, quarter-by-quarter. There are mix changes each and every quarter. There are seasonality changes. Mortgage is lower volume in the fourth quarter than other quarters. So you put it altogether, I don't really worry about minor changes by quarter. It's really the multiyear trends and USIS is starting up with a very, very high margin trending in the right direction.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've seen really nice growth in our margin, obviously, in the third quarter. Good performance in the second quarter. So I'd say our margin performance is accelerating, and you should expect to continue to see very good margin accretion in the fourth
componenttext: And you've seen really nice growth in our margin, obviously, in the third quarter. Good performance in the second quarter. So I'd say our margin performance is accelerating, and you should expect to continue to see very good margin accretion in the fourth quarter. We gave a range of over 50%, but you'll see very nice margin accretion on the fourth quarter as well. And again, consistent -- the company has delivered outstanding performance overall as we said year-to-year. USIS is a contributor to that, and we expect it to continue, and we feel very confident in our long-term model of moving toward 40% in our long-term model.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just last question for me as it relates to the Credit Karma expansion, anything we should be mindful of from a pricing perspective as we model the consumer services, the consumer division going to '17?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just last question for me as it relates to the Credit Karma expansion, anything we should be mindful of from a pricing perspective as we model the consumer services, the consumer division going to '17?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's -- I would describe it really as an apples and orange contract. If you think of the old contract, it was one geography, one basic product. And as we alluded to, it is now multiple geographies, multiple products and innovations. So it is going to
componenttext: No. It's -- I would describe it really as an apples and orange contract. If you think of the old contract, it was one geography, one basic product. And as we alluded to, it is now multiple geographies, multiple products and innovations. So it is going to be a growth driver for Credit Karma. This can be a long-term growth driver for us as well.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Andre Benjamin with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's my first question. Lenders, as we listen to commentary from large banks have been largely talking a lot about prime and super prime consumers. But I was wondering as you continue to rule out deeper analytics, how much your conversation is talking a
componenttext: Here's my first question. Lenders, as we listen to commentary from large banks have been largely talking a lot about prime and super prime consumers. But I was wondering as you continue to rule out deeper analytics, how much your conversation is talking about the ability to use Cambrian, trended data, alternative data to get more comfortable lending to weaker credit consumers? Largely, because I know when you frame trended data, you also talked about the uplift to prime loans, I don't know how, but what that looks like for subprime as well?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good questions. The answer is yes. We are and have been actively engaged in leveraging our unique data assets to give the underwriters a more holistic view of risk. And that could be things like leveraging the debt-to-income data that we have, not mo
componenttext: Yes, good questions. The answer is yes. We are and have been actively engaged in leveraging our unique data assets to give the underwriters a more holistic view of risk. And that could be things like leveraging the debt-to-income data that we have, not modeled but actual debt income, it can be using our MCE plus database, which gives insight to how consumers will pay off their utility obligations. You have a score. And, in fact, many parts of Latin America where the credit markets are nascent, we're leveraging alternative data assets there to help bring people into the credit markets. So that's an active part of our strategy and has been for quite some time and will be going forward.

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: More directly, is it fair to say that the uplift that you observed analyzing some of those lower quality credits is the same or higher or lower relative to the prime bucket?
componenttext: More directly, is it fair to say that the uplift that you observed analyzing some of those lower quality credits is the same or higher or lower relative to the prime bucket?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends on the vertical you're looking at and geography you're looking at. The lift you might get in the credit card offering versus an auto loan would be different in different parts of the country as well, and will be different depending how y
componenttext: It really depends on the vertical you're looking at and geography you're looking at. The lift you might get in the credit card offering versus an auto loan would be different in different parts of the country as well, and will be different depending how you want us segment subprime from super subprime. So there are so many nuances. There's no one generic answer. You can get back about the [indiscernible] the teams, the D&A teams, and I mentioned in my prepared comments, are deeply engaged with our customers around the world looking at ways to make the smarter underwriting decisions, including subprime.

componenttext: Well, I mentioned in my prepared comments and this has been a couple of years in a now. It's extremely broad based. It's a good growth contributor, but there are so many other things going on across EWS' revenue growth. It's far more than just ACA.

componenttext: Sure. And then my last question is have there been any surprises on the Veda integration so far? And is the expectation still for EPS accretion of $0.20?

headline: Equifax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: The answer to the last part of your question is yes. And the answer to the first part of the question is no. No surprises. I mean every time you buy a company, you may have a surprise here and there, but nothing material by any means. It's going extremely well. We've got members of the Veda team up here right now. Teams down there. So it's -- cultural integration will take, as it always does, the longer than process integration. The acceptance from the customers are the things we can help bring to those mortgage has been warmly received. So all in all, it's going very well.
